summary:
=================

The study aims to identify specific clusters of variables that are specific to the onset and maintenance of chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia. The hypothesis is that specific psychological factors (clusters of high number of early traumatic events, high levels of central sensitization, and specific traits and defense mechanisms) characterize FM, CM, and VU groups compared to controls. The study will involve the administration of a protocol of self-report questionnaires consisting of two parts: the main (about 25 minutes for the administration) and the optional one (additional 20 minutes). The primary outcome measures will be central sensitivity index, traumatic experiences index, personality traits, defense mechanisms, mental pain, and environmental sensitivity. The secondary outcome measures will be presence and intensity of psychological symptoms of depression, anxiety and psychosomatics, physical and psychological quality of life index, alexithymic traits, perceived social support, sexual satisfaction, genital pain, and sexual functioning.

The study aims to compare the pressure ulcer prevention effects of two mattresses with different support surfaces used in bedridden patients. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, triple-masked study. The experimental group received a massage mattress with a cube/block system, while the control group received a standard of care mattress. The study measured the number of patients without pressure ulcers. The study followed up patients for four weeks.

=================

The study aims to investigate the effect of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values and quality of life in children aged 10-12 with type 1 diabetes. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an experimental group and a control group. The experimental group will receive exercise with augmented reality glasses for two days a week for 12 weeks, while the control group will receive no intervention. The primary outcome measures will be changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Istanbul.

=================

The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery. The study will be conducted in the Trakya University Health Research Center General Surgery Clinic between 01.03.2023 and 01.12.2023. The study will consist of 32 patients in each group (intervention, placebo, and control). The intervention group will watch a virtual reality video with mobile virtual glasses, while the placebo group will watch the same video over the phone with the naked eye. The control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the preoperative anxiety level, measured by the stress level on the smart bracelet and the VAS-A scale before and after watching the video. The study will use the experimental research method and will be randomized. The study will be conducted by the researcher (SŞ) and the necessary hygiene will be provided before the use of glasses. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Trakya University Health Research Center Ethics Committee.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL for abdominal wound closure in men and women patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery. The study is a single arm prospective interventional study. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4. Secondary outcome measures include stitch count, numbers of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons’ comfort with device during closure, and surgeons’ satisfaction with final closure result. The study is designed to measure the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL for abdominal wound closure in men and women patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery.

The study aims to investigate the immune biomarkers of salivary gland carcinoma and to develop a liquid immune profile-based signature (LIPS) for the diagnosis and prognosis of salivary gland carcinoma. The study will recruit 100 patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma in the head and neck region and 100 healthy controls. The patients will be divided into three groups: an observational group, a control group with benign salivary gland tumors, and a control group with functional diseases of the nose or ear. The study will measure changes in the immune matrix, longitudinal immunophenotyping, cytokine expression, metabolic state, and microbiomic state of the patients. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 5 years.

=================

The study aims to determine compliance with the Mediterranean diet, the tendency to use various nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related problems and quality of life in MS patients and to evaluate whether there is a significant relationship between these parameters. The study will use the 14-item Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale (PREDIMED) to determine the adaptation status of individuals to the Mediterranean diet, the Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale to determine the quality of life of individuals, the 12-item Ms Gait Scale to determine the gait impact, and the Expanded Disability Status Scale to determine the disability status of the patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year and will involve 100 participants. The primary outcome measures will be Mediterranean Diet Compliance Status, Quality of Life Of Multiple Sclerosis Patients, Impacts on Walking, and Expanded Disability Status Scale.

The SIIT-CD Study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled study that evaluates the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's Disease. The study includes 100 patients who are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (SIIT group) or the non-intervention group (non-intensive induction therapy group). The experimental group receives selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools, while the non-intervention group receives standard induction therapy. The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive induction regimen and the standard induction regimen. The study is designed to be open label, and the intervention model is parallel assignment. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the participating centers.

The study aims to investigate the preference of a culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) population for second line overactive bladder (OAB) therapy. The study uses a discrete choice experiment to measure the preference of patients for two fictive therapies, each option comes with it's own botox and sacral neuromodulator (SNM) characteristics. The study is designed for adult patients with OAB and excludes those with a history of SNM or Botox. This is a three-arm pragmatic randomized study to evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of the use of continuous glucose monitoring devices among people living with type 1 diabetes in South Africa. The study will recruit 180 participants (150 adults and 30 children) from three study clinics in South Africa. Participants will be randomized to one of three arms: continuous use of CGM, intermittent use of CGM, or standard of care. The primary outcome measure will be the change in HbA1c levels from baseline to end of intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include the variability of blood glucose concentrations related to diabetes, unplanned visits to outpatient clinics and/or hospital related to diabetes complications, and quality of life of recipients of diabetes care and their caregivers. The study will also assess the acceptability and feasibility of continuous and intermittent CGM use from a healthcare provider, recipients of care, and caregivers perspective. Costing surveys will also be conducted to determine the cost of continuous and intermittent CGM use from a user and provider perspective. The study will be conducted over a period of 15 months.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fractionated stereotactic ablative body radiotherapy (SBRT) with focal boost on dominant lesion in localized prostate cancer. The study will enroll 50 patients with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate, primary localized PCa, cN0 and cM0, intermediate or high-risk disease according to NCCN 2023, visible dominant lesion on mpMRI, ECOG 0-1, IPSS ≤ 18, and desirable prostate volume (not mandatory). The study will use SBRT 36.25 Gy in 5 sessions of 7.25 Gy to the entire prostate (including seminal vesicles) with a DIL simultaneous integrated focal boost (SIB) up to 50 Gy in 5 sessions, with partial protection of the prostatic urethra and bladder trigone. The primary outcome measure will be biochemical progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures will be incidence and severity of acute urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, incidence and severity of late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, and patient reported outcomes and quality of life assessment. The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with open label masking.

The SMILER project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) as an emerging e-health intervention for young people with neurological or respiratory disorders. The study will recruit 100 children with controlled asthma, aged 12-17 years, who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (SG) or the control group (standard treatment plan). The intervention group will play the SG for 30 minutes, three times a week for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita), both administered at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the University of Pisa.

The SMILER project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) as an emerging e-health intervention for young people with neurological or respiratory disorders. The study will recruit 100 children with controlled asthma, aged 12-17 years, who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (SG) or the control group (standard treatment plan). The intervention group will play the SG for 30 minutes, three times a week for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita), both administered at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the University of Pisa.

The study aims to investigate the neural and behavioral correlates of pavlovian to instrumental transfer (PIT) in humans. The study will use a 2x2 between-subjects design with two groups (AUD and non-AUD) and two conditions (acute and chronic stress). The study will use a PIT paradigm with four parts: an instrumental learning task, a classical conditioning task, a third part measuring interference at the instrumental response level, and a final part with query trials. The study will also use a Counting Stroop task, a No-go Simon task, and a Stop Signal reaction time task to assess interference at the stimulus and response level. The study will use fMRI imaging (BOLD) and sMRI (structure) to investigate neural correlates of PIT effects. The study will also use questionnaires for chronic stress, hair samples for cortisol measurement, and saliva samples for cortisol measurement to assess chronic and acute stress effects. The study will also use smartphones with additional mobile sensors to measure physical activity, data on location, geolocation-based triggering of e-Diaries, self-reported stress reactivity, cue exposure, drug craving, impulsivity, and drug consumption. The study will also use a clinical diagnostic (SKID-I Interview) to assess neurocognitive and psychopathological functioning. The study will also use genetic and epigenetic testing to explore outcome prediction using polygenic risk scores. The Flow and Grow study is a multicenter, non-blinded, randomized control trial that aims to determine the optimal time to wean CPAP off in extremely low birth weight infants. The study will involve 130 infants, a target sample size determined based on retrospective data from all of the participating units. The weaning protocol in the treatment group will incorporate algorithms outlining stability criteria, failure criteria, and algorithms for registered nurses (RNs) and respiratory therapists (RTs), including steps to take in such situations. The control group will be weaned according to the unit's or medical team's practices. The primary endpoint of the study is a binomial outcome (failed CPAP wean, yes/no). The study will be conducted at four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) within the Rady Children's/University of California, San Diego network, including Rady Children's Hospital - San Diego, Jacobs Medical Center, Scripps La Jolla (Rady NICU) and Rancho Springs (Rady NICU). The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

The study is a phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Frexalimab (SAR441344) in adults with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis. The study will enroll 240 participants who will be randomized to receive either Frexalimab or placebo. The primary outcome measure is time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) confirmed over 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include time to onset of composite cCDP confirmed over 3 months, time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3-months or 6-months, time to onset of confirmed disability improvement (CDI), number of new and/or enlarging T2-hyperintense lesions per scan as detected by MRI, and number of new and/or enlarging T2-hyperintense lesions per month. The study will also assess change from baseline in multiple sclerosis impact scale 29 version 2 (MSIS-29v2) questionnaire scores over time, change from baseline in patient reported outcome measurement information system (PROMIS) Fatigue multiple sclerosis (MS)-8a over time, annualized relapse rate during the study period assessed by protocol defined adjudicated relapses, number of participants with adverse events, SAEs, AEs leading to permanent study intervention discontinuation and AE of special interests (AESIs), number of participants with potentially clinically significant abnormalities (PCSAs) in laboratory tests, ECG, and vital signs during the study period, number of participants with antibody over time, change from baseline in serum Ig levels over time, change from baseline in plasma neurofilament light chain (NfL) levels over time, and Frexalimab plasma concentration over time. The study will be conducted over a period of 204 weeks.

Endoscopic Management Of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula As A Complication of Acute Diverticulitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic management of controlled colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute diverticulitis. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 66 patients divided into two groups: endoscopic group and surgical group. The endoscopic group received endoscopic management of the fistula using OTSC, while the surgical group received sigmoid resection with primary anastomosis with circular stapler. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of recurrence of the fistula within one week after the endoscopy, while the secondary outcome measure is the incidence of side effects of endoscopy within one month after the surgery. The study is currently ongoing and has not yet been completed.

=========

This is a randomized, un-blinded study comparing usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing. The study aims to improve the screening of heart failure and identify patients at risk for heart failure earlier. The intervention group will have NT-proBNP drawn and those with an elevated NT-proBNP will have a study visit with assessments to include, physical examination, electrocardiogram and study AI echocardiogram. The study will measure the incidence of HF diagnosis in outpatient settings, number of outpatient HF visits, number of urgent HF visit, number of HF hospitalizations, incidence of prescription for guideline recommended HF therapies in patients diagnosed with HFrEF, and number of HF events in HFrEF. The study will enroll participants for six months.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the effects of Propofol dose according to lean body weight by evaluating patients with bodymass index below 35. Patients who will be induction of anesthesia with propofol will have a body analysis with Tanita before the operation. Patients' height, weight, age, gender and other general information will be recorded. Total body weight (TBW), ideal body weight (IBW) and lean body weight (LBW) of the patients will be calculated. Patients over the age of 18 who will be operated under general anesthesia for 2-6 hours will be included. Patients with propofol allergy or contraindicated to propofol are included in the study. In order to decide and try the most appropriate weight-based scalar for propofol dosing for anesthesia induction to be evaluated by specifying patients who need additional propofol during intubation in the study, Ingrande et al. 80 patients with a mean body mass index [BMI] between 18-35 and Bispectoral index (BIS). ) monitorization, propofol infusion (100 mg/kg/hour) will be started according to total body weight, and the infusion will be stopped with a BIS value between 50 and 40, and the elapsed time will be recorded. Routine anesthesia applications will be performed with neuromuscular blocker applied. The total dose of Propofol given; the dose applied to kilograms will be calculated according to TBW, IBW and LBW. And the relationship between the doses given and the body mass index will be evaluated. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of Propofol dose with sufficient depth of anesthesia according to total and lean body weight. The study is an observational study and no non-routine procedures will be performed on patients. Routine anesthesia procedure will be applied to the patients. The study will be conducted in three groups: Group 1 BMI = 18.5-24.9, Group 2 BMI = 25-29.9, Group 3 BMI=30-34.9. The study will be conducted in three groups: Group 1 BMI = 18.5

===============

This is a prospective cohort study evaluating the efficacy and tolerability of oral letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in heart and lung transplant recipients. The study will compare the exposed group with a pre-intervention period of standard valganciclovir prophylaxis. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of days during which appropriately-dosed prophylaxis is taken during the planned treatment course. Secondary outcome measures include the frequency of acute cellular rejection, CMV resistance, neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, unplanned discontinuation of MMF or azathioprine, and incorrect renal dosing. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The PHYSIOSCORE is a tool used to assess the complexity level and physiotherapy care in hospitalized patients. It was developed in three phases. In phase 1, the questionnaire was validated based on variables used in clinical practice. In phase 2, the PHYSIOSCORE was tested for concordance and interrater reliability. In phase 3, the PHYSIOSCORE was clinically validated. The PHYSIOSCORE consists of 106 items divided into three domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. The respiratory domain includes six items: pulmonary function, breath sounds, PaO2/FiO2, and chest X-ray. The imaging domain includes four segments: pulmonary parenchyma, pleura, vascular plot, and expandability. The neuromuscular domain includes six items: muscle strength, muscle tone and postural control. The PHYSIOSCORE was tested in three phases. In phase 1, the questionnaire was validated based on variables used in clinical practice. In phase 2, the PHYSIOSCORE was tested for concordance and interrater reliability. In phase 3, the PHYSIOSCORE was clinically validated. The PHYSIOSCORE was tested in three phases. In phase 1, the questionnaire was validated based on variables used in clinical practice. In phase 2, the PHYSIOSCORE was tested for concordance and interrater reliability. In phase 3, the PHYSIOSCORE was clinically validated.

============

The SAVAL trial is a phase II study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of observation in patients with p16+OPSCC who are candidates for TORS and have positive ctDNA levels. The study will test the hypothesis that patients currently recommended for adjuvant RT based on intermediate risk factors can be observed post-TORS when ctDNA is cleared. Patients will be stratified into three risk groups based on pathological features and ctDNA levels. The low risk group will be observed per standard of care, the intermediate group will also be observed per the experimental arm, and the high risk group will receive adjuvant treatment per standard of care. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival at 2 years post last treatment. Secondary outcome measures include rate of recurrence, rate of salvage, locoregional recurrence, overall survival, freedom from distant metastases, patient scores from the MDADI questionnaire, and PEG-tube rate. The study will use TransOral Robotic Surgery (TORS) as the primary surgical modality and will also include proton and photon therapy as adjuvant treatment options. The study will enroll patients with p16+OPSCC who are candidates for TORS and have positive ctDNA levels. Eligible patients must have clinical stage T0-3, N0-N1, and M0 disease as defined by physical examination and appropriate imaging within 60 days of enrollment. The study will be conducted at the University of Maryland Head and Neck Tumor Board.

=========

The study is a single-institution prospective phase 2 trial comparing ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) to partial breast irradiation (PBI) in breast cancer patients. The study aims to assess the acute and late toxicity of the two radiotherapy regimens and evaluate the local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life (QoL) in patients undergoing ultra-hypofractionated WBI or PBI. The study will use the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) scale version 5.0 to assess acute toxicity and the Harvard score for breast cosmesis to assess the cosmetic outcome. The study will also use the EORTC QLQ-BR23 questionnaire validated for the Serbian-speaking population to assess the QoL. The study will enroll breast cancer patients who have undergone breast-conserving surgery and have invasive ductal carcinoma, age ≥ 50, tumor size ≤ 3 cm, R0 resection, unicentric/unifocal carcinoma or multifocal carcinoma within 2 cm of the primary neoplasm, pN0 (sentinel lymph node biopsy or axillary lymph node dissection performed), N1mi, hormone receptor status - any, histological grade G1 or G2, and exclusion criteria. The study will use an ultra-short course of radiotherapy with 26Gy in 5 fractions to administer the radiotherapy to the part of the breast where the tumor was located in the PBI arm and the whole breast where the tumor was located in the WBI arm. The study will measure the primary outcome measures of acute toxicity and late toxicity and the secondary outcome measures of local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and QoL. The study will enroll 50 patients in each arm and will follow the patients for 5 years.

This study aims to explore the use of symptom monitoring and digital life coaching (DLC) to inform a more complete understanding of the impact of multiple myeloma on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being among a diverse U.S.-based, contemporary sample. The study will evaluate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of DLC and its potential to augment existing standards of care for patient support. Patients enrolled in the program will be assigned to a health advisor who will act as an educator and accountability partner, supporting patients as they experience treatment for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. Throughout the engagement, patient reported outcomes (PROs) will be collected at multiple time points to assess the patient status and will be used to explore relationships between medical management, health related quality of life (HRQoL), and engagement in the program. The study will be conducted at UCSF and will enroll 100 individuals with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The study will be conducted over a 3-month period, with participants completing assessments at baseline, 30, 60, and 90 days after consent. The primary outcome measure will be the feasibility of the digital health coaching intervention, defined as a retention rate greater than or equal to 70%. The secondary outcome measure will be change in Cancer Behavior Inventory-Brief Form (CBI-B) scores at 3 months. The study will also collect wearable data from Fitbit devices to assess physical activity levels and other health metrics.

-----------------
The study aims to investigate the effect of a 4-week WholeFiberTM intervention on fecal calprotectin, IBD-complaints, QoL, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota and SCFA levels in patients with CD and UC. The study will be conducted as a 4-week pilot study with one arm to explore the effects of a WholeFiberTM intervention. Measurements will take place before and after the intervention, questionnaires will also be conducted halfway. The primary parameter is change in fecal calprotectin after the 4-week intervention, which is a marker for inflammation in the gut. Secondary parameters are improvements in IBD-complaints, QoL, serum markers, and changes in the gut microbiota and increase in fecal SCFA-production. Moreover, it will be explored whether the response on the intervention will be different between UC and CD. Furthermore, an evaluation questionnaire will be conducted to assess feasibility and acceptance of the WholeFiberTM intervention in this population.

The study is a multicenter randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in the treatment of localized gingival recessions. The study will include 100 participants with RT1 localized gingival recessions with a height ranging from 3 to 5 mm and at least 2mm of keratinized tissue width. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the active comparator group (coronally advanced flap (CAF)) or the experimental group (CAF+ PADM). The primary outcome measure will be the reduction of the gingival recession height, and the secondary outcome measure will be the thickness of keratinized tissue evaluation after periodontal plastic surgery. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months, with baseline, 6 months, and 12 months measurements.

===============

This is a Longitudinal CrossOver Clinical Trial that aims to compare changes in heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients undergoing conventional physical exercise and in a virtual environment during hemodialysis sessions. The study will assess heart rate and respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, systemic blood pressure, laboratory tests, as well as the Kidney Disease Quality of Life Short Form questionnaire, the Beck Anxiety and Depression Inventory, and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire in all groups. The study will use heart rate variability indices, using both linear and non-linear measurements, using a chest trap that captures the R-R intervals in milliseconds. The study will use a crossover assignment model, with participants in Group A performing virtual reality interventions and those in Group B performing stationary bike interventions during hemodialysis sessions. After the initial 10 interventions, there will be a 1-week washout period and the groups will switch exercises. The study will measure heart rate variability behavior during interventions with virtual reality and stationary bike while in hemodialysis, as well as blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation during these interventions. The study will also measure these parameters 20 days after the intervention period. The study will use the Kidney Disease Quality of Life Short Form questionnaire, the Beck Anxiety and Depression Inventory, and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire to assess the quality of life, anxiety, depression, and physical activity levels of the participants. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

===============

The Respiratory Variability and Dyspnea During Spontaneous Breathing Trial is a study that aims to analyze the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients under invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will include 100 patients, including 50 communicative patients and 50 non-communicative patients. The study will measure clinically significant dyspnea using the Dyspnea visual analog scale (D-VAS) and the Mechanical Ventilation Respiratory Distress Observation Scale (MV-RDOS) in all patients. The study will also measure the intensity of dyspnea using the D-VAS and MV-RDOS in communicative patients. The study will measure ventilatory variability using the coefficient of variation (CV) of chest expansion and the H1/DC component of the respiratory signal by Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) over periods of 5 minutes. The study will also measure the surface electromyography of inspiratory extra-diaphragmatic muscles using self-adhesive surface electrodes. The study will measure airway flow and pressure using a disposable pneumotachograph and a differential pressure sensor connected to a demodulator. The study will measure the failure of the spontaneous breathing test (SBT) using the appearance and persistence for at least 5 minutes of one of the following criteria: SpO2 ≤ 90% or PaO2 ≤ 50mmHg with FiO2 ≥ 50%, PaCO2 > 50 mmHg, pH < 7.32, respiratory rate > 35/min, heart rate > 140/min, systolic blood pressure > 180 mmHg or < 90 mmHg. The study will compare the group clinically significant dyspnea vs. not clinically significant on their variability indices (CV and H1/DC) using the non-parametric Mann-Whitney test. The study will also compare the two groups successful vs. failure of the SBT on their variability indices (CV and H1/DC) using the same methods. The study will test the correlations between variability indices and intensity of dyspnea and between variability indices and surface EM

The study aims to investigate whether applying action observation therapy (AOT) in a population with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) would yield positive results in cognitive status, upper limb function, activities of daily living (ADL), gait, and balance. The study will compare the effectiveness of AOT in patients with MCI who observe the therapist, patients with MCI who observe patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group. The hypothesis is that intervention using an exercise plan for upper and lower limbs through action observation learning is effective in improving cognitive status, functionality, ADL, gait, and balance in patients with MCI. The study will use the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), Barthel index, Fugl-meyer scale, Box and block test, Berg Balance Scale, and 10 Meters Walking Test to measure the primary outcomes. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled design with a sample size of 100 participants. The study will be conducted in a facility that provides care to individuals with MCI. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study. The primary purpose of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device. The study will compare the length of the procedure between the experimental group, where patients will have a central venous line placed using an ultraportable ultrasound device, and the sham comparator group, where patients will benefit from the technique of central venous line placement by conventional ultrasound. The study will measure the length of the procedure in seconds, and the time frame will be 1 day. The study will be conducted in patients scheduled to have a right or left jugular central venous line placed preoperatively or in the ICU. The study will exclude patients with absolute emergency not allowing randomization, pregnant women, patients with suspected or proven jugular thrombosis at the insertion site, change of central venous line on guidewire, and operators with no experience in central venous line placement under ultrasound.

The study aims to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of Erbium:YAG Laser in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars in respect of genital pelvic pain and scar tissue healing. The study is a randomized sham-controlled prospective study. The study population includes adult females who have given birth in the last 6 months with episiotomy and have vulvar pain and dyspareunia. The intervention is non-ablative thermal-only Er:YAG laser treatment using R11 and PS03 handpieces. The primary outcome measures are the rate of change of pain and the rate of scar tissue healing. The secondary outcome measures are the rate of improvement in sexual function and the incidence and severity of device related adverse events. The study will be conducted for 6 months.

The study aims to investigate the effects of an intensive upper limb therapy program focused on somatosensation in children and adolescents with unilateral cerebral palsy. The study will compare the effects of Sense for Kids therapy, which is a somatosensory discrimination therapy, to an equal dose of motor therapy. The study will investigate the potential role of clinical and neurological baseline characteristics on treatment response, including the anatomical characterization of the brain lesion, age and baseline somatosensory function. The study will be conducted as a randomized, controlled, and evaluator-blinded randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomized to the intervention or active control group through randomization by minimization with an allocation ratio of 1:1. Participants will receive three session of 45 minutes upper limb therapy per week for a period of 8 weeks, resulting in a total therapy intensity of 18 hours. The intervention group will receive Sense for Kids therapy, which consists of component-based training and occupation-based training. During the component-based training participants will perform graded and structured practice of tactile object recognition, texture discrimination and proprioception. During the occupation-based practice, participants will repetitively perform self-chosen activities of daily living while attention is denoted to somatosensory aspects necessary for successful task completion (e.g., position of the upper limb, texture of materials, localization of materials based on touch). Participants in the control group will receive an equal amount of motor training, consisting of unimanual motor tasks and bimanual goal directed training of self-chosen activities. Outcomes will be assessed at three different points in time, being within two weeks prior to therapy commencement (baseline), within one week following therapy completion (post-intervention) and 6 months after the therapy has ended (follow-up). Outcome assessments include qualitative and quantitative measures of upper limb sensorimotor function. The primary outcome measure is the Assisting Hand Assessment and is used to score the (spontaneous) use of the more impaired hand during bimanual activities. The medical imaging protocol, which will be only acquired at baseline, includes structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging and diffusion weighted images. The time effects of the intervention on upper limb sensorimotor outcomes will be objectified using linear and/

The study aims to understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease and its relationship with patient outcomes including complications of gallstone disease and post-operative complications. The study will use a prospective cohort design to collect data from 75 adult patients presenting to East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Hospitals with newly diagnosed gallstone disease following confirmatory imaging investigations. Data will be collected from electronic patient records including clinical history and diagnostic investigations, anthropometry, blood and imaging results (if taken as part of routine clinical care) for the initial presentation and subsequent readmissions/planned follow-up timepoints. Stool samples will be collected from patients either during admission or at home at each timepoint. Samples will be returned by post to the research team where they will be stored and analysed. Patients will also be asked to provide a 3 day food diary card. Patients will have a sample collected at time of diagnosis and then at 6 monthly intervals whilst awaiting cholecystectomy. A pre-operative sample will be required within 6 weeks of any surgical intervention. Following cholecystectomy an immediate post-operative sample (within the first week) will be collected as well as a sample at 6 months. The primary outcome measure is the diversity of species present in the stool of participants through study completion, up to 3 years from cholecystectomy. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the East Kent Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Research Ethics Committee.

* Elevated initial APRI value was associated with the development of SALD in adult patients with sepsis.
* SALD was diagnosed by the following criteria: (1) ALT or AST≥20 folds upper limit of normal level; or (2) TBIL≥2.0 mg/dL.
* SALD is further divided into hypoxic hepatitis and sepsis induced cholestasis (SIC), based on the presence or absence of elevated TBIL.
* Hypoxic hepatitis is diagnosed when elevated transaminase (>800 IU/L) is present only; and SIC is diagnosed when TBIL is elevated (≥2.0 mg/dL).
* The study used association analysis to assess the correlation between APRI and the occurrence of SALD.
* The study was validated using the MIMIC IV database.

This is a randomized, double-blind, active-controlled clinical study evaluating the immunogenicity and safety of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs. The study has two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm received two doses of 25 μg/0.5 ml Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) at a 0-1-month immunization schedule, while the active comparator arm received two doses of 25 μg/0.5 ml recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) at the same schedule. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events after 2 doses given intramuscularly according to different immunization programs, and the secondary outcome measures include laboratory markers of immunity and immunogenic end points. The study is designed to measure the immunogenicity and safety of the vaccine in people with different immunization programs.

The study aimed to examine the impact of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled experimental study with a sample of 350 women who had a normal delivery in the delivery room. The experimental group received skin-to-skin contact within the first minutes of normal delivery and the control group did not receive skin-to-skin contact. The maternal attachment scale and traumatic birth perception scale were used to evaluate the bond between mother and baby and the perception of traumatic birth, respectively. The study found that skin-to-skin contact had a positive effect on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth.

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled, double-blind, single-centre study investigating the effect of an ultrasound-guided sacral erector spinae plane block on the post-operative pain of lumbar discectomy surgery. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee and followed the Consolidated Reporting Trials Standards. Patients over 18 years of age with American Society of Anesthesiology status 1-3 were eligible to participate. The study was designed to compare the pain scores and opioid consumption between the two groups. The first group underwent sacral erector spinae plane block at the end of surgery, while the second group had no block. The study measured patient pain scores and total opioid consumption for 24 hours. The study also measured the incidence of nausea-vomiting and patient satisfaction. The study was conducted in patients undergoing elective lumbar discectomy, and informed consent was obtained from the patients. They were randomised using a closed envelope technique, opened by the physician performing the block. 54 patients were included in the study, divided into two groups of 27 patients as esp block (group 1) and control group (group 2), both groups underwent standard general anaesthesia. The blocks were performed in the operating theatre at the end of the operation, before the patient woke up. The patients were unaware that the block was being performed on them. A patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) device was given to both groups by another doctor blinded to the group, and Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores assessed for 24 hours. Standard monitoring (peripheral oxygen saturation, electrocardiogram, non-invasive arterial blood pressure monitoring) was performed. Anaesthesia induction was achieved with 1 mcg/kg fentanyl, 2 mg/kg propofol, 0.6 mg/kg rocuronium, and anaesthesia maintenance with 2% sevoflurane, 4 lt/min 50%/50% oxygen/nitrogen mixture. The study aims to develop and validate a noninvasive multimodal ultrasound-based imaging biomarker for myofascial pain (MP) in chronic low back pain (cLBP) patients. The study will use multimodal ultrasound imaging to measure the echogenicity of latent and active trigger points, the dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation quantified by strain tensors in the thoracolumbar fascia and multifidus muscle, and the viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles measured by ultrasound shear wave elastography. The study will use deep learning to integrate these measurements into a predictive biomarker and use established validation methods to test its ability to predict MP. The study will determine the sensitivity and specificity of the biomarker to classify the myofascial components of pain, as well as the response to treatment (a diagnostic and predictive marker). The study will recruit 10 subjects per age decile (10 subjects ages 30-39 yrs., etc.) for healthy normals and 100 subjects for cLBP patients. The study will be conducted in three phases: R61 Phase (year 1 to 3), R62 Phase (year 4 to 6), and R63 Phase (year 7 to 9). The primary outcome measure will be the diagnosis of one of four MP-related categories, and the secondary outcome measure will be the presence of substantial MP. The study will use the Neural Understanding Network to analyze the data.

The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a two-arm, blinded, randomized controlled trial that aims to estimate the effect of an adapted telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use at 3 months among opioid-naïve adult Emergency Department (ED) and urgent care patients with musculoskeletal pain. The study will enroll 200 patients who are 18 years of age or older, have a primary complaint of acute musculoskeletal pain, and an average pain score of 4 or higher since pain onset. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention arm, which will receive an interactive pain management video, or the usual care arm, which will receive standard care provided by the ED or urgent care provider and staff. The primary outcome measure will be a composite score of pain severity and interference on the Brief Pain Inventory-short form (BPI-SF) at 3 months. Secondary outcome measures will include pain severity and interference on the BPI-SF, opioid use during the past week, patient-reported physical function using the PROMIS Physical Function-4, patient-reported global health using the PROMIS Global Health-Physical 2a, and healthcare utilization, including the number of visits to the ED or urgent care and non-ED or urgent care physicians. The study will be conducted over a 2-year period and will involve data collection for subjects in all arms of the study according to a predetermined schedule.

The study aims to investigate the impact of Neuro-Linguistic Programs on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon. The study will use a single group assignment design with triple masking. The intervention will be a behavioral Neuro-Linguistic program developed by three specialists. The study will measure the identification of school triggers, schoolchildren's strengths and difficulties progression, and concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning of schoolchildren through the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale. The study will be conducted in Lebanon and will include 130 schoolchildren aged between 5 and 11 years attending the same school for at least a year. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 months after the intervention.

The study aims to evaluate the value of the ECOX tool in improving the final grade for service EOS compared with standard learning during the training course. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: control and interventional. The control group will take part in the ECOS of the departments scheduled at the end of their internship using the various revision methods usually offered to them by the faculty or in the emergency department, apart from the ECOX tool. The interventional group will take part in the ECOS of the departments scheduled at the end of their internship using the ECOX tool available in the emergency department to practice before taking the on-duty OSCEs. The primary outcome measure is the students' average score on the end-of-course OSCEs. The secondary outcome measures are the average STAI-Y (State-Trait Anxiety) scores between the two groups and the average scores on the behavioral assessment during the service EOS between the two groups. The study is conducted over a period of 10 weeks.

The study aims to develop a web-based health care program for patients with pulmonary hypertension and to evaluate the effects of this program on symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life. The study is a randomized, parallel-group, double-blind, and block randomization, experimental design study. The primary outcome measure is the Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension Symptom Interference Scale, and the secondary outcome measures are the Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support, the 6-Minute Walk Test, and the Cambridge Pulmonary Hypertension Outcome Review. The study will be conducted over a period of six months, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (web-based health care program) or the control group (usual care). The study will be conducted in Taiwan.

The study aims to investigate the effects of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study is a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: one arm with patients who choose life-prolonging treatment with long-term mechanical ventilation support and their families, and the other arm with patients who decline life-prolonging treatment with long-term mechanical ventilation support and their families. The study measures overall quality of life using the Quality of Life Scale, health-related quality of life using the Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire and the Kidsscreen-27, and disease-specific quality of life using the Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis assessment scale - 5 items (ALSAQ-5). The study also measures caregiver burden using the Zarit Burden Interview and health-related quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L. The study is conducted in Norway and is expected to run for 21 months.

The study aims to evaluate the incidence of postoperative neurologic deterioration in patients with chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH) undergoing standard of care surgical evacuation of cSDH. The study will perform subdural ECoG monitoring to assess for the presence or absence of spreading depolarization. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of decline in Markwalder grading scale (0[normal]-4[comatose]) or Glasgow coma scale (3[no response] to 15[normal]) by one point. Secondary outcome measures include extended Glasgow outcome scale (1[dead]-8[upper good recovery]), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (1-30), NIH toolbox cognitive battery, PROMIS-29 v2.0 profile, TBI-QOL, and Headache disability Index. The study will be conducted as a single arm study performing subdural ECoG monitoring to assess for the presence or absence of spreading depolarization. The study is a multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. The study aims to compare the efficacy of annual versus biannual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS) after 2 years of initial treatment. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesion >3mm on cerebrospinal MRI at 24 months compared with inclusion MRI. The study will be conducted in French-speaking patients with MS who meet the inclusion criteria. The study will be conducted in two arms: experimental arm with annual ocrelizumab infusions and other arm with semestrial ocrelizumab infusions. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. The study aims to compare the efficacy of annual versus biannual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS) after 2 years of initial treatment. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesion >3mm on cerebrospinal MRI at 24 months compared with inclusion MRI. The study will be conducted in French-speaking patients with MS who meet the inclusion criteria. The study will be conducted in two arms: experimental arm with annual ocrelizumab infusions and other arm with semestrial ocrelizumab infusions. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

The SPARCOL Study is a randomized, parallel assignment study that compares the outcomes of combined endoscopic laparoscopic surgery (CELS) to standard surgery for early stage colon cancer in elderly frail patients. The study measures the change in patient-reported postoperative recovery, exercise capacity and physical condition, and quality of life. The primary outcome measure is change in QoR-15, while secondary outcome measures include changes in exercise capacity and physical condition, EORTC C30 and EORTC CRC questionnaires, G8 score, duration of surgery, blood loss, intraoperative complications, conversion rate, rate of complete resection margin, assessment of histopathological risk factors, long-term oncological outcomes, Clavien-Dindo classification, Comprehensive Complication Index, length of hospital stay, 90-day mortality, hospital readmissions, and rate of secondary standard resection. The study is designed to measure the outcomes of CELS surgery in elderly frail patients with early stage colon cancer.

The study is a phase 2 open label pilot study to evaluate the effectiveness of nebulised 6% hypertonic saline in decreasing respiratory exacerbations in people with neuromuscular disease or neurodisability. The study is designed as a randomized intervention model with a parallel assignment and a nebulised 6% hypertonic saline as the intervention. The primary outcome measure is the course of antibiotics for respiratory infections, and the secondary outcome measures include lung clearance index, forced oscillation technique, lung ultrasound, electrical impedance tomography, airway inflammation, bacterial diversity, ease of airway clearance, health-related quality of life, patient and main carer treatment satisfaction, family impact, and health economics. The study is conducted in two arms: experimental and placebo comparator. The experimental arm receives nebulised 6% hypertonic saline, while the placebo comparator arm receives nebulised 0.9% normal saline. The study is conducted for 52 weeks, and the participants are assessed at baseline, week 52, and at various time points in between. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and is approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

Paraphilic Disorders and Other Conditions With Risk for Sexual Violence: a Case-control Study

The study aims to investigate the risk for sexual violence in individuals with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. The study will use a case-control design, with a sample of 100 participants with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia, and 100 healthy controls matched for age and sex. The study will use a variety of measures to assess the participants' psychiatric and sexual functioning, including the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview, the Personality Inventory for DSM-5, the Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment, and the Karolinska Interpersonal Violence Scale. The study will also use measures to assess the participants' impulsivity, sleep quality, and quality of life. The study will follow the participants for 12 months and will assess the effectiveness of different treatments for paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. The study will also investigate the risk for sexual violence in individuals with these conditions.

The study aims to develop a new metabolic imaging approach (aMRI) for evaluating neurological disease in patients with gliomas. The primary objective is to characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in tumor versus (vs) normal brain. The study will assess the validity of aMRI as a metabolic imaging approach via direct comparison with a standard metabolic imaging approach, ¹⁸FDG PET. The study will also characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in the various normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor, in comparison to ¹⁸FDG PET. An exploratory objective is to compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V within disease lesions change with different disease types, their disease stage, and their treatment status. The study will use contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET) to obtain the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V and the standardized uptake value maximum (SUVmax) of ¹⁸FDG PET, respectively. The study will recruit adult patients with glioma who require MRI and ¹⁸FDG-PET imaging. The study will measure the mean values of kᵢₒ*V of the entire tumor region, mean value of kᵢₒ*V in the tumor periphery and core regions, and kᵢₒ*V in different normal appearing brain sub-regions, unaffected by tumor. The study will evaluate the utility of aMRI to differentially assess the metabolically active tumor periphery and necrotic core regions and the correlation of the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V with the simultaneously obtained and co-registered ¹⁸FDG PET (SUVmax) data. The study will also evaluate the observation of robust correlation with PET, which would validate activity magnetic resonance imaging (aMRI) as a metabolic sensor.

The GDMT Research, Education & Assist Trial for Heart Failure Care (GREAT-HF Care) is a cluster randomized study designed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving GDMT in patients with HFrEF. Clinicians stratified based on practice specialty, location, and pharmacist referral habits will be permuted block randomized to achieve 45%/45%/10% proportional distribution across the following arms respectively: (1) usual care, (2) multi-pronged clinical decision support (CDS) inclusive of a patient portal message about GDMT, an interruptive advisory upon chart entry as a notification to clinicians on GDMT consideration and a Best Practice Advisory (BPA) that includes a GDMT order set, and (3) multi-pronged CDS as in #2 but replacement of GDMT order set with referral to integrated clinical pharmacist co-management. Secondarily, each of the 5 clinical practice sites of roughly equal HFrEF patient loads were assigned to receive either an early or delayed education rollout. Exploratory analyses will look to determine the independent and incremental benefits of education with other interventional approaches.

DRIVE-Mind II is a prospective cohort study comparing PWID diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder and getting benefit from a community-based psychiatric intervention to a control group of PWID free of psychiatric disorders. The study aims to compare the two groups in terms of HIV/HCV exposure, severity of substance disorder, quality of life, sustainability of mental health improvement. The study will enroll 600 participants (200 in the intervention group and 400 - 200 HIV-positive and 200 HIV-negative - in the control group). The primary outcome measures are viral exposure score, severity of substance use score, and quality of life score. The secondary outcome measures include percentage of compliant participant, percentage of participant facing difficulty to access to care, percentage of psychiatric disorder associated with methamphetamine use, HIV/HCV incidence, incidence of psychiatric disorders in the control groups, and cost of a specialized community-based psychiatric intervention.

The present study is a randomized, clinical, superiority trial comparing the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment with that of endodontic treatment combined with PDT in patients with apical lesion. The study will have three arms: a placebo group which will receive conventional endodontic treatment and a simulated treatment with the equipment in which no radiation will be emitted; a group which will receive conventional endodontic treatment associated with PDT with diode laser at 660 nm, fluence 10 s/canal; and a group which will receive conventional endodontic treatment associated with PDAT with laser at 660 nm, 20 s/canal. The photosensitizer used in the PDT will be methylene blue. Clinical and radiographic examination of all the patients will be used to obtain baseline values (T0) and values 6 months post-treatment (T1). The presence and size of apical lesion will be assessed at T0 and T1, the percentage reduction of the lesion will be calculated and the PAI index will be used as a scoring system to assess the lesion. The success rate will be assessed for each group 6 months after completion of the treatment. Disinfection of the root canals will be assessed by analysis of colony formation (ufc/ml); biological samples will be taken with paper cones inserted into the root canals to the apical region at two moments: Baseline (before treatment, T0); after instrumentation with PDT (experimental groups) and without PDT (placebo group). Adverse events will be analysed; a serious adverse event for this study is any unfavourable odontological event that the investigators believe to bear a causal relation with the experimental intervention.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of psychiatric orders in psychoanalytic treatment of ASD. The study includes participants with ASD, aged between 18 and 70 years, who will receive a combination of sertraline, duloxetine, and cognitive behavioral therapy. The primary outcome measures include the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Dissociative Experiences Scale, The Defeat Scale, Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale, Severity Measure for Agoraphobia-Adult, BPD Check List, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, Young Schema Questionnaire, Personality Belief Questionnaire, Behavioral Satisfaction Questionnaire (X and Y axis), Heart Rate, Systolic Blood Pressure, and Diastolic Blood Pressure. The study will run for 90 days.

The DIAMOND study is a pilot, prospective study designed to primarily assess the ability of blood-based liquid biopsy using NGS to monitor disease progression to Trastuzumab-deruxtecan (as second line treatment) in patients with histologically confirmed diagnosis of HER2-positive metastatic disease previously treated with one treatment line for metastatic disease including pertuzumab with Trastuzumab or Trastuzumab alone (associated to taxane). The primary objective of the trial is to dynamically assess circulating alterations associated with resistance to Trastuzumab-deruxtecan, including changes of the HER2 status by a novel approach named HER2-2D that simultaneously assesses HER2 amplification and (over)expression in blood. The primary endpoint is the concordance between the clinical evaluation (progressive disease versus not progressive disease) based on RECIST criteria and the evaluation of liquid biopsy, (appearance of a new mutation and/or increasing of an existing one). Secondary objectives include: 1) molecular stratification of patients (dynamic approach by liquid biopsy); 2) lead time (anticipation of progression) assessment by liquid biopsy; 2) HER2-2D: use of a non-invasive liquid biopsy method to non-invasively and objectively assess HER2 status and to select patients displaying a HER2-low status. Trastuzumab Deruxtecan will be administered at the dose of 5.4 mg per kilogram by intravenous infusion every 3 weeks (standard recommended dose). Treatment will be maintained until disease progression, severe toxicity or patient refusal. Liquid biopsy will be performed at baseline and repeated at different time points and/or at progression disease.

* The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) for mental health problems in earthquake-affected adults in Turkey.
* The study will be conducted on Zoom, which is an online platform with HIPAA compliance.
* The study will be designed as a pilot randomized controlled trial, and the potential effectiveness of individual CPT will be tested compared to the Enhanced-Care as Usual (E-CAU) control group.
* The primary outcome is post-traumatic stress disorder, and the following are the secondary clinical outcomes: symptoms of depression, anxiety, and well-being.
* The study will be conducted in two arms: in either the CPT (n =15) or only the control group (E-CAU; n=15).
* The first session will take place no longer than one week after the pre-intervention assessment.
* The post-intervention assessment through the same measures will be scheduled six weeks after the pre-intervention assessment (i.e., one week after the 12th CPT session).
* The follow-up assessment will be conducted one month after the post-assessment.
* All study participants, including dropouts, will be invited to all outcome assessments.

===============

This study aims to investigate the quality of family planning counseling among reproductive aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley, Egypt. The study will use the validated and client-centered based QCC Scale to measure the quality of care received by women during family planning visits. The study will collect data through a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire which includes socio-demographic characteristics of women, family planning practice, facility factors, and the QCC Scale. The study will investigate the determinants of quality of family planning counseling among reproductive aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley, Egypt. The study will be conducted for one year.

The PIVCO study aims to determine a more standardized procedure representing optimal ablation strategy for patients suffering from PsAF using PFA and multielectrode ablation catheters. The central hypothesis is that ablation of the posterior LA wall (PWI), together with mitral and cavotricuspid isthmus ablation added on top of PVI, will be associated with better effects in terms of rhythm control. The primary endpoint will be a recurrence of AF (or atrial tachycardia, AT) lasting >30 seconds as assessed using repeated 7-day ECG Holter monitoring in patients without anti-arrhythmic drugs (AADs) during the entire post-blanking follow-up, i.e., starting three months after the index procedure. All patients should complete a 12-month follow-up period. Secondary endpoints include the first recurrence of on-AADs AF/AT lasting >6 minutes during the post-blanking follow-up period, number of hospitalizations and emergency out-patient visits related to AF/AT recurrence, worsening of heart failure, or other cardiovascular diseases, number of electrical cardioversions, proportion of patients on AADs at the end of follow-up, PFA-related complications, assessment of the quality of life using standardized instruments (AFEQT, EQ5D), feasibility of achieving a complete block of the mitral isthmus and PWI using PFA, proportion of patients with delayed conduction into LAA after mitral line, number of patients that underwent repeated ablations during follow-up. Interventions will be performed on the day of admission for ablation: 12-lead ECG randomization to group PVI or PVI+, physical examination, medication taken, medical history, laboratory tests, cardiac CT scan, transthoracic echocardiography, esophageal echocardiography, catheter ablation strategy, and quality of life questionnaires. The following information will be recorded on the day of discharge: date of hospital discharge after ablation, length of in-hospital stays, early complications of ablation, and medication at the discharge (all antiarrhythmic drugs except beta-blockers will permanently be discontinued at hospital discharge). The Catholic Health Initiatives Children's Home Visiting Longitudinal Study is a longitudinal study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a home visiting program in improving child development and school readiness, reducing child maltreatment, and improving maternal health. The study is being conducted in three counties in New Mexico, USA, and will follow 1,200 families with a first-born child from birth to age 15. The intervention group will receive home visiting services for three years, while the control group will receive standard care. The study will measure child development and school readiness using the Ages and Stages Questionnaire, the Child Behavior Checklist, and the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers. It will also measure maternal health using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale, the Brief Symptom Inventory, and the CAGE-AID. The study will measure child maltreatment using the Conflict Tactics Scale Parent-Child Form and New Mexico Children, Youth and Families Department records. The study will also measure reductions in child maltreatment using the Parenting Sense of Competence and the New Mexico Children, Youth and Families Department records. The study will measure positive parenting practices using the Brief Symptom Inventory and the Adult Adolescent Parenting Inventory. The study will measure family economic self-sufficiency using the New Mexico Human Services Department records. The study will measure reductions in juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime using the Conflict Tactics Scale Parent-Child Form, jail data, law enforcement records, and court records. The study will measure changes in juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime using the New Mexico Children, Youth and Families Department records. The study will measure linkages and referrals using the New Mexico Human Services Department records. The study will measure positive parenting practices using the Brief Symptom Inventory. The study will measure reductions in child maltreatment using the Parenting Sense of Competence and the New Mexico Children, Youth and Families Department records. The study will measure reductions in juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime using the Conflict Tactics Scale Parent-Child Form, jail data, law enforcement records, and court records. A Phase I clinical trial is being conducted to assess the safety and immunogenicity of a new malaria vaccine candidate, RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-M, in healthy adult volunteers. The study will compare two dosing regimens: a delayed regimen and a delayed fractional regimen. The primary outcome measures will include the occurrence of solicited local/systemic reactogenicity signs and symptoms, unsolicited adverse events, change from baseline for safety laboratory measures, and occurrence of serious adverse events. Secondary outcome measures will include the humoral immunogenicity of RH5.1 soluble protein with Matrix-M, comparison of anti-RH5 serum IgG functional immunogenicity between the two groups receiving soluble RH5.1 at different doses, and differences in innate immune responses following the first and third vaccinations. The study will be conducted in two groups of 12 volunteers each, with the delayed regimen group receiving three doses of 10 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M on days 0, 28 and 182 via intramuscular (IM) injection in the deltoid region of the non-dominant arm, and the delayed fractional regimen group receiving two doses of 50 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M on days 0, 28 and one dose of 10 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M on day 182 via intramuscular (IM) injection in the deltoid region of the non-dominant arm. The study will be conducted over a period of 547 days.

This is a 18-months, randomized, rater-blinded study to evaluate the influence of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the baseline to 18-months change in the QoL of individuals with MSA compared to a sex-, age- and disease-duration matched historical European MSA cohort. The study will recruit 46 individuals with MSA fulfilling all the inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria. The individualized therapeutic plan, including mobile palliative care offer (for wheelchair-bound individuals) and guidance for self-practiced physio-, speech and occupational exercises will be prepared based on a standardized operational protocol drafted by the study team on the basis of published consensus recommendations, scientific evidence and principles of good clinical practice and adapted to the individual healthcare preferences and therapeutic needs of the recruited individuals. The study will measure the change in the EQ-5D-5L score, changes in the MSA-QoL score and subscores, time to clinical milestones, changes in the individual healthcare preferences assessed by means of the Autonomy Preference Index (API), in-person and telemedicine medical, psychological and neurorehabilitation interventional needs of individuals with MSA, change in the Short Assessment of Patient Satisfaction (SAPS) referred to the overall individualized treatment plan, individual satisfaction with the single telemedicine and mobile palliative interventions, healthcare professionals satisfaction with the single telemedicine and mobile palliative interventions, number of medical complications, single-intervention and cumulative healthcare costs, changes in the EQ-5D-5L score of informal caregivers of individuals with MSA recruited in the present study and change in the Carers quality-of-life questionnaire for parkinsonism (PQoL Carers) score and other caregiver-burden indicators in informal caregivers of individuals with MSA recruited in the present study.

The study aims to investigate the genetic basis of response to growth hormone treatment in children with idiopathic short stature. The study will recruit 100 children with idiopathic short stature who have received at least one year of growth hormone therapy and are prepubertal at initiation of and throughout the first year of therapy. The study will compare the frequency of genetic variants between good responders and poor responders to growth hormone therapy. The study will also investigate the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway in both responder groups. The study will use non-invasive biological samples to measure the genetic variants. The study will be conducted over a one-year period. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain informed consent from all participants. The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of neurochecks on sleep in critically ill adults with cerebral aneurysm. The study will compare the sleep efficiency, wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and sleep quality of patients who receive hourly neurochecks with those who receive every-other-hour neurochecks. The study will measure these outcomes within 24 hours of enrollment. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to assess the accuracy of the identification of iENE by radiologists in real-world situations by correlating with histopathology (pENE) and evaluate the prognostic significance of iENE. The study will also determine radiological features of iENE that best correlate with pENE and assess the utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in accurately diagnosing iENE. The study will measure interobserver variability amongst radiologists in grading radiographic ENE and to measure the impact of standardized criteria on this variability. The study will be conducted under the auspices of the Head and Neck Inter Group (HNCIG, Www.Hncig.Org) and is part of the Evaluation Prognostic and Predictive Indicators in Head and Neck Cancer (EPIC) Programme. The study will include data from consecutive patients at each site treated between 1/1/1999 and 12/31/2020 who fulfil all the eligibility criteria. The primary outcome measures will be the accuracy of a radiologic call of iENE (with pENE being the gold standard comparator) by radiologists not trained for any standardized diagnostic classification systems for iENE, overall survival rates based on presence of iENE and pENE, recurrence rates based on presence of iENE and pENE, overall survival rates based on presence of various degrees of iENE and pENE, and recurrence rates based on presence of various degrees of iENE and pENE. The secondary outcome measures will be the diagnostic accuracy of various radiographic features of iENE with pENE, diagnostic accuracy of published standardized classification systems with pENE, interobserver variability measured by Cohen's kappa, and utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in accurately diagnosing iENE. The study will be conducted over a period of 31 December 2023.

============

The study aims to compare the efficiency and safety of bedside versus conventional bone biopsy in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of patients with DFO. The main objective is to demonstrate non-inferiority of beside blind bone biopsy compared to conventional bone biopsy (surgical or radiological) on DFO remission without surgery at 1 year. The secondary objectives are to compare clinical efficacy between groups of bone biopsy, compare microbiological culture results between groups, compare the safety of both procedures, compare DFO remission according to results of BB (negative or positive), estimate total costs for the intervention and total medical costs in each groups, estimate total quality adjusted life years (QALYs) based upon EQ5D5L scores, and calculate the point estimate of the incremental cost utility ratio and estimate the probability of decremental cost effectiveness for the beside blind bone biopsy compared to conventional biopsy. The study will include subjects with diabetes and DFU with a suspicion of DFO. DFO is a complication of a large amount of DFU and is a major trigger of lower limb amputations. As we will include participants before bacteriological confirmation of DFO through bone biopsy, we will use the clinical and radiological criteria for DFO according to IWGDF 2019 guidelines. The intervention is a bedside blind bone biopsy procedure performed by a physician at the bedside in the clinical ward. The primary outcome measure is the remission of DFO at 12 months and is defined by a composite criterion as: an epithelialized ulcer for 28 consecutive days and absence of local inflammation and/or stabilization or improvement of radiologic abnormalities and no need for surgery of the foot to treat DFO during follow-up. The secondary outcome measures include clinical efficacy, microbiological results, occurrence of adverse events during the study, remission rate of DFO, costs, and QALYs. The study will be conducted as an open-label, parallel-group, randomized, non-inferiority trial. The study will be conducted in two centers in Paris, France.
