The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of high-intensity interval training on physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance among college male ice hockey players in China. The study uses a randomized controlled design with two groups: an experimental group that receives high-intensity interval training and a control group that receives traditional technical skill training. The study measures maximal oxygen uptake performance, endurance performance, power performance, agility and skill performance, and passing and shooting performance before and after the intervention. The study finds that high-intensity interval training significantly improves maximal oxygen uptake performance, endurance performance, power performance, agility and skill performance, and passing and shooting performance compared to traditional technical skill training. The study suggests that high-intensity interval training is an effective method for improving the physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college ice hockey players.

The study aims to investigate the effect of chlorhexidine mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion. The study will be a double blind, randomised design, crossover trial for the effect of chlorhexidine mouthwash on healthy control and people with dental erosion (PwDE). The study will be conducted over 15 visits, with each visit lasting 30-40 minutes. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either a placebo chlorhexidine mouthwash or an antibacterial chlorhexidine mouthwash. The study will measure blood pressure, endothelial function, flow-mediated dilation, nitrate and nitrite in saliva and plasma, oxidative stress markers and redox-related molecules via ELISA, and identification of salivary proteins via SDS-PAGE electrophoresis and proteomics analysis. The study will be conducted at the University of Portsmouth, UK.

===============

A Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) for patients after accidental injury can reduce opioid use and improve quality of life. The study is designed as a prospective randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the effect of a PAC-plan. The PAC-plan consists of three main elements: an opioid management plan upon discharge from the hospital, an appointment with the participant's regular GP within 2-4 weeks after discharge and an opportunity for increased collaboration between GP and hospital specialists. The primary outcome is oral morphine equivalent (OMEQ) consumption 6 weeks after discharge. Secondary outcome measures are OMEQ 52 weeks after discharge. In addition, registry-based OMEQ, pain, health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and other Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) at 6 and 52 weeks. The study will be conducted at the Division of orthopaedic surgery, Oslo University Hospital (OUH), Norway. OUH is a highly specialized hospital in charge of extensive regional and local hospital assignments in the South-Eastern Health region in Norway and is described as a level 1 trauma centre. The study will recruit 100 patients from the Division of orthopedic surgery, Oslo University Hospital (OUH), Norway. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Norwegian Regional Ethics Committee for South-Eastern Norway.

=================

The study is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study that compares the use of a guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing to the center's original antiplatelet regimen in patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms who receive intracranial stenting. The primary outcome measure is ischemic events, including ischemic stroke, transient ischemic stroke (TIA), and stent thrombosis, occurring 30 days after stent implantation. The study is designed to prevent ischemic events. The study is randomized, with patients being assigned to either the control group, which continues to use the center's original antiplatelet regimen, or the experimental group, which uses a guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing. The guided antiplatelet regimen is adjusted based on LTA testing results, and the timing of drug adjustment is at least 1 day before stent implantation. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of the guided antiplatelet regimen in preventing ischemic events.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will use dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans to assess bone mineral density, a gross motor function measurement scale (GMFM) to assess gross motor function, and a quality of life questionnaire for children (CP QOL-Child) to assess quality of life. The study will include two groups: Group 1 (ambulant) and Group 2 (non-ambulant). Group 1 will consist of 37 children with CP classified to level I, II, and III according to GMFCS, while Group 2 will consist of 38 children with CP classified to level IV and V according to GMFCS. The study will be conducted over one day, and the primary outcome measures will be DXA scans, GMFM, and CP QOL-Child. The study aims to provide valuable insights into the factors influencing the holistic well-being of children with CP.

The study aims to investigate the effects of dopamine on working memory gating, learning, and motivation. The study will use a within-subjects, double-blind, randomized placebo-controlled design. Participants will receive both placebo and the active medication (sulpiride 400mg) in a crossover design. The primary outcome measures will include working memory gating task reaction time, working memory gating task accuracy, Simon task accuracy, Simon task reaction time, perceptual decision-making task accuracy, and perceptual decision-making task reaction time. Secondary outcome measures will include eye-blink rate, Operation Span test, Digit Span test, Beck Depression Inventory, Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, Behavioural Inhibition Scale/Behavioural Activation Scale, State and Trait Anxiety Inventory, Utrechtse Burnout Schaal/Maslach Burnout Inventory, and Covid-19 Stress Scales. The study will be conducted in healthy volunteers between 18 and 45 years of age, who are predominantly right-handed and have no history of prolactin-dependent tumors, autonomic failure, clinically significant hepatic, cardiac, obstructive respiratory, renal, cerebrovascular, cardiovascular, metabolic, ocular or pulmonary disease/disorders, epilepsy in adulthood, endocrine treatment, neuroendocrine treatment, melanoma, hypersensitivity to sulpiride, one first degree or two or more second degree family members with a history of sudden death or ventricular arrhythmia, abnormal QT interval, uncontrolled hypertension, diagnosed skin lesions, lactose intolerance, glaucoma or increased risk for glaucoma, possible pregnancy or breastfeeding, metal objects in or around the body, claustrophobia, diagnosis (or history of) psychiatric treatment, neurological treatment, drug dependence (opiate, LSD, (meth)amphetamine, cocaine, solvents, or barbiturate), alcohol dependence, use of MAO inhibitor, anaesthetic, antidepressant or antipsychotic drugs within the week prior to the start of the study, average use of

===============

The HYGEF study aims to determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension (HT) in a cohort of adolescents, perform genetic analyses to determine a link between specific polymorphisms and/or mutations of genes involved in the development of HT in adults like the Adducin genes and Endogenous Ouabain (EO) and HT and explore whether urine Na+/K+ excretion and urinary markers of inflammation and oxidative stress are linked to HT and cardiovascular risk in participants with the selected genotypes. The study will enroll adolescents in high schools in the north (Milan), center (Livorno) and south (Grottaglie) of Italy to obtain a sample that could be representative of the Italian adolescents. During the visit at the high school, investigators will obtain questionnaires to have some information about eating habits, lifestyle and family history, two (or three in they were very discordant) blood pressure measurements, weight and height of the students, a sample of urine and a sample of saliva to extract DNA. Genotyping will be performed on the basis of previous genetic studies carried out in adult patients with hypertension and cardiovascular and renal related diseases. The primary outcome measure of the study is to establish a link of specific polymorphisms of Adducins and EO-related genes with selected phenotypes (hypertension, Na+ and K+ intake). The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years.

=========

The EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA) is a randomized, feasibility trial that aims to explore whether general anaesthesia can cause epigenetic changes in children and whether the type of anaesthetic given impacts any changes present. Participants undergoing hypospadias surgery will be randomized to one of two anaesthetic maintenance approaches that are used routinely in clinical practice: intravenous or inhalational. Blood will be taken before and after surgery to undergo laboratory analysis including epigenetic, biochemical, haematological, and redox. The study has been designed as a feasibility trial to evaluate whether a larger scale trial looking at anaesthesia and surgery in relation to changes in markers on DNA (epigenetics) is both possible, and of value. The primary objective is to assess and determine the feasibility of conducting a paediatric perioperative epigenetics study in which participants are randomized to two methods of maintaining anaesthesia for surgery. The findings will be disseminated in both a timely and responsible manner amongst the relevant scientific community and shared in an appropriate fashion with the legal representatives of the children who took part after.

=========

The study aims to investigate whether a variety of additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in patients with hypothyroidism receiving L-T4 in whom TSH cannot be used as a reflection of thyroid hormone status (e.g. central hypothyroidism). The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design and will include 100 patients with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, 100 patients with hypothyroidism after total thyroidectomy due to thyroid carcinoma, 100 patients with central hypothyroidism, and 100 healthy controls. The primary outcome measures will be TSH, fT4, fT3, and fT3/fT4 ratio concentrations. Secondary outcome measures will include TT4, TT3, rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitine(s), and amino acids concentrations. The study will assess whether the additional markers can provide a better insight into thyroid hormone status in peripheral tissues and whether they can be used to predict thyroid hormone status in patients using L-T4 in whom TSH cannot be used to assess thyroid hormone status. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands and will be approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of the University Medical Center Groningen.

The FRAIL-HIP study showed that palliative non-operative management (PNOM) can be a good alternative for frail elderly people with a hip fracture who do not benefit from operative treatment. The aim of this project is to implement PNOM in all Dutch hospitals as part of shared decision-making in a select group of frail patients with a hip fracture. The study design is a multicenter prospective cohort study. The target population are frail institutionalized elderly who have a limited life expectancy and fracture their proximal femur. The study will use mixed methods in the different phases of the study. The primary outcome measure is nonoperative treatment.

The study aims to generate proof-of-concept of using a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning for patients with brain tumours. By extending the clinical standard MRI session used for radiotherapy planning in 10 patients diagnosed with glioblastoma with advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation, a physiological CTV will be generated for each patient in addition to the standard CTV. Treatment for each patient will be according to the current standard in which the standard CTV is used. Initial analysis will include comparing both CTVs in terms of volume and location. Patient follow-up will occur according to the clinical standard, including the standard MRI scan protocols, for a maximum of 2 years. Pattern-of-failure analysis will be done to compare the standard CTV and physiological CTV. It is hypothesized that the physiological CTV will be smaller than the standard CTV, whilst having the same pattern-of-failure.

The study aims to evaluate the acceptance and effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients treated by autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT) and actively followed at Saint Louis on January 1st, 2021. The study will compare the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT as compared to non-AHSCT SSc patients. Secondary outcomes will include the proportion of SSc patients who refused vaccination during the study period, the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 infection in SSc patients previously treated by AHSCT and in non-transplant controls, the time of onset of first COVID-19 infection (symptomatic or asymptomatic) diagnosed during the study period after completing at least 2 vaccine injections in SSc patients previously treated by AHSCT and in non-transplant controls, the severity of symptomatic COVID-19, and the proportion of SSc patients with at least 1 grade≥3 adverse event after COVID19 vaccination. The study will also assess the humoral response in SSc patients treated by AHSCT and in controls after messenger RiboNucleic Acid (mRNA) vaccine against SARS-CoV. The study will be conducted in two arms: one arm will include SSc patients treated by AHSCT and actively followed at Saint Louis on January 1st, 2021, and the other arm will include SSc patients treated by AHSCT and actively followed at Saint Louis on January 1st, 2021, but without AHSCT. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Filière des maladies Auto-immunes et Auto Inflammatoires Rares (FAI2R) systemic sclerosis centers.

The CONNECT study is a stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CNH+ intervention in improving parental mental health and infant outcomes in NICUs in Canada. The study will be conducted in 10 NICUs across Canada, with 5 NICUs in the intervention arm and 5 NICUs in the control arm. The intervention will be implemented in a stepped wedge design, with each NICU implementing the intervention in a staggered manner over a 2-year period. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including both quantitative and qualitative data collection methods. The primary outcome measures will include parental mental health (as measured using the Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy Scale) and infant outcomes (as measured using the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Outcomes Scale). Secondary outcome measures will include parental engagement in care, parental satisfaction with the NICU experience, and infant outcomes (as measured using the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Outcomes Scale). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Research Ethics Board of each participating NICU.

The study aims to investigate the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis. The study includes women with medium and high risk as determined by the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Women (OST) who are 54 years old and over and in the post-menopausal period. The experimental group receives the Otago Exercise Program, which includes strengthening exercises and moderate-intensity walking exercise, while the control group receives no intervention. The study measures lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment model and no masking. The primary outcome measures are lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life. The secondary outcome measure is dynamic balance. The study is conducted in French and is registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry with the identifier NCT03505557.

This is a two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) falling under the preparation phase of the Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) framework. The study aims to demonstrate if a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity is feasible and if there is preliminary effectiveness that diet quality and meal timing traits improves as assessed by 24-hr dietary recalls, a novel urine biomarker, and continuous glucose monitoring (CGM). Adolescents (N=14, aged 14-17 years) at risk for diet quality that is low or in need of improvement (Healthy Eating Index (HEI) < 80) and with a history of having overweight or obesity (body mass index (BMI) between the 85th and 99th percentile on at least two occasions six months apart in the medical record in the last five years) will be invited to participate. Clinical measurements will be acquired at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). Diet, urine, blood glucose, physical activity, and sleep data collection will take place in the home setting. The study interventions and measures include personalized goal, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies delivered through text messaging. The primary outcome is change in overall Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score. Secondary outcomes include change in urinary Na and K.

===============

The study aims to analyze the incidence of postoperative complications such as CH and CHS within 1 month and to find the risk factors of CH. The study will enroll 400 cases of patients suffering from carotid artery stenosis. The investigators will perform TCD on patients by Sonographer for identifying CH. Postoperative CH will be defined in patients whose MCA mean velocity increased by more than 100% within 48 hour after carotid artery stent. CH and CHS mostly occurs within one week after CAS. The parameter of ultrasonic measurement will be stored in Statistical Package for the Social Sciences （PACS）and analyzed later. The study will use a controlled clinical study design. The intervention/treatment will be carotid artery stenting. The primary outcome measure will be cerebral hyperperfusion and the secondary outcome measure will be cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to test the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered expressive writing intervention on emotional, social, and physical well-being among informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer. The study will use a randomized crossover design with a waitlist control. Participants will attend four group-based expressive writing sessions led by a trained facilitator. The study will measure changes in psychological distress, quality of life, and depression at 6 weeks.

===============

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled single-surgeon trial performed at the University of California San Francisco that investigates the use of IV TXA in patients undergoing GAM. Patients who meet WPATH guidelines for GAM, undergo GAM, ASA I-III, and are >18 years old will have the opportunity to be enrolled. Patients will be randomized by a random computer generator and will be notified after randomization as to which group they are assigned. The investigators will enroll patients into this prospective trial investigating the effect of IV TXA on postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal. Patients will be randomized into two groups, an experimental group receiving IV TXA and a control group that will not receive IV TXA. Patients will be excluded if they are <18 years old, have a history of prior chest surgeries, coagulopathy or bleeding disorders, and have a history of thromboembolic events including deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Patients will also be excluded if they are chronically anticoagulated, are on antiplatelet medications or have ever had an adverse reaction to IV TXA. All patients who are being scheduled to undergo bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction will be recruited to participate in the study. Patients will be consented to participate in the preoperative visit. The primary outcomes will include the presence of hematoma, seroma, and drain output, and time to drain removal, while the secondary outcomes will consist of thromboembolic events and wound complications. Patients will be managed for hematoma and seroma as per standard procedure, whether with ultrasound, clinic aspiration, IR drain placement, or return to the operating room as deemed necessary by the senior surgeon.

=================

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of smell training (ST) and trigeminal nerve stimulation (TNS) in adults with COVID-related persistent smell loss (anosmia, hyposmia, phantosmia or parosmia). The study aims to determine the efficacy of ST versus potential natural gains in function, the TNS-enhanced effects of ST on smell function, and whether TNS+ST is more efficacious than ST in treating the other symptoms of long COVID. The study will use a 3-group design: Group 1) Active ST (N=60), Group 2) Placebo ST (PBO, N=60), and Group 3) Active TNS plus Active ST (N=60). The primary outcome measures will be change in psychophysical olfactory function from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in perceived intensity of odorants from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in perceived hedonics of odorants from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in olfactory-related quality of life from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, and change in impact of olfactory loss from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include change in long COVID symptoms from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in sustained attention from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in cognitive function from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in mood state from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in sleep quality from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in excessive daytime sleepiness from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, change in symptoms of depression from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks, and change in symptoms of anxiety from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=================
The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the clinical effect of acupuncture therapy on primary insomnia. The study includes two arms: the acupuncture group and the placebo acupuncture group. The acupuncture group receives Tiaoshen acupuncture, while the placebo acupuncture group receives non-insertive acupuncture using the sham needle supported by the Park device. The primary outcome measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which is used to evaluate the insomnia degree before and after treatment. The secondary outcome measures include the Fatigue Scale-14, the Epworth Sleepiness Scale, and the Self-Rating Anxiety Scale. The study is conducted over a period of 4 weeks, with the PSQI score being evaluated at the beginning, end, and 4 weeks after treatment. The study is designed as a parallel assignment, with triple masking.

This is a phase 3, randomized, open-label, parallel-group, multicenter study of anthracycline-free, platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy with or without pembrolizumab in patients with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer. The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of the two arms in terms of pathologic complete response (pCR), residual cancer burden (RCB), distant relapse-free survival (DRFS), overall survival (OS), and other secondary endpoints. The study will also assess patient-reported outcomes, including fatigue and physical function.

The study aims to evaluate a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP) in preventing the need for foster care and promoting the recovery of pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy. The study will use a quasi-experimental design with a control group to compare one-year outcomes with the PCAP-1 participants. The study will measure the proportion of target children not placed in foster care, mother acquires or maintains child custody, proportion of mothers abstinent from drugs and/or alcohol, proportion of mothers on a reliable method(s) of birth control, reduction in costs to state agencies, proportion of mothers who acquire or maintain stable housing, proportion of mothers who acquire or maintain employment, proportion of mothers who enroll in or complete an educational program, proportion of mothers with ongoing criminal justice involvement, and proportion of mothers who receive public benefits. The study will be conducted in Oklahoma with two sites enrolling 100 participants each, randomly assigned to the experimental groups: treatment and control (services as usual). The one-year intervention will take place over the three-year project period, with enrollment into PCAP-1 occurring on a rolling basis over the first two years of this study. Two case managers will each be assigned 20 PCAP-1 participants over the study period to avoid the n=1 confounding problem. The study will use the recruitment strategies described above to recruit 40 eligible people into PCAP-1 at a third PCAP site. The long- and short-form Addiction Severity Index (ASI) and the investigator-created Self-Administered Survey (SAS) will capture outcome data about individuals in both the PCAP-1 and control groups. The SAS will elicit information from clients along several dimensions covering a wide range of client behavior metrics and social psychological concepts important for addiction research, including criminal justice involvement, additional adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), social support, maternal attachment (antenatal and postnatal), mental health, self-esteem and self-efficacy, addiction beliefs, parenting practices, and parent/child experiences and child development. The study will also contribute complementary child welfare administrative data to the evaluation of PCAP-1. The study is a comparative study of the Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and the LenStar LS900. The study is designed to evaluate the agreement between the test devices and the predicate device, the precision of the test devices, and the safety of the test devices. The study will be conducted in three subject populations: normal, cataract, and special eyes. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 4 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study is a phase III, interventional, multicenter, open label, randomized study to evaluate whether treatment with zanubrutinib in combination with rituximab will result in an improvement in Progression Free Survival (PFS) compared to treatment with rituximab in patients with previously untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL). The study will include a Screening Phase, a Treatment Phase, and a Follow-Up Phase. Subjects with investigator-confirmed progressive disease (PD) according to the Lugano 2014 criteria or unacceptable toxicity, or investigator/subject decision must discontinue study treatment. Patients who complete the treatment and patients who will discontinue treatment for any reason will enter the Follow-up Phase. The Response Follow-up Phase will occur for subjects who complete the treatment or discontinue for reasons other than disease progression and will include efficacy assessments every 24 weeks until investigator-assessed disease progression. Subjects with PD during the Response Follow-up Phase will continue to be followed in the Survival Follow-up Phase. An Independent Data Monitoring Committee (IDMC) will be responsible for independent review of the interim safety analysis on the first 20 enrolled patients in the experimental arm.

===============

The study aims to enhance parent/caregiver engagement in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) through the use of a PICU journal. Eligible participants will be identified by their primary Certified Child Life Specialist using the daily PICU census and electronic medical record. All eligible participants will first be approached by the child life specialist on their care team to provide brief information about the study and refer to the key study personnel if the parent/caregiver is interested in learning more. If they are potentially interested in participating, a member of the key study personnel will approach the parent/caregiver at bedside and give information and obtain consent. Data will be collected at three-time points: time one (T1) between 24 - 72 hours of the child's admission, time two (T2), peri-discharge, and time three (T3) three months post-discharge. The primary outcome measures include parent/caregiver reported stress level, parent/caregiver care engagement level, parent/caregiver reported depression and anxiety symptoms, parent/caregiver reported impact of events, parent/caregiver use of and satisfaction with PICU journal, child reported impact of events, and parent/caregiver experiences interview. The study will be conducted at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt.

This study aims to improve the health and well-being of Hispanic/Latino autistic children by improving the utilization of the evidence-based autism intervention Ayres Sensory Integration and to improve stakeholder engagement in the research process for effective outcomes. The study uses a randomized mixed methods design to evaluate stakeholder engagement. Phase one compares two stakeholder engagement methods (Design Thinking -DT, and Focus Group - FG) and evaluates stakeholder engagement. Phase two uses data from phase one to culturally adapt the intervention and obtain stakeholder input on acceptability and feasibility for the Hispanic/Latino population. The study measures stakeholder engagement using the Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation and evaluates implementation success via the Acceptability of Intervention Measure (AIM), Intervention Appropriateness Measure (IAM) and the Feasibility of Intervention Measure (FIM). The study is being developed by a skilled and experienced team of investigators.

The study aims to investigate the effect of the flipped learning model on nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University Nursing Department. The experimental group will receive flipped training, while the control group will receive normal course education. The study will measure the effect of the flipped learning model on the course success of nursing students. The study will last until 20/12/2023.

=============

This is a prospective study to quantify the ability of Epitel's™ Remote EEG Monitoring System's (REMI™) to record electroencephalography (EEG) of seizure events in an ambulatory setting for extended periods (14 - 28 days). Patients presenting with questionable seizure characterization that are scheduling a conventional at home ambulatory EEG (Amb EEG) and who meet the study inclusion and exclusion criteria will be prescribed a REMI system. The purpose of this study is to demonstrate that the REMI system is able to record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify ictal events over extended periods, and that extended clinical EEG data is valuable in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure related symptoms. The study will measure the number of seizures identified in the first three days and the number of seizures identified during days one to fourteen and all twenty-eight days. The study will be conducted in an open label design.

The study aims to compare the effect of a Multi-Component Training (MCT) programme versus a Continuous Cardiovascular Training (CVT) programme on blood pressure levels in adult hypertensive subjects. The study will be conducted as a controlled, randomised, longitudinal and prospective clinical trial, with several simultaneous study branches; on the one hand, the intervention with Multicomponent Training; on the other hand, the intervention Continuous Training and, finally, the control group. The recruitment of the sample will be done in collaboration with the primary health care centres in order to recruit a total of 75 adult hypertensive subjects between men and women who will be divided into three groups of 25 people each, two intervention groups and one control group. The inclusion criteria for participation in the clinical trial will be adult subjects, between 40 and 65 years of age, with controlled arterial hypertension and who do not do physical exercise or have not done so in the last 12 months. Exclusion criteria will be pregnant women and hypertensive patients with serious diseases that prevent the safe practice of physical exercise (unstable coronary artery disease, heart failure, renal failure, severe pulmonary hypertension, uncontrolled diabetes). The intervention will consist of two different training programmes, one with EMC and one with ECVC, for 12 weeks (3 months), with a frequency of 2 days a week and a duration of 60 minutes per session. During this period of time, the different phases of the design of the training programmes will be exhaustively defined, from the planning phase, with the anamnesis of the subject, through the periodisation phase, where the mesocycles, microcycles, training sessions and training units will be organised, the programming phase, controlling and manipulating the operative variables of frequency, volume, intensity and density, until reaching the last phase of the process, which will be the training prescription phase, with the work methodology and the selection of exercises. The EMC programme will involve applying two main intra-session and daily training units, a first part focused on strength work and a second part for cardiovascular training. This group will train 60 minutes per session, 10 minutes for the preparatory phase to exercise, 40 minutes for the main phase of the training, 20 minutes of strength work and 20

=========

The study is a before-and-after observational study that examines the effect of a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines on fasting time, preoperative anxiety, discomfort, thirst, hunger, nausea or vomiting, postoperative nausea or vomiting, patient satisfaction, postoperative quality of recovery, length of stay, and postoperative surgical complications in adult patients undergoing surgery. The study is conducted in a single center in France and includes a total of 100 participants. The intervention consists of a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting rules, which includes mandatory on-site lectures, reminder displays, individualized fasting cards, short message service reminders, and medical fasting prescriptions with clear fasting times. The primary outcome measure is fasting time, which is measured before surgery. Secondary outcome measures include preoperative anxiety, discomfort, thirst, hunger, nausea or vomiting, postoperative nausea or vomiting, patient satisfaction, postoperative quality of recovery, length of stay, and postoperative surgical complications. The study is conducted over a maximum of 30 days follow-up period.

===============

The study aims to test the effects of the Mentored Planning to be Active + Family intervention on physical activity outcomes and health outcomes among rural Appalachian 7/8th grade children suffering from overweight and obesity. The study is a community-based randomized controlled trial targeting 7th grade students in rural Appalachia. Half of the participants will receive MPBA+F, and the other half will receive self-guided (usual care) modules. The long-term goal is to reduce the high rates of overweight, obesity, and type 2 diabetes in Appalachian youth through effective, sustainable interventions. The study measures change in daily physical activity and body composition.

The study aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality animation and ice massage on labor pain, duration of labor, and satisfaction in term primiparous and singleton pregnancies. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. The experimental group received ice massage to the hoku point for 20 minutes and virtual reality animation for 20 minutes. The control group received standard care. The primary outcome measures were labor pain, labor duration, and birth satisfaction. The study measured labor pain using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)I and II, labor duration using the Personal Information Form, and birth satisfaction using the Birth Satisfaction Scale - Revised (BSS-R). The study was conducted in a hospital in Quebec, Canada.

===============

A Study of Cytomegalovirus Disease Epidemiology in Pediatric and Adult Liver Transplant Recipients in China is a study that aims to investigate the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections among children and adult liver transplantation patients in China. The study will include participants who have received their first orthotopic liver transplant within 10 days prior, are willing to participate in the study, and have the ability to understand information material. The study will measure the primary outcome of clinically significant CMV reactivation or CMV disease observed within 12 months of transplantation, as well as secondary outcomes such as loss to follow-up survey and participants asked to withdraw. The study will be conducted over a period of 22 months after liver transplantation.

===============

Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT) for Right Brain Stroke Rehabilitation is a study that aims to develop a biomarker-based process to identify patients who should be administered PAT. The study will define and validate brain imaging biomarkers that predict the presence of Aiming SN, a strong predictor of functional recovery after receiving PAT. The study will also examine the correlation between the brain imaging biomarkers predicting Aiming SN and improvements in daily life function after PAT. The study will determine if adding behavioral predictors to biomarker predictors accounts for additional variance in the trajectory of functional recovery. The study will establish the utility of a validated biomarker that routinely identifies Veterans with SN after stroke who are the best candidates for PAT. The study will reduce reliance on specialized SN assessment, coordinate VA and community systems providing Veteran stroke care, and improve stroke care efficiency, to enhance outcomes and quality of life after stroke for thousands of Veterans.

The study aims to analyze the blood samples of patients with brain lesions in the resonance images compatible with a glioma-like tumor in order to detect and quantify the circulating DNA (ctDNA) of tumor cells on it. The study will use a ddPCR to detect specific mutations present in this tumoral ctDNA, allowing the team to confirm the presence of a glioma-type tumor, and providing real-time information of its classification as astrocytoma or oligodendroglioma. The study will be a pilot study of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas by analyzing circulating tumor DNA in blood samples, and its validation with the corresponding tissue biopsies. The study will be a single group assignment, open label, and will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The primary outcome measure will be the detection of circulating free DNA in blood samples of patients by means of a ddPCR. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a pilot study of zimberelimab and quemliclustat in combination with chemotherapy in patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer (BRPC) or locally advanced pancreatic cancer (LAPC). The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy. The primary objective is to estimate the resection rate in the BRPC cohort and progression free survival in the LAPC cohort. Secondary objectives include estimating the change in CA 19-9 levels, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate, and overall survival. The study will use a Simon's two-stage design to demonstrate the resection rate is greater than 50%. The study will enroll 20 patients with BRPC and 20 patients with LAPC. Patients will receive zimberelimab IV, quemliclustat IV, oxaliplatin IV, leucovorin calcium IV, and inrinotecan IV on study. Patients will undergo collection of blood samples and CT throughout the trial. Patients with borderline-resectable pancreatic cancer will undergo collection of tissue samples. Patients with locally advanced pancreatic cancer will undergo core biopsy. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study aims to investigate the effect of MIYAIRI 588 on depression syndrome and risk factors of cardiovascular disease in hemodialysis patients. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The participants are adults aged 20 years or older undergoing hemodialysis for at least 3 months, with a URR of 65% or higher. The participants must not have allergies to the components of the intervention drug, low tolerance of milk or dairy products, dementia, delirium, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, liver failure, or significant suicide risk during the study. The participants must not have a significant clinical syndrome, addiction to alcohol or drugs, terminal cancer, severe infection, heart failure, central venous catheter in the past 6 months, or be taking antibiotics, anti-oxidant vitamin supplement, probiotics, prebiotics, antidepressants, anti-anxiety medicine, yogurt, or the products in the past 3 months. The participants must not be pregnant or lactating. The study will measure the change in depression score using the Beck Depression Inventory score (Chinese version 2.0) at 3 months. The study will be conducted in China.

The study aims to test the feasibility and acceptability of integrated CM-PST in a K99 Phase, and to test the efficacy of CM-PST in a R00 Phase. The K99 Phase is a single-arm pre/post study, while the R00 Phase is a 2-arm randomized control trial. The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence, and the secondary outcome measures include change in AUD severity, change in AUD screening status, change in alcohol-related negative consequences, change in alcohol use, change in drug use, change in reasons for drinking, change in negative affect, change in positive affect, and change in neural target engagement of positive affect, negative affect, and cognitive control. Participants must be male or female young adults aged 18-24 years, English-speaking, with current alcohol use greater or equal to 1 day/week via phone screening and meet criteria for mild, moderate, or severe AUD on the AUDIT and AUDADIS surveys. Participants will complete follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months with blinded outcome assessors.

===============

A phase 2, randomized, open-label study is being conducted to compare the efficacy of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, pembrolizumab) versus a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) in patients with BRAF V600E/K mutation-positive melanoma who progressed during or after prior treatment with anti-PD-1 therapy. Approximately 150 participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to the triplet or the doublet/control therapy (75 participants in each arm). Randomization will be stratified by baseline serum LDH level, and by type of PD-1 resistance. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate (ORR) as determined by investigator assessment per RECIST v1.1. The study is expected to be completed in approximately 48 months.

The study aims to determine the effect of high fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation applications on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students. The study will be conducted at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing. The study will be conducted with 68 students, 34 in a group. The study will be conducted with 68 students, 34 in a group. The study is a randomized, cross-over, single-center, open-label, phase 2 clinical trial. The study aims to compare the reduction of microemboli of air using a new developed air trap (Emboless) during hemodialysis (HD) with a standard air trap (Fresenius 4008/5008). The study is designed to measure the reduction of air microemboli contamination in the venous bloodline during HD. The study is conducted in a cross-over design, where each patient is randomized to perform the first HD with either their standard air trap (F5008) in the venous bloodline tubing or using the Emboless bloodline and vice versa. Each patient is included to make two paired series. A maximum of 30 patients are planned. Each with 2 series of each two different sets of air traps that would give a total of 120 dialyses. A safety committee evaluates if significantly worse outcome appears especially with the Emboless. During HD the microbubbles are counted by a GAMPT ultrasound device using two probes. One probe is set at the inlet side of the air trap and the second at the outlet side. The outlet side represents data of microbubbles in the blood that are entering into the patient. Comparative non-parametric paired analyses are performed between the air traps. Monitoring of the study is performed.

The study aims to determine how repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (theta burst stimulation) influences movement among individuals with and without a concussion history. The study is a single-blinded cross-over design with two testing sessions separated by a minimum of 7 days. During the first testing session, participants complete single-task serial subtraction, single- and dual-task jump landing, and a theta burst stimulation intervention. The jump landing will be completed before and after theta burst stimulation and under single- and dual-task (serial 7s) conditions. During the second testing session, participants complete the jump landing before and after theta burst stimulation under single- and dual-task (serial 7s) conditions. On both testing sessions, the symptom checklist and Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia 11 (TSK-11) will be administered upon arrival to the lab (after informed consent on day 1), and immediately after repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation. The Godin Leisure Activity Questionnaire will be administered on both days before the jump landing. The NASA Task Load index will be administered on both days immediately after the completion of every cognitive and motor task. At the end of the second day of testing, the participants will be asked which day the participants believed the participants received the experimental and control conditions of the theta burst stimulation intervention. The study is designed to measure reaction time, knee flexion angle, knee abduction angle, hip flexion angle, hip adduction angle, trunk flexion angle, trunk lateral bending angle, NASA Task Load Index, and Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia 11. The study is a non-invasive brain stimulation and injury risk biomechanics study.

=========

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing extended pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPDEXCEPT) with conventional pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy. The study aims to evaluate the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula and other outcomes such as location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and postoperative mortality. The study includes patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, Vater ampulla, head or uncinate process of the pancreas, aged between 18 and 80 years, with good compliance and cooperation with follow-up. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: extended transection group and conventional transection group. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula, and the secondary outcome measures include location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and postoperative mortality. The study is expected to be completed in 3 months postoperatively.

===============

The study aims to compare the effects of two types of concurrent training on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life of older adults. The first type of training is traditional concurrent training consisting of strength and aerobic exercises. The second type of training is concurrent training consisting of strength training combined with dance classes. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled clinical trial with a sample size of 100 participants aged between 65 and 75 years old. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: experimental group (traditional concurrent training), experimental group (concurrent training consisting of strength training combined with dance classes), or control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measures will include changes in dynamic balance, cognitive function, self-reported quality of life, static balance, seat to stand capacity, stairs climb capacity, leg strength, leg power, hand grip strength, and cardiorespiratory capacity. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity with the intervention, lipid profile, specific tension of quadriceps, and depressive symptoms. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 8 weeks, and 12 weeks.

=========

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of a virtual reality-based sensory stimulation intervention in preventing delirium in intensive care units. The study will recruit all ICU patients admitted to the study setting who are ≥ 18 years, have not been diagnosed with dementia, delirium or acute psychiatric illness, and have a Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) score ≥-3. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive VR-based sensory stimulation, or the control group, which will receive usual care. The primary outcome measures will include delirium incidence, duration, and severity, while the secondary outcome measures will encompass patients' psychological well-being, clinical outcomes, and other outcomes. The study will be conducted over a period of fourteen days, with all interventions administered by a research team. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the outcome of surgical fixation of multiple fractured ribs with the outcome of conservative management. The study includes 100 patients with multiple fractured ribs who are randomly assigned to either the intervention group (surgical fixation) or the control group (conservative management). The primary outcome measures are the need and duration of mechanical ventilation and the severity of thoracic pain using a pain scale of 0 to 10. The study is conducted at Sohag University Hospital and is designed to run for 1 year.

The study aims to compare the acute psychobiological responses to the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) in healthy, recreationally active men and women aged 18-35 years. Participants will complete the MMST or the TSST and have their saliva cortisol, state anxiety inventory (STAI-S), heart rate, and salivary alpha amylase (sAA) measured before and after the stress test. The study will use stratified block randomisation to evenly distribute participants to the MMS or the TSST based upon sex (male or female) and trait anxiety (low STAI-T score <40 or high STAI-T score ≥40). The primary outcome measure will be changes in the concentration of saliva free cortisol assessed by ELISA. Secondary outcome measures will include assessments of state anxiety inventory (STAI-S) response to acute psychological stress, continuous measurement of heart rate, and salivary alpha amylase (sAA).

===============

The DELI_NAFLD study is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial designed to assess the short-term efficacy and safety of postbiotics (cell lysate and DNA fragments of the probiotic strain L. rhamnosus DV - NRRLB-68023) in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will include 3 periods: a screening period of up to 1 week, a treatment period of 3 months, and a follow-up period of up to 3 months. Participants will receive a twice daily oral dose of postbiotics or placebo in capsules identical in organoleptic characteristics. The primary outcome measure will be changes in hepatic fat content as measured by magnetic resonance proton density fat fraction (MRI-PDFF) in % at 3 months compared to baseline. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in hepatic steatosis index (HSI), ALT, AST, GGT, liver stiffness (LS), TyG index, hs-CRP, total cholesterol (TC), triglycerides (TG), LDL-C, VLDL-C, HDL-C, waist circumferences (WC), body mass index (BMI), body fat in percentage, and visceral fat content. The study aims to determine the efficacy and safety of postbiotics in treating NAFLD and to identify potential biomarkers for the diagnosis and monitoring of the disease.

=============

The study aims to examine the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) plus standard medical therapy in reducing the experience of pain in patients 6 to 21 years with sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) who present to the emergency department (ED), compared to historical standard medical care alone. The study also aims to examine the effectiveness of VR plus standard medical therapy in reducing hospital admission rates for patients 6 to 21 years with sickle cell VOC who present to the ED, compared to historical standard medical therapy alone. The study will use a non-randomized, sequential assignment design with two separate arms: a control arm and a trial arm. The control arm will be a retrospective chart review of patients ages 6 to 21 who present to the pediatric emergency department with sickle cell VOC listed as one of their diagnoses. The trial arm will be a prospective, convenience sampling of up to 100 patients ages 6 to 21 years who present to the pediatric emergency department with VOC listed as either their main complaint or as one of multiple complaints as identified by health care provider at time of presentation and meet inclusion criteria. The intervention will be virtual reality headset which will be offered simultaneously with standard medication therapy. The primary outcome measures will be pain scores, patient disposition, length of stay in the emergency department, and time to emergency department disposition.

============

The PREVEN-IAM study is a randomized, parallel assignment, digital empowerment intervention for patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The intervention is delivered through a web-based platform and includes periodic delivery of email messages with links to educational, motivational and supportive materials for secondary prevention, access to a message box for questions and answers, and possibility of video-calls with the preventive team. The primary outcome measures include changes in BMI, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol levels, glycemia levels, glycosylated hemoglobin in diabetic patients, expired carbon monoxide in smokers, physical activity, adherence to a heart-friendly diet, smoking reduction or cessation, self-efficacy, health locus of control, and cardioprotective treatment adherence. Secondary outcome measures include long-term maintenance of controlled levels of risk factors and incidence of symptomatic coronary events. The study is designed to measure the efficacy of the digital empowerment intervention on measurable risk factors and lifestyle changes in patients with AMI.

===============

The study aims to investigate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in the diagnosis of pediatric elbow fractures. The primary research objective is to determine the test performance characteristics of PSUS performed by pediatric emergency medicine physicians compared to radiography for the detection of pediatric elbow fractures. The study will consist of two parts, first involving a feasibility study and followed by an active study. The feasibility phase will involve novice PsUS users obtaining accurate and adequate imaging for interpretation. The active study will compare the initial test performance characteristics of PSUS performed by bedside physicians compared to standard radiography in the diagnosis of pediatric elbow fractures. The study will measure the accuracy of PsUS elbow exams compared to Xray in suspected fracture or bedside nursemaid reduction in suspected subluxations. The feasibility outcome and acceptability of study training will be determined by successful completion of adequate images obtained during ultrasound elbow exam.

===============

The study aims to compare the effects of two different orthoses on individuals with hallux valgus deformity. The study will include 40 participants, 20 in each group. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the toe separator orthosis group or the dynamic orthosis group. The study will last for 1 month. The primary outcome measure will be the hallux valgus angle, which will be measured using a goniometer. The secondary outcome measures will be plantar pressure analysis and orthosis satisfaction. The study will be conducted at the Podiatry and Orthotics Center at Istanbul Medipol University.

===============

The study is a prospective evaluation of speech function in children with cleft palate and velopharyngeal insufficiency undergoing surgical treatment with pharyngeal flap. The study measures speech function through patient- and parent-response outcome measures, specifically the CLEFT-Q and Intelligibility in Context Scale. The primary outcome measures are changes in speech function preoperatively and 1 year postoperatively. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of pharyngeal flap surgery in improving speech function in children with cleft palate and velopharyngeal insufficiency.

=================
The Efficacy of Probiotics for the Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder Among Adult Males: A Comparison With Placebo and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in a Randomized Controlled Trial

The study aims to compare the efficacy of probiotics with placebo and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) in the treatment of alcohol use disorder (AUD) among adult males. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with a sample size of 120 participants. The primary outcome measure will be the change in Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol-Revised (CIWA-Ar) score across four time points. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in Penn Alcohol Craving Scale (PACS) score, Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD) score, and Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAMA) score. The study will also assess the change in event-related potential in EEG monitoring, serum tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) level, fecal microbiota analysis, and serum interleukin-1β (IL-1β) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of Xinxiang Medical University.

The study will compare the efficacy of probiotics with placebo and ACT in the treatment of AUD among adult males. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with a sample size of 120 participants. The primary outcome measure will be the change in CIWA-Ar score across four time points. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in PACS score, HAMD score, and HAMA score. The study will also assess the change in EEG monitoring, serum TNF-α level, fecal microbiota analysis, and serum IL-1β and IL-6 levels. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of Xinxiang Medical University.

=========

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of barbed absorbable sutures versus standard absorbable sutures for vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy. The primary outcome measures are vaginal cuff dehiscence at 30 and 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include vaginal cuff complications, hospital stay, operative time, intraoperative blood loss, 30-day post-surgical morbidity, quality of life index, and sexual function at 90 days after surgery. The study is designed as a multicenter, parallel arms, open-label, randomized controlled trial with double masking. Participants undergo elective total laparoscopic hysterectomy surgery performed for the treatment of benign pathology, aged 18 years or older, and are able to express adequate informed consent to participate in the study. The study is not designed to accept healthy volunteers. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of barbed absorbable sutures versus standard absorbable sutures for vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy.

===============

The study aims to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that proposes two opposite brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. The study will use fMRI to measure striatal and amygdala reactivity to reward and emotional stimuli, respectively, and Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) to measure gambling behavior and emotions in everyday life. The primary hypothesis is that these brain phenotypes are diametrically opposed in impulsive and emotional gamblers, and the secondary hypothesis is that these phenotypes are capable of predicting the relationship between emotions and gambling behavior in everyday life. The study will focus on individuals with gambling problems, including those with gambling addiction and problem gambling, and will include a control group of healthy individuals with no gambling problems and no psychiatric comorbidities. The study will recruit 60 gamblers and 60 healthy controls.

=================

The study is a randomized controlled prospective trial comparing 2D 4K vs. 3D HD laparoscopic imaging systems in bariatric surgery. The study aims to compare the operation time, intraoperative complications, workload of the operating surgeon, and postoperative complications between the two groups. The study includes patients with the indication for gastric bypass according to SMOB guidelines: BMI > 35, Age > 18 and Cumulative two years of controlled conservative dieting without weight loss. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with single masking. The primary outcome measure is operation time, and the secondary outcome measures are intraoperative complications, workload of the operating surgeon, and postoperative complications. The study is conducted in a single center and includes 30 patients in each group. The study is expected to be completed in 2022.

The study is a non-invasive observational study investigating the effects of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO) on critically ill patients. The study employs a modified technique to obtain exhaled air from the ventilator tubes to perform a standard hydrogen breath test for SIBO diagnosis. The study aims to assess the prevalence of SIBO on critically ill mechanically ventilated ICU patients. Secondary outcomes include investigation of the effects of SIBO on ventilator associated pneumonia, as well as ICU length of stay and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate in critically ill patients. The study aimed to investigate whether exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) is present following exercise in patient after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and if so, if it changes with exercise intensity. A repeated measures and single-blinded randomized study was done. Thirty-eight patients 24 hours after TKA were randomly assigned to either low intensity exercises (LIE) group or high intensity exercises (HIE) group. An exercise programs lasted for five days during the hospitalization period. Pain severity was assessed by Visual Analog Scale (VAS) (0-10 mm). Pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over quadriceps and biceps brachii and muscles immediately before and after exercise. The primary outcome measure was change of pain severity and change of Pressure pain theshold. The study found that exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) was present following exercise in patient after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and it changes with exercise intensity.

===============

The Nigerian Breast Cancer Risk-Reduction Study is a randomized, parallel assignment study designed to evaluate the effects of risk assessment and counselling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwestern Nigeria. The study will measure the effects of the intervention on adherence to breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction practices, as well as predictors of breast self-examination and time to first breast cancer screening post-intervention. The study will also determine the perception of familial breast cancer risk, knowledge of familiar breast cancer risk, and knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and breast cancer etiology among participants. The study will use the Nigerian Breast Cancer Study (NBCS) absolute risk prediction model to predict the 5-year and lifetime breast cancer risks of the participants. The study will be conducted over a period of six months, and participants will be followed up for this duration. The study will be conducted in Southwestern Nigeria, and will recruit first-degree female relatives of histologically diagnosed breast cancer patients aged 20 to 75 years of age who are willing to be contacted after six months for follow-up. The study will be conducted in two arms: a control arm that will receive standard care and a treatment arm that will receive standard care plus risk assessment and counselling. The study will be double-masked, and participants will be randomly assigned to either the control or treatment arm. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board.

This study aims to investigate the effect of CYP2B6 genotype and multiple doses of efavirenz on the disposition and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine in healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine will be determined after a single dose of methadone and tizanidine in the morning with 250 ml drinking water. In phase 2, the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine will be determined after 16-day oral treatment with 600 mg/day efavirenz. The study will be conducted in an open-label, two-period, fixed sequence design. The study will be conducted in healthy volunteers who are judged healthy without any significant medical condition as determined by and decided from a pre-enrollment screening session that include medical history, laboratory tests such as blood and urine tests, vital signs, and an electrical tracing of the heartbeat (electrocardiogram, EKG). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study aims to evaluate serum magnesium levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients. The study will be conducted on two groups: cases and control. The cases group will undergo a diagnostic test for magnesium, while the control group will also undergo the same test. The study will last for one year. The primary outcome measure will be the percentage of serum magnesium levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients.

The study aims to investigate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on serum IGF-1 and IL-6 levels in elderly patients with sarcopenia. The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Ophiochepalus striatus extract) or the control group (placebo). The study is designed to measure the primary outcome measures of IGF-1 and IL-6 levels at 2 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include SARC-F score, muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical performance. The study is designed to investigate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on sarcopenia in elderly patients.

=========

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility of using a digital therapeutic mobile app, the 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program, for improving patients' pain self-management and function who suffer from chronic pain. The study will conduct a 2-arm randomized control feasibility study to evaluate the feasibility of using the mobile app and an optional activity tracker, the feasibility of conducting a 2-arm trial, and estimate the effect size for planning for a larger efficacy trial based on primary outcomes. The intervention arm will test a mobile app that aims to help people reduce pain interference who have chronic pain, as well as mental health issues with depression and anxiety. Participants in the intervention arm will also have the option to sense health data with a tracker that integrates with the app, which will inform the feasibility of this feature. The study will measure the primary outcome of pain interference using the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale - Short Form 6b and secondary outcomes of depression and anxiety using the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 (GAD-7) at baseline, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after enrollment (and start of intervention in the intervention arm).

The study aims to compare the microbial colony counts of removable retainers in wet and dry storage conditions. The study will also compare the surface roughness, colour stability, and compressive strength of removable retainers in wet and dry storage conditions. Additionally, the study will evaluate the OHRQoL of participants storing their removable retainers in dry and wet conditions. The study will use a randomized crossover design, with participants being randomly assigned to one of four groups: Hawley retainers in dry storage condition, Hawley retainers in wet storage condition, vacuum-formed retainers in dry storage condition, and vacuum-formed retainers in wet storage condition. The study will recruit 24 participants who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria and will follow them for 6 months. The primary outcome measure will be the microbial colony counts of removable retainers in wet and dry storage conditions, and the secondary outcome measures will be the surface roughness, colour stability, compressive strength, and OHRQoL of participants storing their removable retainers in dry and wet conditions. The study will use SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 26.0 to analyze the data, and statistical significance will be set at p < 0.05.

The study is a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design at eight sites throughout the US, specifically recruiting sites and individuals who are Black, Latino, Indigenous and Native American, and individuals living in rural areas of the country. The goal of the new model is to improve food security and quality of life in patients 60 years and older from key vulnerable populations with greatest social and economic need by providing continuity of nutrition care for malnutrition treatment across settings. The study will compare the usual care process with no referral to the new model which includes a referral and nutrition care in the community using a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design. The study will have two distinct portions: the clinical component, which includes patient identification, effective cross-referrals, and enhanced data reporting and transfer to the community partner, and the community component, including enhanced nutrition care and reporting including both MNT and MTM. The study will have a total study duration of 35 months. Patient recruitment will occur within all 5 periods for a total of 1120 patients and at a rate of approximately six to seven patients per month per site. The study will have a primary objective to test the feasibility of a patient identification, cross-referral, data reporting, and communication (including data transfer) process from an acute care hospital to a community meal provision organization. The study will also have two secondary objectives: to increase the rate of patients older than 60 years of age with malnutrition receiving care (MNT, MTM) in the community setting and to improve food security, determinants of malnutrition, and quality of life in persons older than 60 years of age discharged from the hospital with a diagnosis of malnutrition. The study will use a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design at eight sites throughout the US, specifically recruiting sites and individuals who are Black, Latino, Indigenous and Native American, and individuals living in rural areas of the country. The study will have a total study duration of 35 months. Patient recruitment will occur within all 5 periods for a total of 1120 patients and at a rate of approximately six to seven patients per month per site. 1,3-Butanediol is a dietary supplement that has been shown to increase circulating ketone bodies. This study aims to investigate the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with chronic heart failure. The study will use a randomized crossover design, with participants receiving either 1,3-butanediol or placebo. The primary outcome measure will be cardiac output, as measured by LVOT VTI and HR, at 6 hours. Secondary outcome measures will include stroke volume, heart rate, LVEF, changes in circulating 3-OHB, and changes in FFA.

===============

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of subpectoral bupivacaine for pain management in adolescent reduction mammaplasty. The study will recruit 120 patients aged 13-21 years who are undergoing bilateral reduction mammaplasty at Connecticut Children's from 1/1/2022-12/31/2025. Patients will be randomized into either the study group (receiving intraoperative subpectoral bupivacaine) or the control group (will not receive subpectoral bupivacaine). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain score, which will be patient-reported on a rating scale of 1-10. Secondary outcome measures include narcotic use, length of stay in post-anesthesia care unit, and return to full activity. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks post-operatively.

* Radiation: Pencil Beam Scanning Proton Therapy
* Intervention: Spot Delete technique in proton therapy
* Primary Outcome Measure: Reduction in Radiation Dermatitis
* Secondary Outcome Measure: linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam
* Study Duration: 3 years
* Study Type: Supportive Care
* Study Design: Single Group Assignment
* Study Purpose: To measure skin reactions during proton therapy for 100 patients over a period of three years.

The study is a multicenter, non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation using a GnRH antagonist protocol in women undergoing IVF. The study includes 1000 infertile women aged 20-42 years old who are planning to undergo IVF/ICSI pregnancy treatment. The study is designed to measure the cumulative live birth rate through study completion, an average of 18 months. The study is double-blinded, and the participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (generic cetrorelix acetate) or the active comparator group (reference cetrorelix acetate). The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

This is a phase 1 study of peposertib (M3814) and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin (Doxil®) in patients with metastatic leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of peposertib in combination with low-dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride (liposomal doxorubicin) as evaluated by the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) rate at each tested dose level. The study will also determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of liposomal doxorubicin and peposertib combination and determine the maximal tolerated dose (MTD) if identified. The study will obtain a more precise determination of adverse events (e.g. dose limiting toxicities estimate at the selected dose). The study will assess the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and liposomal doxorubicin used in combination with each other. The study will estimate the objective response rate (ORR) per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1 in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin. The study will estimate the progression free survival (PFS) in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin. The study will test the hypothesis that soft tissue sarcomas (STS) with homologous recombination deficiency (HRD) like leiomyosarcomas (LMS) will be more susceptible to deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin. The study will test the hypothesis that gammaH2AX and pNBS1 can be used as pharmacodynamic biomarkers of response to DNA-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.
