The SPARROW trial is a multicenter, randomized controlled, superiority trial that compares perioperative versus preemptive antibiotic treatment during five postoperative days after pancreatoduodenectomy in patients with a high risk for contaminated bile. The primary endpoint is the rate of clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infections (OSIs) within 90 days after surgery requiring a therapeutic intervention. Secondary endpoints include the rate of isolated OSIs, wound infections, postoperative pancreatic fistula, bile or enteric anastomotic leakage, post pancreatectomy hemorrhage, delayed gastric emptying, bacteremia, Clostridium difficile infection, major morbidity (Clavien-Dindo ≥III), reintervention, ICU admission, length of hospital stay, readmission, and in-hospital and 90-day mortality. The study is designed to evaluate the additional value of preemptive antibiotic treatment on clinically relevant OSI in patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy with a high risk for contaminated bile. The study population includes adult patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy with a high risk for contaminated bile (patients with preoperative biliary drainage or an ampullary malignancy). The intervention includes perioperative prophylaxis (cefazolin, metronidazole, and a single dose of 5-7mg/kg gentamicin) or additional cefuroxime and metronidazole for five postoperative days. The study is expected to recruit 304 evaluable patients.

* KRAS G12C mUtation: KRAS G12C mutation detected through local next-generation sequencing analysis.
* KOSMOS-II observational master study: Patients who have consented to participate in the KOSMOS-II observational master study.
* Sotorasib: Oral sotorasib.
* Panitumumab: IV Panitumumab.
* RECIST v1.1: Lesions that have not experienced disease progression after radiation therapy are excluded.
* ECOG performance status: Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0 to 2.
* Adequate bone marrow and organ function: Bone marrow: Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) ≥ 1,500/mm3, Platelet count (PLT) ≥ 100,000/mm3, Hemoglobin (Hb) ≥ 9 g/dL. Liver Function: Total bilirubin ≤ 1.5 X upper limit of normal (ULN). If liver metastasis is present, total bilirubin up to ≤ 3 X ULN is allowed. For patients with Gilbert's syndrome, total bilirubin up to ≤ 3 X ULN and direct bilirubin within the normal range is allowed. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) ≤ 3 X ULN (or ≤ 5 X ULN if liver metastasis is present). Renal Function: Creatinine clearance ≥ 30 mL/min/1.73m2 (using the Cockcroft-Gault formula). Estimated life expectancy of at least 3 months according to the investigator's judgment. Ability to take oral medications. Understanding and compliance with the clinical trial protocol and ability to provide informed consent by signing the informed consent form.

The study aimed to investigate the effects of different nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening on postoperative nutritional status of patients with gastrointestinal cancer. The study included 302 patients with gastrointestinal tumors admitted to the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023. The patients underwent nutritional risk screening after admission and were divided into intervention group (NRS2002≥3 and PG=SGA≥4, n=204) and control group (NRS2002 < 3 or PG=SGA < 4 , n=98) according to the screening results. The intervention group received different nutritional interventions, and the control group received routine nutrition support. The study measured the changes of various nutritional indexes of patients before and after nutritional intervention. The results showed that the intervention group had significant improvements in nutritional risk screening 2002, dietary energy intake, dietary protein intake, nutrient energy intake, nutrient protein intake, prealbumin, albumin, hemoglobin, BMI, fat-free weight, walking time, grip strength, and other nutritional indicators compared with the control group. The study also found that the intervention group had a significant improvement in nutritional risk screening 2002, dietary energy intake, dietary protein intake, nutrient energy intake, nutrient protein intake, prealbumin, albumin, hemoglobin, BMI, fat-free weight, walking time, grip strength, and other nutritional indicators compared with the control group. The study aims to compare the effect of the Abutment-Prosthesis Connection on Marginal Bone Loss and Gingival Sealing Around Dental Implants. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study includes two arms: Experimental and Active Comparator. The Experimental arm receives the Connect® device, while the Active Comparator arm receives the Multi-unit device. The study measures the primary outcome of Marginal bone level and secondary outcomes of Peri-implant microbiome and Peri-implant inflammation. The study is designed to measure the effect of the Abutment-Prosthesis Connection on Marginal Bone Loss and Gingival Sealing Around Dental Implants.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical feasibility of the measurements from a non-invasive ultrasound patch in comparison to a conventional transcranial Doppler probe on 60 participants. The study will measure the blood flow spectrum of different arterial segments including middle cerebral artery, anterior cerebral artery, posterior cerebral artery, vertebral artery, basal artery, internal carotid artery, and ophthalmic artery. The agreement of these two devices on peak systolic velocity, mean flow velocity, and end diastolic velocity of the measurements will be evaluated using the Bland-Altman plot. The study will run for 1.5 years.

* Hemodiafiltration (HDF) is a treatment for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) that uses a semipermeable membrane to remove waste products from the blood.
* Endogenous reinfusion is a process in which the waste products removed during HDF are returned to the body.
* The study aims to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxins by HDF with endogenous reinfusion in maintenance hemodialysis patients.
* The study will measure the concentrations of β2-microglobulin (β2-MG), indoxyl sulfate and λ-free light chain (λFLC) before and after HDF.
* The study will also measure the single-compartment urea clearance index (spKt/V), Urea Reduction Ratio, other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic including α1-MG, κFLC, Hcy, IL-6, p-cresol, YKL-40, CFD, leptin, hippuric acid, TMAO, ADMA, TNF-α, myoglobin, FGF23 and iPTH, serum albumin, branched chain amino acids and vitamins A, C, E before and after HDF, and the comfort of HFR treatment.

This is a phase III, randomized, controlled, open-label, multi-center clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab as adjuvant therapy in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma and high-risk recurrence factors after liver transplantation. The study includes 180 patients, who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm (multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab) or the control arm (no adjuvant therapy). The primary outcome measure is the one-year recurrence-free survival rate (1-year RFS rate), while secondary outcome measures include recurrence-free survival (RFS) duration, overall survival (OS), two-year and three-year RFS rates, graft survival, and quality of life evaluation. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 3 years, with participants being followed up for a minimum of 12 months. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy in preventing disease recurrence and improving graft survival in patients with high-risk hepatocellular carcinoma after liver transplantation.

The study aims to study the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver. The study is a single center, open label, randomized controlled trial with a study period of 1 year. The primary outcome measure is the change in clotting time in both groups. The secondary outcome measures include changes in inflammatory parameters, endothelial dysfunction, pulmonary function, renal function, adverse effects of human albumin solution, duration of hospital stay, and mortality at 28 days. The study will be conducted at the Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, New Delhi. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Ethics Committee. The study will be registered with the Clinical Trials Registry of India (CTRI).

=================

This is a prospective study that enrolled 65 patients with potentially operable non-small cell lung cancer without driving gene EGFR/ALK mutation in stage III. The study aimed to evaluate the significance of MRD monitoring in patients with potentially resectable stage III non-small cell lung cancer. The patients were followed up for 2 years according to the standard diagnosis and treatment path, with a total of 9 times of follow-up, all of which were 3-month follow-up plan of the standard diagnosis and treatment path, and the follow-up examination was conducted in accordance with clinical standards. The primary outcome measure was disease-free survival (RECIST) and the secondary outcome measures were overall survival, the prediction of recurrence by positive MRD, pCR rate of MRD-negative patient, negative MRD rate in pCR patients, and 2-year DFS of ctDNA-negative patients in operation group / inoperable group. The study used tumor-informed personalized monitoring MRD test kit for 1021-MRD analysis.

The study is a single center prospective cohort study comparing ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The study aims to determine the proportion of patients meeting the RASS sedation score within 24 hours and the dosage of propofol or ciprofol during sedation, the dosage of norepinephrine during sedation, the duration of mechanical ventilation, the incidence of adverse events, the length of ICU stay, and the mortality rate. The study will be conducted in a single center and will recruit 100 patients who are treated with vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure ≥65 mmHg, require sedative medication for comfort, safety, and to facilitate life support measures, and obtain informed consent. The study will be conducted over a period of 28 days.

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial in single blind, in two parallel arms, in ratio 1:1, of superiority. The trial compares laparoscopy plus laparotomy versus laparotomy alone. Children will be randomized into 2 groups: Laparoscopy + laparotomy group Laparotomy group The main objective is to evaluate the inflammatory response Day 2 postoperative in preterm infants with ECUN who have undergone surgery. The main criterion is the evolution of the blood C reactive protein level between Day 0 and Day 2 postoperatively. This is a randomized controlled trial of hair removal in the axilla for women, comparing intense pulsed light to diode laser. The study will have 4 sessions of treatment, totaling 4 treatments, with a follow-up at 30 days and 6 months after the end of the treatment. The armpits will be cleaned with 0.5% alcoholic chlorhexidine and shaved with a disposable razor blade. Neutral water-based gel will be applied to the region to receive the treatment. Patients will be instructed not to perform any trichotomy procedures in the region during the research period. The treatment technique will be punctual where the applicator will be kept in full contact with the skin at 90° and moved to the next point after deposition of energy over the entire treatment area until the defined energy is delivered. The applicator tip will be cooled as much as the equipment allows. The primary outcome measures are hair count and global aesthetic improvement scale (GAIS), while the secondary outcome measures are hair thickness, pain score (visual analogue scale), quality of life (WHOQOL-bref), satisfaction level score, and self-esteem scale. The study will be double-masked and randomized, with participants assigned to two groups in parallel for the duration of the study.

===============

The PROMISE-BD-100 study aims to assess plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels every hour from admission to 48 hours after onset in patients with acute ischemic stroke due to a large- or medium-vessel occlusion. The study will determine the responsiveness of plasma BD-tau to brain injury after onset and evaluate whether BD-tau plateaus at different time points after onset indicating no further infarct progression. The primary outcome is the evolution of BD-tau levels in acute ischemic stroke, characterized by the time point when plasma BD-tau levels start to rise after onset, the type of rise, and until when plasma BD-tau levels continue to rise. Secondary outcomes include functional outcome at 90 days and 7 days after onset, early recurrent ischemic stroke, secondary intracerebral hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic transformation. The study will be conducted in a specialized stroke service in patients admitted with acute ischemic stroke due to large- or medium-vessel occlusion within 9 hours of symptom onset. Eligibility criteria include a clinical diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke, large- or medium-vessel occlusion confirmed by CT or MRI angiography, and written informed consent. Exclusion criteria include CT or MRI showing intracranial hemorrhage upon admission, a history of ischemic stroke, subarachnoid hemorrhage, intracerebral hemorrhage, subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, CNS tumor, meningitis, or encephalitis within the last three months, severe renal dysfunction (eGFR < 30ml/min/1.73m2), dementia, and pre-stroke disability defined as a premorbid modified Rankin Scale score > 1. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of artificial intelligence in accelerating the learning curve for mastering contrast-enhanced ultrasound of thyroid nodules. The study is a randomized controlled trial with three arms: training set, internal test set, and external test set. The training set includes patients with thyroid nodules underwent contrast-enhanced ultrasound and ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration during January 2018 and December 2020 in Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital Sun Yat-sen University. The internal test set includes patients with thyroid nodules underwent contrast-enhanced ultrasound and ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration during January 2021 and May 2023 in Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital Sun Yat-sen University. The external test set includes patients with thyroid nodules underwent contrast-enhanced ultrasound and ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration during January 2022 and June 2023 in Houjie Hospital of Dongguan and Central People's Hospital of Zhanjiang. The primary outcome measures are the area under the curve, the number of cases, and the cases time. The study is expected to be completed in June 2023.

The study aims to investigate the ability of different stimulus encoding methods to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks in visual prosthesis patients. The study will involve basic experimental studies involving humans (BESH) designed to quantify the perceptual experiences of retinal and cortical prosthesis patients. The investigators will produce visual percepts in CORTIVIS and Argus II patients either by directly stimulating electrodes (using FDA-approved pulse trains), or by asking them to view a computer or projector screen and using standard stimulation protocols (as is standardly used for their devices) to convert the computer or projector screen image into pulse trains on their electrodes. Informed by psychophysical data and computational models, the investigators will test the ability of different stimulus encoding methods to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks (e.g., object recognition, navigation). These encoding methods may include computer vision and machine learning methods to highlight important objects in the scene or to highlight nearby obstacles and may be tailored to each individual patient. Performance of prosthesis patients will be compared both across stimulus encoding methods and to performance in normally sighted control subjects viewing stimuli manipulated to match the expected perceptual experience of prosthesis patients. The normal method of stimulation is a chain from a camera mounted on eye glasses through a video processing unit (VPU) which converts the video image into FDA-approved electronic pulse trains. Sometimes the investigators will test subjects using the camera. More often, the investigators will carry out 'direct stimulation' when using an external computer to directly specify pulse trains (e.g., send a 1 s 10 Hz cathodic pulse train, with a current amplitude of 100 microAmps and a pulse width of 45 microseconds to Electrode 12 of an Argus II implant). Important parameters for safety include a) pulses must be charge-balanced (an anodic pulse must be followed quickly by a cathodic pulse and vice versa or the electrode will dissolve), b) charge density should be limited. The frequency of the pulse train and the current amplitude of the pulse train is not actually a critical safety issue, since the electronic/neural interface is robust to extremely high rates of stimulation and high current levels. However, high frequency pulse trains or high amplitude pulse trains can produce dis

=========

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound surveillance in detecting nodal metastasis in patients with primary high risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. The study will recruit patients with BWH stage T2a tumors in patients who are on chronic immunosuppression, BWH stage T2b or T3 tumors with a negative CT of the nodal basin and a negative SLNB, and BWH stage T3 tumors with a negative CT of the nodal basin. The study will use ultrasound surveillance every 6 months and regular visits every 3 months throughout the duration of the study (2 years). The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with nodal metastasis, and the secondary outcome measures are the number of participants with local recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma, disease-specific death, and overall survival rate.

The study aims to investigate the salivary biomarkers of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) in infants. The study will be conducted in two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group will consist of infants with symptoms of GER or GERD and undergoing 24-hour esophageal MII-pH. Saliva samples will be collected during the execution of the MII-pH of the esophagus 24 hours, at defined time points, at least 2 hours after the last meal, so as to study the circadian variations of their composition. The control group will consist of healthy infants from whom it will be taken a single saliva sample during a health assessment. The primary outcome measure will be the prevalence of GERD in a cohort of infants with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux. Secondary outcome measures will include identifying any differences in the biochemical profile (pepsin and pepsinogen concentration, electrolyte concentration, such as sodium and HCO3-) of saliva samples collected from healthy, GER and GERD patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years.

=======

The NAMELS-18 study is a prospective, open-label, observational study conducted in two hospitals in Greece. The study aims to compare the effect of Empagliflozin and Dulaglutide on liver fat fraction in diabetic patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) after one year of treatment. The study includes 120 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: Empagliflozin, Dulaglutide, or control. The primary outcome measure is the change in liver fat fraction as calculated by magnetic resonance imaging-proton density fat fraction (MRI-PDFF) after 52 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in HbA1c, body mass index (BMI), Fatty Liver Index (FLI), Fibrosis-4 Index (FIB-4), Aspartate Aminotransferase to Platelet ratio Index (APRI), NAFLD Fibrosis Score (NFS), and shearwave elastography (SWE) after 52 weeks of treatment. The study is expected to be completed in 2022.

=============

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to assess the feasibility of surgical exposure of palatally impacted upper canines with open-eruption technique using a surgical template. The study compares this method with the conventional free-hand surgical exposure. The primary outcome measure is the success of the intervention, while the secondary outcome measures include the success of the open eruption technique, surplus costs of surgical planning and manufacturing the surgical guide, duration of the surgical intervention, postoperative pain, and intra- and postoperative complications associated with surgery. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with single masking. The participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group (palatally impacted canine exposure using a surgical template) or the control group (palatally impacted canine exposure using the conventional free-hand method). The study is conducted at the Department of Community Dentistry, Semmelweis University, and includes patients between the ages of 11-18 who need surgical exposure and orthodontic eruption of their palatally impacted canines on one or both sides during their orthodontic treatment. The study is expected to be completed in an average of 1 year.

===============

The CAVEAT trial is a feasibility study that aims to determine if the manualized, brief psychotherapy CAVEAT can be administered to violence-exposed mothers and their young children in the ambulatory care center of a Swiss public hospital. The study will recruit 12 participant-dyads and will implement and check the procedures related to recruitment, inclusion, retention, questionnaire completion, and interviews. The primary outcome measure is treatment satisfaction questionnaire, and the secondary outcome measures are parenting stress questionnaire-short form and maternal attributions rating scale. The study will be conducted as an open-trial feasibility study with interim and post-treatment measures of patient and therapist satisfaction and patient-therapist therapeutic alliance and agreement on treatment goals and realization of treatment objectives.

=========

The HAPPY STUDY is a 1-year randomized controlled trial with a 3-year follow-up period. The study aims to assess the efficacy of a holistic lifestyle digital intervention in reducing the risk of Type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes in Asian women and their children with a history of gestational diabetes. The intervention focuses on diet, physical activity, sleep, and mental well-being. The study will measure changes in glucose tolerance, anthropometric measurements, blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, HbA1c, cortisol, DNA profiling, gut microbiota, total body water, extracellular and intracellular fluid volumes, depression, anxiety, health status, sleep, lifestyle, and social-emotional development in children. Eligible participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group and will receive the assigned intervention for 1 year, followed by a 3-year follow-up period.

=========

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of dry heat and dry cold application on pain, anxiety, and fear levels before blood sample collection in school-age children. The study includes three groups: control group, dry heat application group, and dry cold application group. The intervention is applied for 5 minutes in the dry heat application group and 3 minutes in the dry cold application group. The primary outcome measure is the Wong Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale, and the secondary outcome measures are the Child Fear Scale, Child Anxiety Scale, and Medical Procedures Fear Inventory. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and is approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

===============

This is a phase I clinical trial that assesses the safety profile of chemoreduction with intra-arterial melphalan, followed by ruthenium brachytherapy, performed in patients that would otherwise need enucleation due to tumor size. The study enrolls patients with clinically diagnosed choroidal melanoma with tumor thickness equal to or greater than 8.00 mm. IAC with 7.5 mg of melphalan will be performed through selective catheterization of the ophthalmic artery followed by Ru-106 plaque brachytherapy 4±1 weeks after the IAC. All patients will be followed up with baseline and subsequent B-scan ultrasonography, SD-OCT studies, color fundus pictures, infrared photographs, and electroretinograms (ERG). The primary outcome measure is determination of treatment safety through ERG exams at baseline, 1, 3, and 6 months after the first intervention. The secondary outcome measures include reduction of tumor size, best corrected visual acuity (BCVA), signs of intraocular inflammation, treatment-related adverse events, and globe salvage.

=================

The study aims to determine the incidence of trauma in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia, during the first semester of 2023. The study will be an observational retrospective trial, and the participants will be patients admitted to the emergency ward by trauma. The study will measure the number of patients dead, the number of days in hospitalization, the number of patients needing ICU, the number of days in ICU, the number of patients needing mechanical ventilation, and the number of days in mechanical ventilation. The study will be conducted in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia, and will be an observational retrospective trial. The study will be conducted in the first semester of 2023.

The LSS-NIPT study is a feasibility study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a non-invasive postural therapy (NIPT) for older adult veterans with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS). The study will recruit 20 participants who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomly assigned to the experimental group. The experimental group will receive DME and training to support continuous maintenance of flexion posture during the 6-week trial. The study will measure changes in mobility by actigraphy as the primary outcome measure. The study will be conducted at a single site and will be open label. The study will be conducted over a 6-week period.

=========

A Pilot Study to Assess Effects of Self-Administered Nitrous Oxide (SANO) on Urodynamic Study (UDS) Parameters

The study is a pilot study to assess the effects of self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) on urodynamic study (UDS) parameters. The study will consist of two runs, with SANO and oxygen given through a mask during each run. The study will assess bladder capacity, intra-UDS pain and anxiety, post-void residual, max flow rate, detrusor overactivity, and detrusor pressure at maximum flow. The study will be randomized and will have a crossover assignment. The study will be conducted in healthy volunteers aged 21 to 85 years old who are scheduled for UDS and have no medical conditions that would impede the study. The study will be conducted in an ambulatory setting.

=========

This study aims to investigate the relationship between Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs), attachment styles, resilience, psychological and quality of life outcomes in women in remission from breast cancer. The study includes an exploratory biological ancillary study that aims to identify the gene expression variations that are determinant in terms of vulnerability/protection (cytogenetic and transcriptome), through the measurement of the level of biological chronic stress and epigenetic methylations of the NR3C1 and FKBP5 genes, in relation to adversity in childhood. The primary outcome measure is quality of life assessed with the Short Form Survey 12 (SF-12 scale). Secondary outcome measures include fear of recurrence, fatigue, anxiety and depression, attachment relationships, resilience, and resting RMSSD values. The study includes women in remission from breast cancer who are over 18 years of age, literate, and agree to participate in the project and sign the informed consent form. The study is designed as a cross-sectional study with an average of 1 year follow-up.

===============

The study aims to assess the real-world effectiveness of the DiscoveryTM AI-assisted polyp detector system in clinical practice and compare the results between expert and non-expert endoscopists. The study is a single-center crossover trial. The participants are adults ≥45 years old who are referred for screening colonoscopy and have adequate bowel preparation. The intervention is a diagnostic test of HD-colonoscopy assisted by AI. The primary outcome measures are adenoma detection rate (ADR) and polyp detection rate (PDR). The secondary outcome measure is adenoma miss rate (AMR). The study will assess the diagnostic performance of the AI-assisted system by sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values (PPV and NPV) and observer agreement. The study will be conducted for up to three years.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness and mechanism of the low glycemic index (LGI) diet in pregnant people with epilepsy. The study will be a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with an experimental group on the LGI diet and a control group on the standard diet. The primary outcome measure will be the tolerability of the LGI diet in pregnant people with epilepsy, while secondary outcome measures will include seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolic pathway alterations. Participants will be pregnant up to 20 weeks gestational age and will be invited to participate in the study. The study will be conducted in the Brigham & Women's Epilepsy-Obstetrical clinic.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a web-based decision support system (DSS) and machine learning web application in promoting adherence to oral anticancer treatments among a sample of 100 metastatic breast cancer (MBC) patients over a three-month period. The DSS, named TREAT (TREatment Adherence SupporT), is a patient-centric approach and comprises four sections: i) Metastatic Breast Cancer; ii) Adherence to Cancer Therapies; iii) Promoting Adherence; iv) My Adherence Diary. The machine learning web-based application focuses on predicting patients' risk factors for adherence to anticancer treatment, specifically considering physical status, comorbid conditions, and short- and long-term side effects. The study measures adherence by calculating the number of pills taken divided by the prescribed amount and identifies clinical factors, psychological parameters, and QoL variables that serve as predictors for patients' adherence to OATs. The study is designed as a 3-month randomized controlled study conducted at the European Institute of Oncology (IEO).

The study aims to investigate the effects of melatonin on glycemic parameters, cardiovascular disease risk factors, bone metabolism markers, and quality of life in peritoneal dialysis patients. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, quadruple-masked, placebo-controlled trial. The study will recruit 100 peritoneal dialysis patients with a BMI below 35 and will be conducted over 10 weeks. The primary outcome measures will include serum concentrations of lipoprotein-a, malondialdehyde, high sensitivity c-reactive protein, soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1, fasting glucose, pentosidine, carboxy-methyl lysine, procollagen 1 intact N-terminal propeptide, osteoprotegerin, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b, receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-Β ligand, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, triglyceride, total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, kidney disease quality of life index, Beck depression test, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures will include serum concentrations of albumin, calcium, phosphorous, and intact parathyroid hormone. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Rome "La Sapienza".

The study is a single-center, prospective, observational study that aims to optimize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) by using a device that incorporates an integrated phosphorylcholine-coated oxygenation system. The study will measure the primary outcome of oxygen delivery values calculated with the CONNECT software using CPB output and hemoglobin values, as well as secondary outcomes of postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) and delirium assessed by CAM-ICU, CPC, and mRS scores. The study will be conducted at the university hospital of Lille, France, and will include patients aged over 18 who are scheduled for elective cardiac surgery under CPB, have given written consent, and are insured under the French social security system. Exclusion criteria include pregnant or breastfeeding patients, off-pump cardiac surgery, lack of DO2 monitoring, emergency surgery, and uncontrolled sepsis. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 28 days postoperative.

The study aims to investigate the changes in skin surface temperature of the lumbar region during auricular acupressure at the kidney point on healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted in two groups: AA-SA and SA-AA. The AA-SA group will receive auricular acupressure on the left ear, followed by sham auricular acupressure on the right ear. The SA-AA group will receive sham auricular acupressure on the left ear, followed by auricular acupressure on the right ear. The study will measure the change in temperature of the left and right lumbar regions during the procedure. The study will also assess the proportion of auricular acupuncture side effects.

The aim of this study is to compare the different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary by-pass (CPB) in cardiac surgery interventions. The MAP will be maintained in the range of values of each study arm. The patients enrolled to elective cardiac surgeries will be evaluated during a pre-operative outpatient visit and widely informed about the chance to participate in the study. When patients undergo to the elective surgery general anaesthesia is administered and CPB is installed. The nominal flow for each patient will be 2,4 l/min/m2. To keep the MAP values around those corresponding to the randomized group, vasodilator (if MAP overcomes the assigned MAP value) or vasoconstrictor drugs will be used (if MAP value is lower than the assigned group). The following drugs will be used: nitroglicerine at incremental dose of 0,01 mcg/kg/min for a vasodilator effect and norepinephrine at incremental dose of 0,01 mcg/kg/min for a vasoconstrictor effect. The primary outcome measure is the serum lactate peak (Lmax) (mmol/l) detected during CPB. The secondary outcome measures are the area under the curve (AUC) of the serum lactate values measured during CPB, number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB, evaluation of intraoperative cerebral perfusion (through monitoring of NIRS), intraoperative pulmonary perfusion (through Pa/Fi ratio, paO2, paCO2 at ABG and VO2R and DO2 of CDI), evaluation of intraoperative and postoperative low cardiac output syndrome (through the calculation of VISmax), postoperative and 30-day LVEF (%) and evaluation of pulmonary injury (through the LIS).

The study is a prospective observational study of the acute and subacute effects of furosemide in patients with acute heart failure. After inclusion, 80 mg of furosemide is administered IV. Measurements include blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, pulmonary fluid content, ultrasound examination of heart and lungs, and assessment of cardiac filling pressures with doppler and strain analysis. Measurements are repeated at several time points until 6 hours have passed. The primary outcome is change in pulmonary fluid content after administration of furosemide.

The study is a national randomized controlled trial that aims to prevent binge drinking behavior among university students aged 18-25 years old with an AUQ score of 24 or higher and an AUDIT score of 3 or higher for its first 3 items. The intervention is a smartphone application that includes biological measurements of phosphatidylethanol (PEth) through blood microsampling. The study measures the change in the number of standard drinks per week and PEth concentration over a period of 30 months. The study is non-randomized, with participants being assigned to either the experimental group (binge drinking with blood microsampling) or the active comparator group (binge drinking-control with blood microsampling). The study is designed to measure the primary outcome of change in the number of standard drinks per week and secondary outcomes of change in PEth concentration over a period of 3 months to 30 months.

The study aims to evaluate the potential benefit of nitazoxanide in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. The study includes 35 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus who are receiving treatment with metformin and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (such as vildagliptin). The experimental group receives nitazoxanide 500 mg orally twice daily in addition to metformin and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (such as vildagliptin). The primary outcome measure is glycemic control, measured by fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin. Secondary outcome measures include insulin resistance, lipid profile, serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1, and serum levels of asprosin. The study will run for 12 weeks.

The study aims to investigate clinical risk factors of autism and to elucidate the changes in gut microbiome in Egyptian autistic children and their possible correlation with clinical outcomes and the severity of the disease. The study will use a case-control design, with autistic children aged between 3-9 years as the cases and healthy children of the same age as the controls. The study will collect stool samples from the participants and analyze the intestinal microbiome and metabolome. The primary outcome measure will be autism clinical risk factors, which will be assessed through prenatal, natal, and postnatal history. The secondary outcome measures will be intestinal microbiome and metabolome analysis. The study will be conducted over a period of one year. The study will use a case-control design, with autistic children aged between 3-9 years as the cases and healthy children of the same age as the controls. The study will collect stool samples from the participants and analyze the intestinal microbiome and metabolome. The primary outcome measure will be autism clinical risk factors, which will be assessed through prenatal, natal, and postnatal history. The secondary outcome measures will be intestinal microbiome and metabolome analysis. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

===============

The study aims to develop an internet-based self-help money management program to improve financial self-efficacy and its associated adverse outcomes among adult population with severe mental illness. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with participants being randomly assigned to either the money management group or the waitlist control group. The money management group will receive a 4-week program consisting of key components of money management and the Model of Human Occupation (MOHO), while the waitlist control group will wait for 4 weeks before receiving the program. The primary outcome measures will include changes in financial self-efficacy, financial behaviour, financial attitude, and financial well-being on various scales. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in psychological wellbeing, anxiety symptom, depressive symptom, and quality of life on various scales, as well as treatment adherence and satisfaction at the interview after the post-intervention assessment.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of START (Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy) in enhancing upper extremity function post-stroke. The study will be a randomized, single-blind, parallel, controlled trial evaluating the impact of START on training outcomes of a functional reaching task in individuals with stroke. The primary outcome measures will be change in EMG (electromyography) onset, change in EMG amplitude, change in movement onset, change in movement linearity, change in functional reaching task scores, and change in sorting task scores. The secondary outcome measures will be retention in functional reaching task scores and retention in skill transfer. The study will be conducted in individuals with severe-to-mild upper extremity impairment, corrected pure tone threshold (octave frequencies 250-4000 Hz) norms for their age and gender, and capacity to provide informed consent. The study will be conducted in individuals with stroke at least 6 months prior to testing. The study will be conducted in individuals aged 18 years and above. The study will be conducted in individuals with hearing aids. The study will be conducted in individuals with severe concurrent medical problems. The study will be conducted in individuals with acute/painful condition/injury of upper extremity/spine that interfere with ability to participate. The study will be conducted in individuals with severe stroke survivors. The study will be conducted in individuals with mildly disabled patients. The study is a prospective monocentric study on hyperinflated COPD patients without collateral ventilation. Patients were evaluated before and 3 months after unilateral ELVR by transdiaphragmatic pressure (Pdi) measured at the functional residual capacity (FRC) after magnetic phrenic stimulation and by high-resolution computed tomography at the FRC allowing 3D modelling of the diaphragm for measurements of fibers length, length of the zone of apposition and radius of curvature of the diaphragmatic domes. The primary outcome measures are the difference in diaphragmatic function, assessed by the transdiaphragmatic pressure, before and 3 months after unilateral valves setting and the change of the diaphragm conformation, by measuring diaphragmatic fibers length in several planes, diaphragmatic area and radius of curvature, before and 3 months after unilateral ELVR.

=========

The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the clinical performance of three bulk-fill resin composites (Fill-Up, QuiXfil, and Tetric N-Ceram Bulk Fill) in Class ӀӀ restorations over a 2-year period. The study includes 120 participants with at least three permanent molars and premolars that need to be treated with Class II restorations due to primary carious lesions. Participants must have a full and normal occlusion and maintain adequate oral hygiene. The study measures the esthetic, functional, and biological properties of the restorations using FDI criteria. The study finds that all three bulk-fill resin composites have similar clinical performance in Class ӀӀ restorations over a 2-year period.
177Lu-DOTATATE Retreatment Trial

=========

The study aims to compare the effects of Mulligan Techniques versus McKenzie Extension Exercises for chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The study will be conducted at Rehab Care and Jinnah Hospital Lahore, from 1st June - 31st January 2024. The study will include 32 patients, 16 in each group, who will be randomly assigned to either Mulligan Techniques or McKenzie Extension Exercises. The study will use the Visual Analogue Scale, Oswestry Disability Scale, and lumbar Range of Motion as assessment tools. The study will be conducted for four weeks, with two sessions per week and a single session per day. The results will be analyzed using SPSS 29 and presented as mean and standard deviation for numerical variables. The study will compare the pain reduction and range of motion between the two groups.

===============

A Phase 2, multicenter, long-term, open label extension trial is being conducted to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents with achondroplasia. The study will roll over participants from previous TransCon CNP clinical trials. The primary outcome measures are safety and tolerability, and height Z-scores. Secondary outcome measures include annualized growth velocity. The study will run for an average of 10 years.

This study aims to explore the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study is an observational study that uses correlation analysis and mediation analyses to assess the mediating effects of self-efficacy, coping, depression and anxiety on the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study measures the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation using the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12). The study is designed to measure the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks.

===============

The LORENA Trial is a study that aims to evaluate the success rate of local excision for organ preservation in early rectal cancer with no adjuvant treatment. The study will recruit patients with rectal cancer diagnosed with clinical staging cT1N0M0, with the inferior edge of the tumour not further than 2 cm above the anorectal ring. The intervention will be transanal local excision, and the primary outcome measure will be the success rate of patients with no need of Total Mesorectal Excision after follow-up. Secondary outcome measures will include morbidity rate, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictor rate, and radical rescue surgery specimen quality. The study will be conducted over a period of 36 months, with data entry done at baseline, after surgical procedure, and at different follow-up periods. The study will be hosted online through the REDCap system, and data will be collected using a database. The study will be conducted in accordance with the 2013 Fortaleza's update of the Helsinki Declaration and each participant's country law.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of the center volume-outcome relationship and that on mortality which remain poorly understood. The study will evaluate whether precise risk stratification can provide better patient counseling and be used for unit-surgeon benchmarking. The study will investigate outcome predictors in patients undergoing surgery for TAAD, including clinical and perioperative variables as well as follow up beyond 15 years. The study will use a multicenter registry design and will include four arms: Ascending Aorta Replacement (AAR) with or without Hemiarch Repair, Ascending Aorta Replacement (AAR) with Aortic Root Replacement (ARR), Ascending Aorta Replacement with Total Arch Replacement (TARP), and Extensive Root and Ascending Aorta Replacement with Total Arch Replacement. The primary outcome measures will include Operative Mortality (OM), Rate of mesenteric ischemia, Rate of permanent Neurologic Deficit (PND), Rate of composite of Major Adverse Events (MAE), Rate of perioperative Myocardial Infarction (MI), Rate of acute heart failure (AHF), Rate of Transient Neurologic Deficit (TND), Rate of spinal Cord Injury (SCI), Rate of acute kidney injury, Rate of perioperative bleeding, Reoperation for bleeding, Rate of mechanical circulatory support, Rate of composite of Major Adverse Pulmonary Events (MAPE), and Rate of reintervention. The study will follow patients for 18 years.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the effects of virtual reality (VR) on academic stress and academic performance in physiotherapy and nursing students of the University of the Balearic Islands. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with two experimental groups and a control group. The experimental groups will receive either a 4-week program with VR-guided visualization or a 4-week program with traditional guided visualization. The control group will receive no intervention. The primary outcomes will be the intra-group and between-group changes in academic stress and perceived stress from the last month. Secondary outcomes will include between-group differences in the level of stress, arterial tension, maximal heart rate, and salivary cortisol level just before exams, as well as between-group differences in exam qualifications. The study will be conducted in Spanish and will be open to physiotherapy and nursing students of the University of the Balearic Islands who are enrolled in at least 80% of their usual academic course during the year of the study and have no previous experience in guided visualization to cope with stressful situations. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks, with participants receiving either the VR-guided visualization or traditional guided visualization program twice per week. The study will be double-masked, and participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of the Balearic Islands.

=================

The study compares the use of remimazolam and propofol as anesthetic induction agents for morbid obesity patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study with a single masking design. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension event during anesthesia induction. The study requires 44 subjects in each group, with a dropout rate of 10%. The study will use a modified intention-to-treat group analysis and report excluded cases with the exclusion reasons. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers.

This is an observational cohort study using MRI to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function and liver endpoints in children with CF aged 6 to 11 years. The study will use a modified version of the protocol used in the GIFT-CF3 study (NCT04618185) to measure GI physiology in addition to MRI measures of lung and liver structure and function. The aim is to identify whether these measures are changed before and after starting ETI. For the CF participants, to be enrolled in the study they must be homozygous or have at least 1 copy of the Phe508del mutation, which would mean they are eligible for ETI treatment. The modified MRI protocol, taken from NCT04618185, has been shortened to include scans that are taken over three timepoints. These timepoints are determined around the ingestion of a test meal which has been previously described. Participants will arrive fasted before having a baseline scan. After their first scan they will eat their first standardised high fat meal followed by a second standardised high fat meal around 240 minutes after. MRI scans to assess GI function will be taken at baseline (fasted), 240 minutes post ingestion of a breakfast meal (T240) and 300 minutes post breakfast (T300). Liver scans will also be taken at baseline and lung scans taken opportunistically at the T240 timepoint. In total, participants will be asked to remain in the MRI scanner for approximately 30 minutes at a time. For comfort, participants will be able to watch multimedia programmes through the use of a specially adapted television while in the scanner. Participants will also be asked to complete validated gastrointestinal questionnaires throughout the study day and recall their GI symptoms over the previous 2 weeks and complete a 3 day food diary. The study will be split into two phases. The first will be a pilot phase where 3 children with CF aged 6 to 11 years and 3 healthy age and gender matched controls undergo MRI scanning. These scans will be assessed to determine whether the scan protocol can be completed by the participants and assess the quality of the images obtained.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of the addition of hemodiafiltration to ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) on the regeneration of marginal donor lungs. The study is a prospective randomized pilot study. The intervention group receives EVLP with HDF, while the control group receives EVLP without HDF. The primary outcome measure is the suitability for transplantation of the lungs after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF. The secondary outcome measures include survival assessed at 12 and 24 months, length of mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, length of hospital stay, and lung function parameters (MEF50) at 1, 3, 6, 12, and 24 months after transplantation. The study is designed as a parallel assignment, with no masking. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the University Hospital of Zurich. The study is registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT02750558).

A Modified Calculation Formula for Meibomian Gland Grading is a study that aims to compare the effectiveness of two different formulas for grading Meibomian Gland Dysfunction. The study will include participants aged 18 to 80 who do not have a history of eye surgeries, systemic health conditions affecting ocular health, or contact lens wearers. The study will use two different formulas for grading Meibomian Gland Dysfunction: the previous calculation formula and the modified calculation formula. The primary outcome measures of the study will be the area of the Meibomian Glands and the whole eyelids, as well as the WTW distance of the cornea. The study will be conducted at baseline, once a subject has enrolled in research.

The study is a single-blind randomized clinical trial (RCT) to evaluate the efficacy of a medical device based on zinc gluconate in preventing oral mucositis in subjects undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The study will be conducted in two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm will receive the medical device based on zinc gluconate, while the active comparator arm will receive a solution based on sodium chloride and bicarbonate. The primary outcome measure will be the occurrence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcome measures will include the time of oral mucositis onset and the severity of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. The study will be conducted in subjects with a diagnosis of head and neck cancer undergoing local radiotherapy for curative or adjuvant purposes, who are able to self-apply the product. The study will be conducted in subjects aged 18 years or older, regardless of sex. The study will be conducted in subjects who do not have any contraindication to the components of the investigational product, neurological or psychiatric conditions that may influence the ability to self-apply the treatment, or participation in other clinical studies.
