The study aims to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study is a cross-sectional clinical study that includes 100 participants. The participants are categorized according to the 2018 classification of periodontal diseases, including healthy, gingivitis, treated periodontitis (stable/unstable), periodontitis Stages I & II, and periodontitis Stages III and IV. The primary outcome measure is the combination of C-reactive protein (CRP), triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 (TREM-1), interleukin (IL)-1beta, metalloproteinase (MMP)-8, IL-10, IL-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), Macrophage Inflammatory Protein-1 Alpha (MIP-1), interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), osteoprotegerine (OPG), Receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa B ligand (RANKL), Tumor Necrosis Factor-Alpha (TNF-alpha). The secondary outcome measures include age, gender, Hb1Ac, Finn-risk, blood pressure, patient's temperature, habits, plaque index, bleeding on probing, suppuration on probing, probing depth, recession, radiographic bone loss, and microbiological analyses. The study is a pilot study.

The study is a cross-sectional clinical study that aims to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study includes 100 participants who are categorized according to the 2018 classification of periodontal diseases. The primary outcome measure is the combination of C-reactive protein (CRP), triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 (TREM-1), interleukin (IL)-1beta, metalloproteinase (MMP)-8, IL-10, IL-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), Macrophage Inflammatory Protein-1 Alpha (MIP-1), interferon-gamma (IFN-

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a dual-hormone artificial pancreas system (dHmG) versus a single-hormone system with rescue carbohydrate recommendations (sHC) in preventing/mitigating hypoglycemic events during an unannounced exercise session and meal challenge in adults with type 1 diabetes. The study will be conducted in a highly supervised, controlled, randomized clinical trial with a crossover design. The primary objective is to determine whether the dHmG configuration outperforms the sHC configuration in terms of minimizing the time spent below the target range (70-180 mg/dL) and the number of hypoglycemic events. The study will be conducted in a highly supervised, controlled, randomized clinical trial with a crossover design. The primary objective is to determine whether the dHmG configuration outperforms the sHC configuration in terms of minimizing the time spent below the target range (70-180 mg/dL) and the number of hypoglycemic events.

=========

The study aims to determine the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. The study is a randomized controlled experimental design with a sample of 84 infants with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks. The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or the music that the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure. The pain of the infants before, during, and after the procedure was measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS). Also, the duration of the procedure and the crying time were evaluated.

===============

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of two training/supervision models for clinicians providing Caregiver Skills Training (CST) to parents of children with developmental disabilities and/or autism. One group will receive training and supervision remotely, while the other will receive training and supervision in-person. Both groups will receive 15 hours of training and 12 weeks of supervision. The study will measure changes in caregiver skills and knowledge, parenting stress, adaptive behavior skills, and social communication abilities from baseline to week 12. The study will also assess caregiver adherence and competence using the Caregiver Diary.

=================

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (tES) in the functional recovery of subjects with subacromial pain syndrome (SPS). The study will be a randomized, triple-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Participants will be recruited through social media and posters placed in primary care centers, hospitals, and other related locations. The study will include 64 subjects with unilateral shoulder pain. The intervention will consist of 24 sessions of transcranial direct electrical stimulation (tDCS) and therapeutic exercises. The primary outcome measures will be changes in pain and disability index (SPADI), spanish version, scale, changes in western ontario rotator cuff (WORC), spanish version, scale, and changes in a visual analogic scale, for the measurement of the shoulder intensity of pain. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in shoulder muscle strength, changes in shoulder active range of movement, changes in joint position sense, changes in head forward posture, changes in subacromial space width, changes in scapulohumeral rhythm, changes in mean signal amplitude of the scapulothoracic muscles, changes in signal frequency of the scapulohumeral muscles, changes in mean signal amplitude of the primary motor cortex, and changes in head forward posture, shoulder protraction and kiphosis. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Valencia.

===============

This study was designed to retrospectively determine any association between hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and change in verbal scores in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). All children aged 2 to 17 years, diagnosed with ASD who completed a verbal test every six months (either Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program or the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills), received applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center (ORC) were screened for inclusion, some of whom had elected to receive HBOT (at least 40 sessions for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA). The study measured the verbal scores of children with ASD who underwent HBOT and compared to those who did not using an age appropriate assessment. The primary outcome measure was the change from baseline of verbal scores at 6 months. The study also collected data on the number of participants with HBOT related adverse events.

===============

The study is a comparative randomized double-blinded study that aims to compare the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block (ACB) versus 4 in 1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study will measure the postoperative pain score using numerical rating scales (NRS) at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours postoperative. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in blood pressure and heart rate, as well as postoperative opioid requirements. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will involve patients who are scheduled to undergo knee surgeries under neuroaxial anesthesia. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the hospital's ethics committee.

The study aims to determine whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction with lymphatico-venous anastomosis can reduce the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study is a prospective randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and non-intervention. The experimental arm includes breast cancer patients receiving axillary lymph node dissection and immediate lymphatic reconstruction, while the non-intervention arm includes breast cancer patients receiving only axillary lymph node dissection. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of arm lymphedema, which will be measured at two years. Secondary outcome measures include drainage amount, seroma or lymphocele, patient reported outcome measures by LYMPH-Q Upper Extremity Module, and occurrence of subclinical lymphedema. The study is designed to measure the prevention of arm lymphedema.

===============

This is a descriptive study of the cosmetic and functional sequelae of patients who received releasing incisions in the management of acute upper limb burns. The study includes adult patients with hand burns that required releasing incisions and were hospitalized at the Pierre Colson Burn Center. The primary outcome measures include functional score, healing assessment, burn VAS, QuickDASH Score, and scar quality. The study measures functional recovery at 3 months and 6 months after the burn, healing time, scar quality, and burn VAS at 3 and 6 months. The study is designed to assess the functional and aesthetic criteria of patients who received releasing incisions in the management of acute upper limb burns.

The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study: Providers Learning About Nutrition Together (PLANT) is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a flexible, multimodal WFPBD educational program for 6 weeks for providers at Stanford in any department. The study measures changes in Diet ID score, mindset about WFPBD, and state of change (motivation/confidence) from baseline to week 6. The intervention includes interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities including movies, recipes, and websites.

The study aims to validate a questionnaire patient reported outcome (PRO) in patients with early breast cancer. The PRO questionnaire survivorship concerns is made up of 17 items which evaluate the problems of survival, the level of concern about problems related to the care of patients, screening, symptom management, family and genetic problems and the fear of disease recurrence, on a scale of 0 to 3. The study will be conducted in two phases. During the transcultural adaptability phase, 80 representative patients will be recruited. During the validation phase, previous patients will be included and more other patients will be included (at least 280). The PRO questionnaire survivorship concerns will be administered twice 15 days apart and in order to identify the levels of agreement between the two assessments, the Interclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) model 3.1 will be applied and calculated for each item. The study aims to put in evidence rehabilitation needs in breast cancer patients in early stage.

============

A Postpartum Adaptation Study of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) Program is a single group assignment, open label study designed to treat postpartum depression, postpartum anxiety, parenting stress, and parent-child relationships. Participants will enroll in a 12-session CARE parenting group therapy. The primary outcome measures include change from baseline to post-treatment in postpartum anxiety score, postpartum depression score, parenting stress score, parental reflective functioning, parent-infant bonding, and post-treatment rating of treatment acceptability and feasibility. Secondary outcome measures include change from baseline to post-treatment in infant temperament.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effects of EEG-NFB training on cognitive function in healthy young men. The study will use a randomized, two-arm repeated measures control design. The experimental group will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training, while the control group will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures will include TMT-A and TMT-B, which are used to assess cognitive processing speed and executive function, respectively. ST-I and ST-II will also be used to measure processing speed and selective attention and inhibition, respectively. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the ethics committee of the University School of Physical Education in Wroclaw.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study aims to compare the efficacy of endovascular thrombectomy via radial approach versus endovascular thrombectomy via femoral approach in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function (defined as mRS score ≤ 3) at 90 days post-operation. The secondary outcome measure is procedure time of the endovascular thrombectomy at the operation 1 day. The study is designed to include patients with acute ischemic stroke in the posterior circulation confirmed by symptoms and imaging examinations. Basilar artery occlusion confirmed by computed tomographic angiography (CTA), magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), or digital subtraction angiography (DSA). Age ≥ 18 years. Time from symptom onset to randomization within 24 hours of the estimated time of basilar artery occlusion. Baseline NIHSS score ≥ 10 before randomization. Intact dual circulation of the hand assessed by the modified Allen's test. Written informed consent from patients or their legally authorized representatives. Exclusion criteria include pre-stroke disability with mRS score ≥ 3, pregnancy or lactation, allergies to contrast agents or nitinol devices, participation in other clinical trials, systolic blood pressure > 185 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure > 110mmHg, known genetic or acquired bleeding diathesis, lack of coagulation factors; or oral anticoagulant therapy with INR > 1.7. Baseline lab values: blood glucose < 50mg/dL (2.8mmol/L) or > 400mg/dL (22.2 mmol/L), platelet count < 50*109 /L, or hematocrit < 25%. Life expectancy less than 1 year. Lost to follow-up within 90 days (e.g. no fixed residence, overseas patients, etc.). Acute ischemic stroke within 48 hours after percutaneous coronary intervention, cerebrovascular intervention, or major surgery (patients can be included if more than 48 hours). Clinical

The BUNDLE study is a prospective mixed-methods study focused on the early integration of community doulas into prenatal care. The investigators will pursue the following aims using a multidisciplinary team of experts in health disparities, community engagement, qualitative research, maternal-fetal medicine, and doula support: Aim 1: Develop an integrated prenatal care model of medical providers and community doulas in Southeastern Wisconsin Approach: The investigators will conduct six focus groups with 30 Black/AA birthing people (currently pregnant or recently postpartum) and 30 prenatal healthcare providers (obstetricians, midwives, doulas, social workers, prenatal care coordinators, nurses, mental health providers, and obstetric unit leaders) to elicit feedback on models of doula/medical provider integration with the overarching aim of building trust and improving maternal health outcomes. Focus group findings will be reviewed with a community advisory panel (CAP) developed as part of the Community Partnership of the MCW U54 center, to gain the CAP's input on intervention development. Aim 2: Compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement and trust and reducing adverse maternal outcomes Approach: In a two-arm randomized controlled trial conducted at Froedtert and MCW, the investigators will randomize 412 Black/AA pregnant people to BUNDLE or standard prenatal care. Primary outcome is healthcare engagement (starting prenatal care in 1st trimester, attending at least 70% of the recommended visits, attending the postpartum visit, and receipt of recommended vaccination during pregnancy). Secondary outcomes include medical mistrust measured by trust in provider scale, perceived discrimination, and frequencies of severe maternal morbidity as defined by the Centers for Disease Control. Aim 3: Disseminate findings to scholarly and community-based forums and actively pursue opportunities for systems- and policy-level change Approach: The investigators will disseminate findings regularly in scholarly (conference, grand rounds) and community-based (listening session, town hall) forums. The investigators will leverage the existing partnerships with policymakers, healthcare organizations, and community leaders to

=============

This was a 3-arm randomized controlled trial, parallel-group study with blind outcomes assessor. The study aimed to compare the effects of connective tissue massage and classical massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The intervention duration was uniform across all groups: 4 consecutive weeks, with 3 sessions per week lasting 15-20 minutes per session. Outcome measurements were taken at the beginning and 4 weeks after the completion of the program. An independent physiotherapist, unaware of the research details and participant groupings, conducted the evaluations. The study adhered to the ethical principles of the Helsinki Declaration and the CONSORT guidelines for rigorous reporting.

This study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study comparing the clinical outcomes of OMNI canaloplasty alone versus OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent in patients with bilateral mild to moderate open-angle glaucoma undergoing uncomplicated cataract surgery. The study will enroll 80 subjects aged 18 years and older. The study will last approximately one year and will include approximately seven study visits to the study center and two visits to the surgery center. The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include reduction in the number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure and percentage of patients with greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline.

This is an open-label, randomized, controlled, comparative efficacy and safety study of Dorzotimol eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL (JGL dd, Croatia), vs. Cosopt eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL (Merck Sharp & Dohme, France) in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The primary endpoint was mean IOP change from baseline on visit 5 comparing with visit 0. Secondary endpoints included IOP reduction rate to the target level of ≤ 18 mm Hg, IOP reduction rate greater than 20%, and IOP reduction rate greater than 30%. The study was conducted in 110 patients with primary open-angle glaucoma. The results showed that Dorzotimol eye drops were noninferior to Cosopt eye drops in terms of mean IOP change from baseline, IOP reduction rate to the target level of ≤ 18 mm Hg, IOP reduction rate greater than 20%, and IOP reduction rate greater than 30%. The study also demonstrated that Dorzotimol eye drops were safe and well tolerated.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of text messaging in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy in veterans at a VA hospital. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label pilot study. Participants will receive a series of instructional and motivational text messages leading up to the colonoscopy procedure. The primary outcome measure is the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score, which assesses participant satisfaction with the Annie text intervention. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of participants who attend scheduled colonoscopy appointments and have adequate bowel preparation at colonoscopy appointments. Eligibility criteria include having previously undergone a colonoscopy and being due for a repeat screening or surveillance colonoscopy at the VA. Exclusion criteria include patients not due for screening or surveillance colonoscopy, those with personal history of colorectal cancer/inflammatory bowel disease/hereditary colon cancer syndrome or family history of hereditary colon cancer syndrome, and those with ICD9/10 codes or medical record indicating these criteria. The study is designed for participants aged 45-85 years old and accepts all sexes.

===============

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arms, parallel therapeutic clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. The study aims to compare the efficacy of the two techniques in terms of uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery, as well as the rate of complications, use of second-line surgical management, synechiae, and fertility at 2 years after surgery. The study will include 110 patients in each arm, who will be randomized on the morning of the procedure. The primary endpoint will be the uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery, which will be compared between the two arms using a Chi-square test or a Fisher's exact test. Secondary endpoints will include the rate of complications, use of second-line surgical management, synechiae, and fertility at 2 years after surgery, which will also be compared between the two arms using a Chi-square test or a Fisher's exact test. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the participating centers.

The study aims to investigate the ability of humans to make inferences about the environment based on past experiences. The study will use an online crowdsourcing platform to recruit participants who meet certain criteria, such as being fluent in English and living in the US. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: short-term inference, long-term inference, or multi-timescale inference. In the short-term inference group, participants will be shown a pair of jars filled with the same absolute number but different ratios of red/blue balls and will be asked to identify which jar is currently in use. In the long-term inference group, participants will be shown a pair of jars filled with the same absolute number but different ratios of red/blue balls and will be asked to predict the subsequent jar in use on the next trial, where jar switches are correlated across trials. In the multi-timescale inference group, participants will be shown a pair of jars filled with the same absolute number but different ratios of red/blue balls and will be asked to both report the current jar and predict the subsequent jar, combining the short and long-term inferences. Participants will draw balls as many times as they wish with replacement during the short-term and multi-timescale blocks but will know the current jar in use for long-term inference. The primary outcome measure will be binary behavioral decision responses, which will be collected through subject-provided choices on the computer. The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with no masking.

The study is an N of 1 trial for adults with early onset dementia and insomnia. The study will evaluate the effectiveness and safety of lemborexant as a sedative medication for insomnia in adults living with both early onset dementia and insomnia. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks with treatment alternating between lemborexant and placebo in an ABBABAAB format. The primary outcome measures will include total sleep time, sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, number of night awakenings, and quality of sleep. Secondary outcome measures will include the presence and severity of adverse drug reactions and drop-out due to adverse events.

* Sinomenine is a traditional Chinese medicine used to treat osteoarthritis.
* Glucocorticoid is a commonly used drug for the treatment of osteoarthritis.
* The study aims to compare the efficacy of sinomenine and glucocorticoid in the treatment of early knee osteoarthritis.
* The study will be conducted as a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial.
* Participants will be randomly assigned to either the sinomenine group or the glucocorticoid group.
* Participants will receive one intra-articular injection every 4 months.
* The primary outcome measure will be the change in the total WOMAC score from baseline and whether sinomenine is noninferior to glucocorticoid.
* The secondary outcome measure will be the change in time from baseline in the Timed Up and Go test and whether sinomenine is noninferior to glucocorticoid.
* The study will be conducted for 24 months after the first injection.

=============

This study is a single-blind pre-test post-test parallel group randomized controlled experimental design to determine the effect of breathing exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety and quality of life in COPD patients. The study will be conducted in a sample of 48 patients, 24 in the experimental and 24 in the control group. The intervention will be applied in the research, investigator blinding will not be possible, and it is planned to blind the participants. The study will evaluate the research data with the SPSS 26 package program. The primary outcome measures are oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, forced vital capacity (FVC), volume of air exhaled in 1 second of forced expiration (FEV1), peak expiratory flow rate (PEF), FEV1/FVC, COPD Evaluation Test (CAT), Modifiye Medical Research Council (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), St George Respiratory Questionnaire and Virtual Reality Experience Evaluation Form. The study will be conducted in the center of Ardahan.

The study aims to understand the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women. The study will use a biobehavioral approach that includes lab-based assessments and a 10-day free-living monitoring period with mobile and wearable devices. The primary outcome measures will include macrovascular function, arterial stiffness, and blood flow measurements in large and cerebral blood vessels. Secondary outcome measures will include physical activity level. The study will recruit 100 Black women aged 18-49 years old who are not currently pregnant, own a smartphone with internet access, and are able to speak and read English. Participants will be excluded if they have been diagnosed with hypertension, cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic, and/or neurological disorders; have functional limitations or health issues that preclude physical activity; are currently taking medications for thyroid function or psychological conditions such as depression, anxiety, and mood disorders; have regularly smoked within the last 2 years; or have been diagnosed with asthma. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period.

=============

This is a phase 2, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel, study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in the treatment of drug-induced moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms in breast cancer subjects. The study will enroll 100 female subjects aged 20 years or older with a confirmed diagnosis of breast cancer who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy and are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors for at least 8 weeks at baseline and will maintain the same treatment regimen and dose throughout the study. Participants will be randomized to receive either 0.8 mg RCN3028 or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the mean change in frequency of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms from baseline to weeks 4 and week 12, and the mean change in severity of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms from baseline to weeks 4 and week 12. Secondary outcome measures will include the menopause specific quality of life questionnaire, the 50%, 75%, and 100% responder rates, the time to onset of efficacy, subject's and physician's global assessment, frequencies of subjects with treatment-emergent adverse events, change from baseline in weekly weighted severity score, change from baseline in the number of mild, moderate, and severe hot flashes, and change from baseline in the number of nighttime awakenings because of hot flashes.

* Retrospective cohort study
* Cardiovascular surgery
* Tranexamic acid
* Post-operative delirium
* Richmond Agitation Sedation Score
* 30 day mortality

=============

The study aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion and functional disability in chronic nonspecific neck pain. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a sample size of 30 participants. The intervention group received myofascial decompression therapy, while the control group received positional release therapy. The primary outcome measure is the Numerical Rating Scale (NPRS) for pain intensity, and the secondary outcome measures include the Neck Disability Index (NDI) for functional disability and range of motion (ROM) for cervical spine flexion, extension, side flexion, and rotation. The study is expected to be completed in 6 weeks, and the results will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and inferential statistics.

===============

A randomized parallel-controlled study was conducted to compare the ileostomy dumpling suture method with the traditional suture method in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study included 100 patients who were randomly assigned to either the experimental group (ileostomy dumpling suture method) or the control group (traditional suture method). The primary outcome measure was the complication rate of stoma, which was assessed on day 30 after surgery. Secondary outcome measures included the stoma DET score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma. The study found that the ileostomy dumpling suture method had a lower complication rate of stoma and a higher stoma DET score compared to the traditional suture method. However, there was no significant difference in the stoma pain score and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma between the two groups.

===============

The study aims to assess the progression in cognitive and associated activities of daily living impairment in Parkinson's disease. The study will include a detailed neuropsychological test battery, including the Pfeffer Activities of daily living scale, and will assess global and domain-specific cognitive performance. The study will also assess motor and non-motor impairment in Parkinson's disease. The study will be conducted over a period of 6-8 years and will include both baseline and follow-up assessments. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

The study aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study includes three arms: age range of 18 to 44 years olds, age range of 45 to 59 years olds, and age range of 60 to 80 years olds. The study measures the appearance of myofibrillation. The study is designed to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study includes three arms: age range of 18 to 44 years olds, age range of 45 to 59 years olds, and age range of 60 to 80 years olds. The study measures the appearance of myofibrillation. The study is designed to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine.

=================
This study aims to investigate the effects of dietary phospholipids on measures of human brain health and psychological wellbeing. Participants will be randomly allocated to either a treatment group or a placebo group and will receive 12 weeks' worth of either 40g per day of bioactive whey protein concentrate powder containing dairy phospholipids or a similar amount per day of matched placebo powder. Participants will complete a battery of cognitive and mood assessments at baseline, 6 weeks, and 12 weeks. Blood samples will also be taken at baseline and 12 weeks to measure changes to plasma phospholipid profiles.

The study aims to investigate the presence of environmental pollutants in human carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with the plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes. The study will enroll 300 consecutive patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy for high-grade internal carotid artery stenosis. Plaque specimens will be obtained from atherectomy and will be analyzed for volatile organic compounds and microplastics through pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, transmission electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry, ELISAs, and Western Blot. The study will compare the expression of inflammatory and plaque stability markers between patients with polluted plaques and non-polluted plaques. The primary outcome will be the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality in patients with polluted vs non-polluted plaques. The study will also explore the relationship between the burden of microplastics and the outcome.

The study aims to compare the mean effective tumor doses of patients with or without response to radioembolization for colorectal cancer liver metastasis. The study will investigate dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after transarterial radioembolization.

The study will include patients who are over 18 years old, have histopathologically proven colorectal cancer diagnosis treated with radioembolization for liver metastases with Y90 glass microspheres in lobar or segmental fashion, and have follow-up data at least 6 months after radioembolization. The study will exclude patients who have no PET-CT, CT or MR of the liver within last 6 weeks prior to radioembolization, no PET-CT, CT or MR of the liver 2-4 months after radioembolization, poor image quality, and previous local treatment or surgery for the liver.

The study will use the Therasphere device for transarterial radioembolization. The primary outcome measure will be the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose, which will be compared between patients with or without response to radioembolization for colorectal cancer liver metastasis. The secondary outcome measure will be the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after transarterial radioembolization. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months after treatment.

* Clinical Evaluation of Chemically Cured Conventional Glass Ionomer After Light Emitting Diode Radiant Heat Enhancement
* A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial
* High Caries Risk Patients
* Intervention/Treatment: chemically cured conventional glass ionomer restorative (Ketac Universal Aplicap) enhanced with light-emitting diode radiant heat
* Primary Outcome Measures: Clinical performance of biological properties and Clinical performance of Functional properties
* Study Plan: Randomized, Parallel Assignment, Triple Masking

The FAPO-X study aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF). The study was conducted at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo (InCor - HCFMUSP) and was divided into six phases. The first phase involved outpatient preoperative care, the second phase focused on hospitalization and informed consent, the third phase involved surgical care, the fourth phase focused on postoperative care, the fifth phase involved a 30-day telemonitoring period, and the final phase involved an outpatient visit. The telemonitored group used the Samsung Galaxy smartwatch for remote monitoring, while the control group followed standard care protocols. The primary outcome measures were rehospitalization rate, scheduled consultations, and extra occurrences. The secondary outcome measures were technological adherence, treatment adherence, and use of the mobile application by patients. The study aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with POAF.

=========

The study is a pilot study of information and communication technology solutions for hypertension care. It is a randomised controlled trial where patients with hypertension will be randomised either to one of the two digital solutions or to standard care. The study aims to test whether the adoption of HSMonitor solutions by healthcare professionals and patients improves the management of patients with high blood pressure. The two solutions are referred to as Solution 1 - HSmartBPM (developed by a supplier consortium led by GNOMON) and Solution 2 - HyperHealth (developed by a supplier consortium led by TECH4CARE). The study measures changes in blood pressure and user satisfaction measured with VAS. The study is planned to be carried out within the framework of the EU project HSMonitor - Pre-commercial Procurement of innovative ICT-enabled monitoring to improve health status and optimize hypertension care (Grant Agreement Nr. 856698).

=================
The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study that aims to screen individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder for liver disease. The study includes participants who are attending outpatient treatment for alcohol use disorder at Novavi Køge or Novavi Roskilde and provide informed written consent. Participants are randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which receives an invitation to a liver stiffness measurement (Transient Elastography), blood sampling, and a leaflet on alcohol-related disease, or the control group, which receives an invitation to screening by blood sampling with Fib-4. The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence or light consumption (≤ 10 units/week) the last 30 days, assessed 6 months since randomization. Secondary outcome measures include heavy drinking days last 30 days and change in AUDIT-C score since randomization. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with double masking.

The study aims to evaluate the value of trio exome sequencing in the etiological assessment of specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders. The study will include 20 families with positive results and 10 families with negative results. The primary outcome measure will be the identification of a genetic cause defined by the presence of at least one ACMG class 4 or 5 variant. The study will be conducted in parallel assignment with no masking. Blood samples will be collected during blood sampling for array CGH, and consultation for results delivery will be offered at 4 months. An interview will be offered to 20 families with positive results and 10 families with negative results. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University Hospital of Geneva.

===============

The Five Days for Health (FDH) program is a small group-based lifestyle modification program aimed at weight loss for adults with a BMI between 25-45 who are motivated to change their lifestyle. The program involves five days of education and practical workshops on nutrition, daily physical activity, and psychological support, with follow-up continuing for one month, three months, six months, and after a year. Participants are encouraged to stay in contact between meetings using an instant messaging platform. The program helps participants make healthier food choices by acquiring knowledge of nutrition basics and meal planning, and participants wear accelerometers to track their physical activity. The program is led by a multidisciplinary team of endocrinologists-diabetologists, a nutritionist, a psychologist, and a kinesiologist. The primary outcome measure is weight loss, with secondary outcome measures including body composition and metabolic parameters.

=================
A phase 1 study of Bio-008 in subjects with advanced solid tumors. The study is designed to evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and antitumor activity of Bio-008 in subjects with advanced solid tumors. The study is divided into two parts: dose escalation and dose expansion. The dose escalation part is designed to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of Bio-008. The dose expansion part is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Bio-008 at the MTD. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study is registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03711528).

=================

The study aims to determine the effect of different music played on the pain and comfort level of premature babies during the retinopathy examination. The study is a randomized controlled trial with three arms: Experimental: Experiment 1 (Rainstick) and Experimental: Experiment 2 (Music-The Happiest Baby), and No Intervention (Control). The study will be conducted on premature infants with a corrected/postnatal age of 28-36 weeks at the time of examination, who have not given sedative, opioid and anticonvulsant drugs before/during the examination, and whose parents do not have diagnosed mental or mental problems and agree to participate in the research. The study will measure the pain and comfort level of the infants using the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) and will record the baby's birth weight, birth week, current weight, corrected week, and delivery type. The study will be conducted in a hospital in Turkey.

============

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of Sovateltide in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke. The study is a multicentric, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical study. The study will be conducted in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, and Europe. The study will enroll 200 patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke who are aged between 18-80 years and have a NIHSS score of 8-20 and NIHSS Level of Consciousness (1A) score < 2 at the time of screening. The study will be conducted over a period of 90 days. The primary outcome measure will be the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 90 post randomization. The secondary outcome measures will include the proportion of patients with an excellent functional outcome with mRS score of 0-1 on day 90 post randomization, the proportion of patients with National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score < 6, mRS ≤ 2, Barthel Index (BI) score > 60 on day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization, the change in NIHSS score ≥ 6, mRS score > 2, and BI score ≥ 40 from baseline to day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization, the proportion of patients with overall clinical outcome as assessed by the global statistical test of NIHSS, mRS, and BI scores at day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization, the change in Quality-of-life (QoL) as assessed by EuroQol-EQ-5D and by Stroke-Specific Quality of Life (SSQOL) at day 30, day 60, and day 90 post-randomization, the proportion of patients with recurrent ischemic stroke within day 30 and day 90 post-randomization as assessed by Questionnaire to Validate Stroke-Free Status (QVSFS), the number of deaths within 90 days post-randomization, and the proportion of patients with radiographic or symptomatic Intra

This study is an ambispective cohort study that aims to investigate the prognosis and its influencing factors of Borderline Personality Disorder. The study will follow up patients with BPD for 2 years after the first follow-up, and the primary outcome measure is the remission rate of BPD. The secondary outcome measures are social disability and quality of life. The study will use ICD-10 (F60.3) to diagnose BPD, and the Social Disability Screening Schedule (SDSS) and WHOQOL-BREF to assess social disability and quality of life, respectively. The study will use Cox Proportional Hazard Model to analyze the influencing factors of remission of BPD, and Generalized Estimating Equation Model to analyze the influencing factors of the patients' social function and quality of life. The study will be conducted by senior psychiatrists who received training on the use of questionnaires and inter-investigator consistency before the follow-up.

=========

This study aims to assess the management of dry eye disease by combining intense pulsed light (IPL) and diquafosol eye drops. The study will enroll participants with bilateral signs and symptoms of dry eye disease, including an Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI) questionnaire score of 13 or higher, a non-invasive tear break-up time (NITBUT) of 5 seconds or less, and a conjunctival staining score (CS) of 3 points or higher. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: IPL+DQS, IPL, or DQS. The IPL+DQS group will receive IPL sessions and DQS eye drops for four weeks, while the IPL group will receive IPL sessions and the DQS group will receive DQS eye drops for four weeks. The primary outcome measures will include changes in non-invasive tear break-up time (NIBUT), Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI), fluorescein and lissamine conjunctival and corneal staining (CFS), meibomian gland function and secretion quality, Tear Film Lipid Layer Score (TFLL), tear meniscus height (TMH), and conjunctival hyperemia (RS score). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in tear production, corneal epithelial integrity, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the institutional review board.

=============

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two different mental health interventions, CBT versus MBT, to improve patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depression. The study will also explore patient characteristics that may moderate the relationship between CBT or MBT and patient outcomes, and compare implementation outcomes of acceptability and feasibility of CBT relative to MBT as reported by patients and clinicians using mixed methods. The study will use a randomized, parallel assignment design with a 9-week MBT program and a 12-18 session CBT program. The primary outcome measure will be change in anxiety and depression symptoms using the Patient Health Questionnaire Anxiety-Depression Scale (PHQ-ADS). Secondary outcome measures will include change in mental health, psychiatric diagnosis, quality of life, well-being, self-acceptance, functional impairment, disability, potential negative effects of intervention, intervention services satisfaction, and intervention therapist and therapy satisfaction.

The IMPACT 2.1 study is a phase 2, open-label, single-arm study evaluating the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in patients with immune related arthritis or arthralgias. The study will enroll patients who have previously been on hydroxychloroquine treatment as standard of care therapy or enrolled in IMPACT 2.0 who develop recurrent grade 2 or higher irAA, or who remain on glucocorticoids for irAA at 3 months. Patients will receive methotrexate 20 mg PO weekly for 12 weeks, folic acid 1mg PO daily for as long as methotrexate is given, and prednisone starting at 20 mg PO daily for 8 weeks tapering dose. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients who are able to discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA. Secondary outcome measures include total steroid usage, development of immune related adverse events other than irAA, adverse events, and re-initiation of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. The study will also assess progression free survival. The study will enroll patients who are 18 years of age or older, capable of providing consent to enrolment and treatment, and have a performance status of ECOG 0-2. Patients with a history of inflammatory arthritis, including rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome, ankylosing spondylitis, or other chronic inflammatory arthritis, are not eligible. The study will be conducted over a total study observation period of 3 years.

The study aims to compare the effects of general and regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients planning total hip arthroplasty. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial. Patients will be allocated to either the general anesthesia group or the regional anesthesia group. The primary outcome measure will be subjective sleep quality, evaluated by PIRS-20 (Pitssburg Insomnia Rating Scale). Secondary outcome measures will include subjective anxiety and pain levels. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

===============

This is a Phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese subjects with episodic migraine. The study will enroll 200 participants aged 18-80 years with a 1-year history of migraine and 4-14 migraine days per month in the 3 months prior to screening. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three atogepant doses or placebo and will be followed for 24 weeks. The primary outcome measure is change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in the 3-month average of monthly migraine days, change from baseline in migraine specific quality of life questionnaire, version 2.1 (MSQ v2.1) role function-restrictive domain score, and change from baseline in mean monthly performance of daily activities domain score of the activity impairment in migraine-diary (AIM-D).

The study is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barré Syndrome. The study will include 100 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Efgartigimod) or the active comparator group (Intravenous Immunoglobulin). The primary outcome measure is the Guillain-Barre Syndrome Disability Scale (GBS-DS) at 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures include the GBS-DS at 4, 24, and 48 weeks, as well as the Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS), Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS), Forced Vital Capacity (FVC), Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (MIP), and Maximal Expiratory Pressure (MEP). The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years.

=============

A Phase 2B, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, dose-ranging study to evaluate the virological response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adults with COVID-19. The study includes 4 arms: low dose, medium dose, high dose, and placebo. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level, and secondary outcome measures include the incidence of treatment-related adverse events, serious adverse events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, and discontinuations. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adults with COVID-19.

===============

The study is a prospective cohort study that evaluates the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP). The study includes women with increasing B-human chorionic gonadotropin (B-hCG) concentrations who are treated with a single dose of 100 mg MTX intravenously and 50 mg MTX in intra-amniotic injection (day 0), along with 30 mg potassium chloride in case of positive fetal heartbeat (FH), and subsequent hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC). The study compares two arms: MTX monotherapy and MTX + letrozole add-on. The primary outcome measures are blood loss during the procedure expressed as a decrease in hemoglobin concentration, blood loss volume during the procedure expressed in volume units, and conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage. Secondary outcome measures include the effect of treatment on bone marrow function (red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets), liver function (serum total bilirubin, alanine transaminase, aspartate transaminase, gamma-glutamyltransferase), and kidney function (urea, creatinine). The study is non-randomized and has a parallel assignment model. The study is open-label.

The BLEED study is a feasibility pilot study aimed at evaluating the feasibility of using donor blood for intraoperative transfusion support during liver transplantation. The study is designed as a single group assignment, open label study. The study population includes adult patients (≥ 18 years) receiving a liver transplant from deceased donors at Fondazione Policlinico A. Gemelli IRCCS. The intervention is a 3-step procedure consisting of 1) recovering blood from the donor during organ procurement; 2) processing donor blood to RBC units; 3) transfusing donor blood to recipients, if necessary during surgery. The primary outcome measure is the number and percentage of LT recipients successfully transplanted with internal donors, who received donor RBC concentrates for the intraoperative transfusion support during liver transplant. Secondary outcome measures include blood product need in enrolled patients and rate of graft failure in the prospective sample.

=================

This study was conducted in Mansoura University Hospitals, Chest Medicine Department on patients attended to Asthma and Allergy clinic. The study was designed to compare the efficacy of sublingual versus subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study included 50 asthmatic patients who were symptomatic and on medications either bronchodilators or inhaled corticosteroids (ICS). The study measured the total IgE and sputum eosinophil levels before and after 6, 12, and 18 months of treatment with immunotherapy vaccines. The study found that sublingual immunotherapy was more effective in reducing total IgE and sputum eosinophil levels than subcutaneous immunotherapy.

The study aims to determine the minimum number of CESB-guided tissue samples needed to establish a final histopathological biopsy diagnosis for ROLs. The study is a prospective, single center, observational cohort study. The study population includes non-pregnant women (>18 years) able to provide written informed consent and with a ROL recently observed during a regular CEM examination. The intervention includes an intravenous injection of iodinated contrast agent prior to image acquisition, followed by a contrast-enhanced stereotactic localization of the ROL to determine the location and depth of the lesion within the breast. After targeting, 18 samples will be acquired using a 9 Gauge vacuum-assistend biopsy (VAB), collected in six separate and numbered cassettes, to be able to determine the chronological order of the tissue sampling. Each specimen will be histologically analyzed in this chronological order and findings will be compared with the final histopathological result after assessment of all 18 specimens. The primary study aim will be to calculate the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen, enabling us to define a minimum number of biopsies required (or tissue volume needed) to establish a reliable diagnosis using CESB. Secondary study outcomes will be general parameters of the biopsy procedure itself, such as patient characteristics, histopathological results, pain experienced during the procedure, and complication rates (hematoma, infection).

===============

The study aims to compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in knee osteoarthritis. The study is a randomized, double-masked, parallel assignment study. Participants are adults aged 50-60 years with knee osteoarthritis, who have been experiencing knee pain due to tibiofemoral knee osteoarthritis for at least 6 months. Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which receives concentric muscle training or the control group, which receives facilitatory kinesiotaping. The study measures temporospatial gait parameters, pain due to knee osteoarthritis using a numerical pain rating scale, functional status using the WOMAC questionnaire, and quadriceps strength using a handheld dynamometer. The study will run for 6 weeks.

=========

The Family Therapy Training and Implementation Platform (FTTIP) Supplement Study is a qualitative study that aims to gather perceptions and experiences of trainees and agency leaders with the platform. The study will include 20 trainees and 16 agency leaders from the sample of the parent study. The proposed supplement aims to: 1) gather perceptions and experiences of the trainees about the process of learning and practicing specific CIFFTA competencies from the platform (time 1 interview) and later, about their unique experiences related to implementation of the Evidenced Based Treatment, delivery of competencies learned, and the application of EBT in a real-world context (time 2); and 2) gain a deeper understanding from leaders of their experiences in facilitating EBTs at their agencies, the identification of barriers that can be addressed by the organizational readiness work (time 1), and later regarding their agencies experience with the platform, consultation process, perceived cost-benefit, and agency readiness (at time 2). The study will measure the TIA Therapist Interview Timepoint 1 and TIA Therapist Interview Timepoint 2, and TIA Agency leader Interview Timepoint 1 and TIA Agency leader Interview Timepoint 2. The study will be conducted in French.

=============

A clinical study was conducted to evaluate the analgesic effect of freshly manufactured 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 in the treatment of herpes zoster pain and shoulder, neck, back and temporal pain. The study was conducted in the Department of pain diagnosis and treatment of the affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University. The study was designed as a single group assignment, open label, investigator-initiated off-label use clinical study. The study included 26 patients with shoulder, neck, back and temporal pain and 10 patients with herpes zoster pain. The study found that the 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 injection was effective in reducing pain scores in all shoulder, neck, back, temporal and herpes zoster pain. The study also found that the 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 injection was safe and well-tolerated. The study concluded that the 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 injection could be a potential treatment option for herpes zoster pain and shoulder, neck, back and temporal pain.

The study is a prospective randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the operative time, fluid deficit, complications, need for second intervention, pregnancy rate and live birth rate between two groups of women with septate or subseptate uterus who underwent hysteroscopic septoplasty with scissors or resectoscope. The study will be conducted at Mansoura University Hospital for at least 24 months. The sample size is calculated to be 16 patients in each group. The data will be analyzed using SPSS program for Windows. The primary outcome measure is operative time and secondary outcome measures are fluid deficit, complications, need for second intervention, pregnancy rate and live birth rate. The study will be approved by the Institutional Review Board and informed written consent will be obtained from each participant.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a respiratory training to cardiac coherence on the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and control. The experimental arm will receive a complementary respiratory training to cardiac coherence in addition to the usual care procedure, while the control arm will follow a usual care procedure in the event of Long COVID. The primary outcome measure will be the mean score on the Long COVID Symptom Tool (ST) scale score 0 to 53 / Higher score mean worse outcome at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the decrease of overall symptoms over time, the decrease of specific symptoms such as fatigue, dyspnoea, anxiety and depression, cognitive disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorder, as well as the impact of the disease on daily life. The study will be conducted at the Reunion University Hospital Cardiac Coherence and Long COVID Symptoms.

The study is a single-center cohort study that aims to evaluate the rate of patients developing atrial fibrillation (AF) after ibrutinib treatment for hematologic reasons. The study will include patients aged 18 and over who have given their free, written and informed consent to this study. The study will include an ophthalmological examination and a blood test at inclusion, 3 months and 6 months. The blood test will include a 2-mL tube of blood to test for blood markers predisposing to cardiovascular complications. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of patients developing AF 12 months after the introduction of ibrutinib. The study will be conducted in a single center.

=========

The study aims to investigate the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal during hemodialysis and blood pH in patients with phosphorus metabolism disorders and acid-base balance disorder. The study is a non-randomized, single-group assignment study with a 4-week treatment period. Participants are randomly assigned to one of three groups: Group 1 receives a constant Dbic of 35 mmol/L, Group 2 receives a constant Dbic of 30 mmol/L, and Group 3 receives a constant Dbic of 35 mmol/L. Blood acid-base and uremic solute levels are measured during the 4-hour treatments with arterial blood samples obtained predialysis and every hour during the treatment. The primary outcome measure is the blood phosphorus concentration change in hemodialysis patients using dialysate bicarbonate profiling. The secondary outcome measure is the maintaining the acid-base balance in accordance with applicable recommendations.

The study aims to evaluate the potential effectiveness of a multimodal intervention for the treatment of unipolar depression. The intervention involves the use of a neuro-stimulation technique, the Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (transcranial Direct Current Stimulation - tDCS), combined with a psychotherapy intervention, metacognitive therapy (MetaCognitive Therapy, MCT). TDCS is a noninvasive neurostimulation technique involving the transcranial application of a low-amperage electric current at a region of the cerebral cortex involved in the pathogenesis of major depression, the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. It has been demonstrated how such stimulation has a neuromodulating effect on synaptic plasticity, with efficacy in unipolar major depression. The technique also has a good safety, as it is not associated with major side effects. MCT is based on the metacognitive model, according to which psychopathological processes are consequent to a cognitive style characterized by repetitive forms of thinking (such as rumination) and maladaptive behaviors such as avoidance and thought suppression. The experimental design will be that of a randomized, double-blind study with three arms of treatment, each consisting of 8 sessions, involving the administration of 1) the neurostimulation intervention (tDCS), 2) of the psychotherapeutic intervention alone (MCT), 3) of both techniques in consecution (tDCS-MCT). This design is aimed at evaluating a potential additive/synergistic effect of the two interventions when combined. During the tDCS sessions, each lasting 20 minutes, the patient will apply the technique of attention training, aimed at further activating the region stimulated by neurostimulation, so as to so as to amplify the plasticity stimulated by tDCS, achieving a synergistic effect. To follow, a 40-minute MCT session will be carried out. The effectiveness of these interventions will be assessed by heteroadministered and self-administered at time zero, after treatment, at two follow-ups of 6 and 12 months. Before and after the treatment cycle (tDCS sessions and MCT sessions), a subgroup of patients will be explored, in the context of a pilot study,

===============

The Efficacy and Safety of Proton Pump Inhibitor (Lansoprazole) in Patients With Moderate Bleeding Risk and Coronary Artery Disease Undergoing Percutaneous Coronary Angioplasty: A Randomised, Open, Compared With Control Study

The study aims to compare gastrointestinal and cardiovascular events in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who underwent percutaneous coronary angioplasty (PCI) with the use of dual antiplatelet drugs (DAPT), especially the controversial use of prophylactic acid secretion inhibitors, and to confirm the effectiveness and safety of gastric acid secretion inhibitors. The study will enroll patients with moderate risk in gastrointestinal risk assessment indicators and randomly assign them to the gastric acid secretion inhibitor group and the non-dose group. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal clinical events in DAPT patients, and the secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of a cardiovascular clinical complex. The study will be conducted for 6 months after randomization.

The study aims to investigate the influence of hot and cold cognition on prospective memory in HIV+ patients. The study will use the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST) to assess prospective memory ability. The study will also use the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) to investigate global cognitive performance, the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) to assess cognitive and affective empathy (hot cognition), and the Modified Five Point Test to assess figurative fluency (cold cognition). The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The study will include both HIV+ patients and healthy control subjects. The study will be conducted in Italy. The study will be conducted in Italian.

=============

The study aims to determine the effects of vertical sitting versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with radicular low back pain. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two arms: Group-A (vertical sitting traction) and Group-B (supine lying traction). The study will measure the primary outcome measures using the Oswestry Disability Index and the Numeric Pain Rating Scale at the follow-up at 12th week. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

===============

The study is a randomized clinical trial comparing dry needling and lasertherapy in the treatment of greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS). The study includes participants with lateral hip pain for at least 3 months and who have reproduction of symptoms in at least one of four tests. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the dry needling group or the lasertherapy group. The intervention will consist of 6 weeks of treatment, twice a week, with the variables of interest being measured at several time points during the study. The primary outcome measure is change in pain intensity using the Visual Analog Pain Scale (VAS), while secondary outcome measures include change in hip function and lower limb function. The study will be double-blinded and will follow participants for 12 weeks after treatment.

The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a rapid technique for the detection of intestinal anti-transglutaminase antibodies to enable a real-time diagnosis of celiac disease. The study will include patients undergoing an elective esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) for suspected CD, eosinophilic esophagitis, autoimmune enteropathy, inflammatory bowel disease, gastritis, gastric or duodenal ulcer, gastroesophageal reflux disease. The study will measure the sensitivity and specificity of the rapid anti-TG2 test detected on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsies compared to the reference standard (serology + histopathology) at the time of endoscopic examination. The study will also measure the concordance of the EMA assay and rapid anti-TG2 test on supernatant of mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens with Culture-EMA results at the time of endoscopic examination. The study will not accept healthy volunteers.

The study aims to investigate the effects of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia in nurses with post COVID-19 condition. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and usual care. The study measures insomnia severity, sleep quality, sleep efficiency, anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. The study will run for 20 weeks, with data collection at baseline, 1, 2, and 3 months after the end of the intervention. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will recruit nurses with post COVID-19 condition who meet the inclusion criteria and do not meet the exclusion criteria. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will recruit nurses with post COVID-19 condition who meet the inclusion criteria and do not meet the exclusion criteria.

===============

The RAPID AFib Pilot Trial is a prospective, randomized pilot study that aims to evaluate the acceptability of the Risk Assessment and Personal Preference to Improve Decisions in Atrial Fibrillation (RAPID AFib) decision aid and its impact on the process of shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset AF. The study will be conducted in a real-world clinical setting and will randomize 1:1 patients with non-valvular AF diagnosed within 12 months, with any level of stroke risk assessed by CHA2DS2-VASc score. Patients will be invited to review an evidence-based website providing information about AF and its management. The intervention group will receive the RAPID AFib decision aid before their upcoming visit, while the control group will attend their clinic visit as scheduled. The primary outcome measure will be the 9-Item Shared Decision Making Questionnaire (SDM-Q-9: patient version) immediately after the clinic visit.

A Phase I, Randomised, Placebo-controlled Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of NNC0491-6075 Following Single Dose Administration to Healthy Participants and Multiple Doses to Participants With Dyslipidemia

===============

The study is a randomized, one-to-one selection of adult patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure who were admitted to ICU. The patients were divided into two groups: Group A, who received high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) as ventilatory support, and Group B, who received non-invasive ventilation (NIV) as ventilatory support. The study aimed to evaluate the efficiency of HFNC versus NIV in patients with acute hypercapnic respiratory failure. The primary outcome measure was the failure of treatment modality, which was defined as a failure of improvement of PH after 1 hour. The secondary outcome measures were mortality and ICU stay. The study used HFNC devices such as Airvo 2, Precision flow Hi-VNI ™ (Vapotherm ), or built-in HFNC mode in (e Volution ventilator ) and NIV devices such as Puritan Bennett™ 840 Ventilator and an oronasal mask of fitting size to each patient. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and was approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to support heart failure care in Uganda by implementing a digital-first care delivery model. The study will use a mixed methods process evaluation to inform iterative adjustments to the implementation processes. The study will also explore cost effectiveness and sustainability factors for Medly Uganda from a financial and societal perspective. The primary outcome measures will be change in self-care of heart failure index and clinical effectiveness. Secondary outcome measures will include participant fidelity to self-care, facility fidelity to implementation strategy, change in blood pressure, change in weight, change in resting pulse, percentage of planned echo training sessions conducted with post-training participant feedback, facility fidelity to implementation strategy assessed by the adherence to medications, change in 6-minute walk test, change in Pro-NT Brain Natriuretic Peptide (Pro-NT BNP), change in Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction, change in Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ), change in EuroQol -5D (EQ-5D), and change in Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9).

=================

This is a phase I, open-label, balanced, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover, oral comparative pharmacokinetic (PK) study of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets, 400mg/50mg of Overseas Pharmaceuticals, Ltd. with Motrin IB (ibuprofen tablets USP) and BENADRYL (diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablet) distributed by Johnson & Johnson Consumer Inc., McNeil Consumer Healthcare Division in healthy adults under fasting conditions. The study aims to compare the PK of the test product (ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets) and the reference product (Motrin IB and BENADRYL) in healthy adults under fasting conditions. The study will be conducted in two cycles, with each cycle consisting of two treatment periods. In each treatment period, subjects will receive either the test product or the reference product. The study will be conducted in a phase I ward of the clinical research center, and subjects will be randomly divided into two groups, T-R and R-T, with 8 participants each. The selected subjects will be admitted to the phase I ward of the clinical research center 1 day before each cycle and fasted for more than 10h before each cycle. At 0 h (within 1.0 h before administration), and 5 min, 15 min, 30 min, 45 min, 1.0 h, 1.25 h, 1.5 h, 2.0 h, 2.5 h, 3.0 h, 3.5 h, 4.0 h, 4.5 h, 5.0 h, 5.5 h, 6.0 h, 7.0 h, 8.0 h, 9.0 h, 10.0 h, 12.0 h, 24.0 h, 36.0 h, and 48.0 h, Upper limb venous blood will be collected at 25 time points, About 1.0

The study is a multicentre prospective observational study that aims to evaluate the impact of apalutamide in metastatic hormone sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) patients. The study will include patients with mHSPC and a treatment decision for apalutamide by clinician. The primary outcome measure is the undetectable PSA rate (defined as PSA <0.2ng/ml by end of year 1 and year 2) in mHSPC patients receiving apalutamide. Secondary outcome measures include the impact of apalutamide on fatigue, cognitive function, and health-related quality of life, assessed using patient-reported questionnaires. The study will run from August 2023 to April 2027.
