The study is a phase 1/2 study of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) or malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT). The study is designed to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of combination treatment with oral idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT in the dose finding/safety phase. The study will also evaluate the safety and efficacy of combination treatment in the expansion phase. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the dose finding/safety phase, patients will receive idasanutlin and selinexor at different dose levels and will be closely monitored for adverse events. The MTD will be determined based on the safety and tolerability of the treatment. In the expansion phase, patients will receive the MTD of combination treatment and will be closely monitored for adverse events and response to treatment. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of radial shortening and capitate shortening in the treatment of ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study includes 2 arms: radial shortening and capitate shortening. The study measures the primary outcome using the modified Mayo wrist score. The study includes 25 participants, aged 18-65 years, with stages II and III ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study is conducted over a 1-year period.

Prehabilitation in Pancreatic Cancer Patients Undergoing Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Pancreatic cancer is a highly aggressive and lethal disease with a poor prognosis. The combination of surgical resection and neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the most effective treatment for pancreatic cancer. However, the surgery is associated with a high risk of postoperative complications and poor recovery. Prehabilitation is a multidisciplinary intervention that aims to improve the functional capacity of patients before surgery, thus reducing the risk of postoperative complications and improving the recovery.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week preoperative intervention in improving the functional capacity of patients undergoing pancreatic cancer surgery. The intervention includes exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety reduction techniques. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 226 patients. The primary outcome measure is the Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI) at 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include functional capacity, time to patient functional recovery, length of stay, and bioimpedance analysis-derived body composition.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board. Patients will be informed about the study and will provide written informed consent.

The study will be conducted in a single center. Patients will be recruited from the surgical unit of the hospital. Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (multimodal prehabilitation) or the control group (usual care). The intervention will be conducted for 4 weeks before surgery. The study will be conducted for 90 days after surgery.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in improving balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental group will receive conventional rehabilitation and dual task exercise training, while the active comparator group will receive conventional rehabilitation only. The study will measure the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6-Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with assessments conducted before and after the interventions.

The study is a pilot study to investigate the zoonotic transmission of influenza viruses in Belgium. The study will be conducted in four groups: Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms, Poultry Farm Sentinel Network, Wild bird/life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network, and Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network. Participants will be invited to take part in the study if they are a worker or volunteer of one of the targeted groups at one of the selected sites and accepting to take part in the study to have regular contacts with animals within job/activity framework being committed to take the regular samples. The study will be conducted for a period of 2 weeks for Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms, 2 weeks for Poultry Farm Sentinel Network, Wild bird/life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network, and Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network. The study will measure the number of sentinel participants positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus and the number of outbreak participants positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will also measure the number of outbreak participants with seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will use RT-qPCR test to detect and characterize non-influenza viruses and inhibition of haemagglutination or seroneutralisation assay to detect seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus.

The study is a longitudinal, within-person design with two parallel conditions. In one condition, youth receive a 6-week canine therapy intervention. The other condition consists of treatment as usual. The subject population are youth that are in a full-time residential treatment facility in Lawrence Hall. The Recovery & Care Canine-Assisted Therapy intervention is a 1.25 hour structured curriculum that will occur weekly across a period of 6 weeks. The program will be delivered by the Canine Therapy Corps (CTCorps). Youth will work with CTC-affiliate staff, including trained dog-handler teams, a canine behavior expert, and a clinical supervisor to engage in a series of structured activities progress throughout the intervention. The primary outcome measures are Emotional Stroop, Flanker Task, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, and Change in Negative Affect. Secondary outcome measures include Attendance and Attrition, Change in Positive Affect, Significant Event Report, and Change in Attitudes towards Pets. The study is designed to evaluate the impact of a canine-assisted therapy program in youth residing in a residential treatment center.

=============

This study is a randomized controlled prospective study that aims to investigate the effect of myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will be conducted with two randomized groups of young adults with flexible pes planus, one group will be applied an exercise program including only foot core exercises, while the other group will be applied self myofascial release with foam rollers, which is a myofascial release method, in addition to foot core exercises. Both the experimental and control groups will receive a program consisting of 7 different foot core exercises, each of which will be progressed gradually for 6 weeks, 3 sets of 10 repetitions per day. A brochure for the exercises will be prepared and given to the participants to do at home. In order to follow up the exercise of the participants, the individuals will be called weekly during this period and exercise follow-up will be performed. The experimental group will also be planned to perform 60 seconds of myofascial release on each tissue on the thoracolumbar fascia, iliotibial band, hamstring, gastro-soleus, peroneals and plantar fascia 2 days a week for 6 weeks with foam roller, which is a self-myofascial release method. At the end of six weeks, the initial evaluations will be performed again on all individuals and the measurement results will be analyzed.

The study aims to investigate whether training of the arms can reduce pain when inserting a peripheral venous catheter and how it is experienced that there can be challenges with vein status for patients in cytostatic treatment. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study with an 8-week daily arm training program as the intervention. The primary outcome measures are pain level as measured by the Numeric Rating Scale at baseline, after five weeks of training/control, and after eight weeks of training/control. Secondary outcome measures include vein status as assessed via ultrasound at baseline, after five weeks of training/control, and after eight weeks of training/control. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of arm training in reducing pain and improving vein status in patients undergoing cytostatic treatment.

The study aims to determine whether decidual leukocyte subpopulations and their associated activation markers are different between women having miscarriage of either a trisomy 16 conceptus (47XY+16 or 47XX+16) compared with a chromosomally normal male conceptus (46XY) and compared with gestationally age-matched decidual tissues. The study will use ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) as a treatment option for managing with miscarriage or termination of pregnancy (TOP) in first trimester loss. The study will measure the histopathologic diagnosis of chorionic villi and immunohistochemistry staining of maternal decidua. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board of The Chinese University of Hong Kong.

The SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study is a single-arm, prospective study designed to evaluate the performance characteristics and technical outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes in patients with gastrointestinal tract disease undergoing clinically indicated ERCP or other duodenoscope-based procedures. The study will enroll 100 patients who meet the inclusion criteria and will follow them for 24 months. The primary outcome measures will be technical performance and procedural performance. The study will assess technical performance by evaluating the device's ability to perform specific tasks, such as biopsy acquisition and stent placement, and procedural performance by assessing the device's ability to complete the procedure safely and effectively. The study will also evaluate the device's durability, ease of use, and cost-effectiveness. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

===============

The Hybrid Pulmonary Rehabilitation Study is a feasibility study that aims to assess the feasibility of a technology-enabled hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation programme for patients with chronic respiratory disease. The study will use the UKCA/CE Class I-approved and DTAC-certified Active+me REMOTE App (Aseptika Ltd www.activ8rlives.com) to deliver a hybrid PR programme that may be used to support a move to a remotely delivered service. The study will recruit patients with chronic respiratory disease who are referred to the Harefield Pulmonary Rehabilitation Programme and will compare outcomes for patients recruited to a Hybrid PR Intervention with a propensity-matched Control Group that has previously received Standard PR. Additional data will be collected from the Hybrid PR group (via Active+me REMOTE / Trial Surveys) to provide supporting evidence relating to uptake, adherence, clinical outcomes (not routinely recorded in standard practice), and usability/acceptability of the Hybrid PR programme. The study will generate evidence to support larger trial to compare effectiveness of a Hybrid PR vs Standard PR delivery model on patient uptake, adherence and outcomes, and service capacity. The aim of the larger trial is to provide definitive evidence to inform clinical guidelines for PR delivery.

===============

An observational study will be conducted to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD as pre-exposure prophylaxis against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19 in Japan. The study will use secondary data from a database and will include patients who have a record of administration of EVUSHELD in the database. The index date will be defined as the date of first EVUSHELD administration in the database (Day 0) and the patients will be followed up to 6 months after the index date (Day 1 to 180). The primary outcome measure will be the demographics and clinical characteristics of patients received Evusheld as PrEP, while the secondary outcome measures will be the event rate and time to event for medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all cause mortality up to 180 days after the date of first administration of Evusheld. The study will be conducted in Japan and will be an observational, cohort study.

============

This is a phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study of risankizumab for the treatment of adult subjects with moderate to severe genital psoriasis or moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of risankizumab in these patient populations. The study will enroll 200 participants, who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (risankizumab) or the control group (placebo for risankizumab). The study will have two arms: Study G and Study S. Study G will assess the efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe genital psoriasis, while Study S will assess the efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study will have a 52-week treatment period, followed by an 8-week follow-up period. The primary outcome measures for the study will include the percentage of participants with achievement of static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1 in Study G and the percentage of participants with achievement of Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 in Study S. Secondary outcome measures will include the percentage of participants with achievement of Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) of 0 or 1, the percentage of participants with achievement of Clinically Meaningful (>= 4-point) Improvement from Baseline on the Genital Psoriasis Itch Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) [Among Participants with a Baseline Score >= 4], and the percentage of participants with achievement of Genital Psoriasis Sexual Frequency Questionnaire (GenPs-SFQ) Item 2 score of 0 or 1 among Participants with a Baseline score >= 2. The study will also assess the safety and efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe scalp psoriasis, as measured by the percentage of participants with achievement of Psoriasis Scalp Severity Index (PSSI 90) and the percentage of participants with achievement of PSSI 75. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsink

The study is a descriptive cross-sectional study of patients with a diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis. The study will collect demographic data, and dichotomous data indicating whether a patient has the variation or does not have the variation, and if the variation is present in one hand or both hands. The study will take place at the Bone and Joint Center at 1365 Washington Avenue, Albany New York, and satellite offices in Guilderland, Clifton Park, Malta, Saratoga, Schenectady and Catskill. Data will be collected for up to two years. There are no risks to patients enrolled in the study, as the test involves asking the patient to simply bend the tip of their thumb. Documentation of the variation is not usually noted in the chart. Therefore, the physicians involved in the study will be asked to include the findings of the variation in their documentation. The patients will be informed during clinical examination if they have a LCV. There is no compensation to participants for enrolling in the study.

=============

This is a phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of atogepant for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric subjects 6-17 years of age. The study includes two PK substudies and a double-blind treatment period. The primary outcome measure is change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, change from baseline in mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants who achieve at least a 50% reduction in average of monthly migraine days, change from baseline in the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) total score, and change from baseline in the Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment (PedMIDAS) total score. Eligibility criteria include a weight of 20 kg to 135 kg, a history of episodic migraine with or without aura consistent with a diagnosis according to the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD) -3 (2018), and 4 to 14 migraine days and < 15 headache days in the 28-day baseline period per eDiary. The study is being conducted at multiple sites in the United States.

===============

The study aims to examine the effects of a 2-week home-based training program with a 4-week follow-up on touchscreen sliding motions delivered on a tablet in patients with Parkinson's disease. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 36 participants, who will be randomized (strata: age, H&Y stage) in the experimental or control group. The primary outcome measure will be the average slide duration (in ms) after two weeks of training, while the secondary outcome measures will include performance accuracy (in %), retention effects on average slide duration (in ms) after four weeks follow-up, and consolidation effects of two weeks of training. The study will use an extensive screening session, including motor and non-motor screening, to assess the association with training responsiveness. The study will also explore whether compliance to training has an impact on learning effects within the training group by using a correlation analysis between compliance rates and training-related changes in performance.

===============

The study is a non-randomized quasi-experimental study that investigates the effect of intensified tactile contact between a mother and newborn on the emotional transformation of women after physiological delivery. The study was conducted in a local childbirth school and the participants were selected from the local population of pregnant women who volunteered to provide experimental intervention to their children after birth. The intervention was applied in the form of Shantali massage and lasted until the end of the 12th week after birth. The study used four standardized, self-reported psychological questionnaires to measure the level of emotions in the designated 'negative' domain (depression, anxiety, negative affects) and the level of emotions in the designated 'positive' domain (satisfaction, sense of effectiveness, positive affects). The study found that the direction of the mother's emotional transformation was different after the intensification of tactile contact with the newborn in comparison to the control group. The study also found that the intervention was effective in reducing the level of depression, anxiety, negative affects, and increasing the level of satisfaction and effectiveness in the experimental group.

=================

This is a phase 2, open-label, randomized, parallel-group, multi-centre study of the efficacy and safety of paclitaxel + bevacizumab + atezolizumab versus paclitaxel + bevacizumab in patients with NSCLC who have progressed after treatment with immunotherapy and a doublet of platinum-based chemotherapy, given concomitantly or sequentially. The study will enroll 100 patients. The primary objective is to assess the progression-free survival at 6 months determined by independent reviewer. Secondary objectives include progression-free survival, objective response rate, overall survival, time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, and incidence, nature, and severity of adverse events. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the role of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in the management of persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study is a pilot prospective cohort study that includes patients with at least one symptom of post-COVID-19 that has persisted for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis. The study provides OMT at the discretion of the treating physician and based on the patient's response to previous treatments. The primary outcome measures include patient recruitment rate and data completion rate, while the secondary outcome measures include neurocognitive and psychological symptoms, physical symptoms, global health, and return to work. The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year, with data collected 3 days after every other OMT session for up to 4 months after enrollment and 2 months after the participant's final OMT session. The study will use the Rivermead Post Concussion Symptoms Questionnaire, the Long COVID-Household Pulse Survey, the PROMIS SF v1.2 Global Health scale, and a 4-point scale to assess return to work. The study will be conducted in French and will be conducted in a single center in Quebec, Canada.

=================

The study is a pilot study that compares the use of ICG microangiography and conventional angiography in severe frostbite patients. The study is designed to assess the concordance or discordance of the two imaging modalities in demonstrating ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite. The study will use the Hennepin Frostbite Score to assess the imaging results. The study will also assess the safety of ICG when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography. The study will be conducted over an average of 2 years.

=============

The study is a randomized, open-label, controlled study that compares the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who are operated on for colorectal cancer. The study includes two arms: a control group that receives classical management in the digestive surgery department and a GPOU group that receives treatment in the Peri-Operative Geriatrics Unit to optimize specific geriatric care. The primary outcome measure is the change in functional status after colorectal cancer surgery between groups, measured using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score at baseline and month 3. Secondary outcome measures include changes in functional status, basic functional status, patient motor ability, patient satisfaction with care, length of hospital stay, medical complications during hospitalization, surgical complications, destination of patients on discharge from hospital, change in patient weight, patient quality of life, change in the patient's place of abode, and overall survival. The study is designed to measure the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who are operated on for colorectal cancer.

============

A Follow-up Study to Describe the Safety of Study Participants Who Received RSVPreF3 Maternal Vaccination (Any Dose) or Controls From Previous RSV MAT Studies During Any Pregnancy Conceived Post Vaccination/Control

The study is a phase 3b, non-randomized, open label, multi-country, cohort study to describe the safety of study participants who received RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination (any dose) or controls from previous RSV MAT studies (RSV MAT-001, RSV MAT-004, RSV MAT-010, RSV MAT-011, RSV MAT-009, RSV MAT-012 and RSV MAT-039) during any pregnancy conceived post vaccination/control. The study includes both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine). The primary outcome measures are the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy related adverse events of special interest (AESIs) from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs from birth up to Day 42 post-birth of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of maternal participants reporting selected pregnancy outcomes and pregnancy related AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those outcomes, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those events. The study is designed as a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with an open label design. The study will be conducted in multiple countries and will enroll both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine).

===============

This is a cross-sectional pilot study of 19F MRI in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis lung disease. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of using 19F MRI in these populations and to assess the primary and secondary outcome measures. The study will recruit 6-17 year old participants who are non-smokers and non-vapers, have a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, and have stable lung function. Participants will breathe a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, during the MRI procedures, and the 19F-tuned MRI will be used to image the lungs and chest. The primary outcome measures will include the participation rate, completion rate, and parental and child acceptability scores. The secondary outcome measures will include MRI defined ventilation defect parameters and fraction of lung volume with slow gas washout time in healthy participants and participants with cystic fibrosis.

=================

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing open and closed chain exercises in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome. The study will be conducted in Pakistan sports board Lahore, Model town Sports Club Lahore and Sheikh Zaid Hospital, Lahore. The sample size will be taken to evaluate the effects of open chain exercise and closed chain exercise among athletes with an age group of 18 - 40 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to 2 groups. Group A will include participants who will receive open kinetic chain exercises 3sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise along with the general training. Group B will include the participants who will receive closed kinetic chain exercises 3sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise along with general training. The subjects will be assessed for pain, function and balance at baseline and after 6weeks of treatment. The primary outcome measures will be Numerical Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) and Y Balance test.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study will include 30 athletes, 15 in each group, with 95% confidence (1-α), 95% test power (1-β) and f=0.6 effect size; with 80% confidence (1-α), 80% test power (1-β) and f=0.6 effect size, a total of 20 athletes, 10 in each group, should be included. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 weeks, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the MIND diet group or the control group. The MIND diet group will receive nutritional advice and will be asked to include the food groups in the MIND diet in their diet in accordance with their consumption frequency. The control group will maintain their usual eating habits. The primary outcome measures will include tau protein, NfL (Neurofilament light polypeptide), S100B protein, BDNF (Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor), telomere, zonulin, NOX2 (NADPH oxidase), 8-OHdG (8- hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine), F2-isoprostanes (F2-isoPs), hs-CRP (High-sensitivity C-reactive protein), IL-6 (Interleukin 6), and TNF-α (Tumor necrosis factor alpha). The secondary outcome measures will include sleep quality score and quality of life score.

The study aims to evaluate the acute success rate of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in heart failure patients with ejection fraction below normal. The study will measure the acute success rate of LBBAP and acute procedure-related complications. The study will also measure the incidence of repeat procedures, pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy including biventricular cardiac pacing, heart failure hospitalization, cardiovascular death, all-cause death, left ventricular ejection fraction, left ventricular end diastolic diameter, left ventricular end systolic diameter, left ventricular global strain, capture threshold, sensing, and impedance. The study will be conducted in two arms: prospective LBBAP-HF cohort and retrospective LBBAP-HF cohort. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study is a Phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single site, single ascending dose study of the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adults. The study is designed to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 in healthy adults. The study will enroll 24 healthy adults, aged 18 to 50 years, inclusive, with a minimum weight of 50.0 kg and maximum weight of 100.0 kg, BMI within the range of 18.0 to 32.0 kg/m2, inclusive. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months. The primary outcome measures will include treatment-emergent adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, and AEs leading to discontinuation. Secondary outcome measures will include Cmax, AUCinf, AUClast, Tmax, and t1/2. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.
